description:
This is a super quirky, cozy and intimate spot. It's a little difficult to find if you're not paying attention -- it's located inside a dark alley almost. I found it by just paying attention to the actual address (2275 Market). There's a little sign inside the alley that will direct you to Sushi Time, just walk down the short stairs and you'll see it to your left! 

This place is definitely super tiny, so seating is limited. Service was quick and friendly. I was lucky enough to get a tight table but don't be surprised if you have to wait or sit at the bar! 

Sushi was great. The sashimi was very fresh ($8.25 for 3 pcs) but small portioned. I suggest getting nigiri if you want something raw -- the slice will be bigger (2 pcs for $5.25) 

I ordered the spicy salmon roll (roughly $7) and the oshinko roll ($3.50). Both were decent! 

This is a great spot if you want fast, fresh and delicious sushi for a fair price! Also very clean which is a plus. Definitely a cozy and nice, casual date place. They offer happy hour from 5-6 PM if you're free!
author: Kimberly G.

description:
I am not sure what all of these 5 star reviews are coming from. Pretty average type of sushi place and service. 

Small place and hidden. 

The service was okay. Nothing I will remember. 

I heard the owner is also serving but if so he wasn't as friendly to us. Maybe he was having a bad day. Everyone does. For that is my 1 star.  Maybe if I ever come back, he will be having a better day. 

Good luck.
author: Jayden R.

description:
Despite the weirdly generic name, I LOVED this tiny sushi spot. It is a little hard to find-- kind of underground in a random alleyway spot. We only found it because they gave a random sandwich sign on the street pointing towards the general direction of the entrance haha. 

The inside is very intimate, probably seating no more than 20. The three of us sat at the bar area, where we had a view of the chefs making their creations. 

Service staff was quick and courteous. The ambiance is cozy, romantic. Lots of quirky wall decor. Lots of tables of twos. 

I ordered the tekka don (tuna on rice with miso soup and side salad). It was a little pricey ($22) but I think well worth it. The tuna was absolutely delicious! Buttery and melt-in-your-mouth quality, atop perfectly seasoned sushi rice. Very simple but so delicious! 

I will be back!! I think they do reservations, especially if you have a bigger group!
author: RachEl L.

description: Enjoyed chirashi at this quirky sushi restaurant. My friends brought me to this little hidden gem on Halloween weekend. A tiny space but very charming with yummy food.
author: P C.

description:
This place is ADORABLE. Probably perfect for a weeknight date. 

Note: this place is SUPER small, about 4 tables so there will sometimes be a wait. This is however, part of their draw, it's quite cute and cozy on the inside, and I love the decor. 

The service is excellent, and the fish was fresh and well prepared. The rice however was a little too stiff, and felt like it had been sitting out for a little too long. 

Overall, I'd come back if only to impress my date with my ability to find hipster sushi places.
author: Sophie W.

description:
Tucked away, under the stairs from Market Street, it's curved glass windows beckon. Small place, small bar, a few tables. Wonderful sakes, nice beers, good flights. The fish is so fresh and tasty, the service attentive and helpful. Always a delightful and delicious time.
Enjoy!
author: William M.

description:
This was my first time at sushi time. I was delightfully surprised by the quality of sushi. The location is tucked away out of sight which makes this place that much more of a gem. 

There are limited amount of seats and it seems like a hole in the wall but it's really great.

I tried the Rainbow roll which colorful and tasty. There's a different piece of sashimi on each piece of sushi.

You should come during happy hour as the rolls are only $5  or $5.50. It's definitely worth it.

There are many sushi options in S.F but you should give this a try.
author: Jeremiah Z.

description: Such delicious sushi! Simple rolls but are so good you don't want all the distraction! Tiny place but part of the experience!
author: Britt B.

description:
I frequently stop here for take-out sushi when I'm on my way home after a long day of work, but I love dining inside when I can, too. The ambiance makes you feel like you're stepping into a sushi spot in Japan. Set back from the hustle and bustle of the other restaurants and bars on Market, it's a little difficult to find--otherwise, I think it'd be a much more popular sushi spot in the Castro/Duboce area.

While I've enjoyed everything I've tried here, my favorite is the Barbie roll. The thinly sliced lemon is so refreshing and pairs perfectly with the fresh pieces of salmon. Simple but unique!
author: Kelly R.

description: This is a good place to get the chirashi bowl. It's a good deal because the portions are generous, and it includes a side salad and miso soup. The atmosphere is unique because the place is underground and is decorated with origami and Japanese-patterned fabrics. Overall, this is one of my go-to's.
author: Andrea T.

description: I love this place.  Always yummy.  Tuna Carpacchio is divine   Staff are always attentive and kind.  I love the quality.  Happy hour is really great  but more than that consistently excellent.
author: allen C.

description:
Pretty average sushi spot. Neither loved it or hated it but I am shocked from all the five star reviews! Came here for a last minute happy hour dinner with my cousin. I had to sit at the bar because she hadn't arrived yet so make sure your whole party is there if you want to sit at a table. 

I only had ten minutes to order so I got four rolls, the tofu salad, the sashimi five, two scoops of sesame ice cream, and a large hot sake. The happy hour deal isn't actually that great. The rolls are only $1 off the regular price and its bizarre how they try to nickel and dime you at every turn. It costs $1 if you want a shiso leaf like wtf?! The whole menu has shit like that. Minimum charges per person, extra $1 here, extra 50 cents there. Oh and they charge for gluten free soy sauce too wtf. Werid. 

The rolls were huge and tasty. The spicy tuna roll is SUPER spicy though. I've never had one so spicy before. The sashimi was just okay. The first piece of salmon sashimi I had was super fishy and gross but the other pieces were fine. Loved the tofu salad and its huge. Ice cream scoops were big too. We left completely stuffed. 

Decor here is beyond cute. I love every little detail of it. Service is fine too. Everyone here I think is Chinese. It was kind of funny hearing the chefs speak in Chinese about how they were going to have noodles for dinner.
author: Tiffany V.

description:
Honestly a 3.5 star sushi spot, but one of the better and accessible options in the Castro. I feel Takara has better seasonal menu, but is harder to get into if you don't time it right.

The first time I went to Sushi Time was one of the last nights my friend was in town before his worldly travel session. He let me know its a bit difficult to find - you enter a courtyard, head downstairs to something that feels oddly authentic. With the curved front window, small bar, and only a handful of seats this feels like something you could experience in Japan. 

The menu is fairly simple as this is primarily focused on sushi - they have some basic appetizers, some standard nigiri and the biggest option/reason to come are the affordable rolls. That said, always take a look at their specials menu. On my most recent trip they had Hawaiian kampachi and Hamachi Toro.

The first time I came, I did a mix of the nigiri (because I'm a fish snob) while my friends mostly did the rolls, and then I ate some of their rolls. The second time my friend and I split a few rolls. We got:

Hawaiian kampachi sashimi: I wanted to introduce my friend to a fish he can't get back on the East coast. A nice, flavorful whitefish and these were solid sized pieces (looking at you Akiko!)
Rainbow Roll: It's a rainbow roll. If you like a variety of fish, this is the safest bet
Astroboy: They weren't kidding with the spicy scallop. This had plenty of heat but was really good.
Speed Racer: Tuna and mango. Simple, cheap, but yummy.
Barbie Roll: Basically a rainbow roll but with all salmon. 

For drinks they offer a solid selection of teas and sake. I've had the delightful genmaicha from the tea menu and I've done a sake sampling here before. 

So if looking for an affordable, accessible, roll-focused sushi place in the Castro that's also a cute date spot, can definitely recommend Sushi Time. If looking for a fish purist spot, would probably hit up Takara instead.
author: Michael C.

description: Came here on a visit to the west coast. It's a rather small restaurant. We came with a party of 6, but they sat us at a table for 4. When the table next to us cleared we asked to have that table join ours, they said they'd only do that if we ordered a lot of food. I wasn't sure what "a lot" is, but we didn't press the issue. Several entrees that were ordered came with soup and salad. There's a lack of awareness with the servers, they overall didn't come off very friendly/welcoming. One was right by our table but it still took two inquiries to get spoons for the soup. The food itself was received well with the group. I personally loved the barbie roll. Also be aware that there is a minimum order of $10/person. I'm not sure if I'd come back and visit if I came to SF. I may order the barbie roll for take out if I do.
author: Katie V.

description:
A friend of mine told me to check this place out for sushi. I have been to the Castro numerous times and have NEVER known this spot was there! It is tucked away in the back downstairs of the entrance from Market Street, which is hard notice it is there, but it is worth it!

Although the place is smaller than your usual sit down sushi restaurant, it makes it a lot more intimate. When arriving, expect to have to wait for a little bit. Luckily, we were able to get sat down right away, but about 10 minutes later, the place was full and people had started to wait outside for tables to open. The food is very much worth the wait.

I got 3 rolls (forgot which ones) but all three rolls were delicious and I finished them all! The miso soup was also very good as a starter! All in all, with the three rolls and soup, I paid about $28 which I found to be inexpensive for a sushi spot. The service is also a plus!
author: Michael T.

description: Sushi was very poorly rolled, would come apart. My girlfriend told the waiver multiple times she had a gluten allergy and yet the rolls she order made her incredibly sick. Avoid if you're celiac or like quality sushi
author: Diego A.

description: Great spot for sushi. Small but cozy, affordable, and good value for the price. Good for casual dining, not a fancy place
author: Jesus M.

description: So much better than all the pretentious sushi spots you'll find in SF. Delicious sushi that's not trying too hard. Sushi Time is also very reasonably priced and the service is great. Loved the Astro Boy roll and the Tai Carpaccio.
author: Sara M.

description: Good sushi at cheap prices. I went here to celebrate with my boyfriend. It's cute and really quaint. The staff was nice and attentive. They have amazing vegetarian rolls and the fish rolls were good too.
author: Lexi A.

description: Great value for what you get. Been going here for years. The rolls are solid and not too extravagant but for the price, you get pretty decent sushi. The sashimi is also generously portioned and well cut by chef.  This is more of a pick up joint than a dine in experience but have done both.
author: Timothy W.

description:
husband found this spot on yelp and we came right when they opened.
through an alleyway and down the stairs (at the far back, not the first set of stairs!)

Kind of reminds you of Japan, but definitely Chinese owned. Came for the HH.

Small menu but if you're just here for a light snack and drinks, you are all set. the rolls tasted pretty fresh, we even ended up ordering from the regular menu as well.
Love how they let you pick your own sake cup, fun!

the place started filling up really fast, so get there early!
We will be back if in the area
author: Christine M.

description: A friend who lived in Japan and has been to loads of sushi bars turned me on to this little spot. It's off Market down stairs don't be deterred it seems like a random space but the food is excellent, fish super fresh and you feel like you're in a little subway station eatery. Low key and quiet inside.
author: Spoon G.

description: Fresh, delicious and not insanely expensive so I'll definitely be back for more!  It's tiny and can fill up quickly but service is fast so if you have to wait, it shouldn't be too long.
author: Janelle F.

description:
Checked out their happy hour. Good prices and decent selection of food items on the menu. However, the sushi had an unusually large quantity of rice with very little filling. I get that I'm paying less than usual, but other sushi happy hours in the Castro don't skimp on their food (try Takara!)

Sorry Sushi Time, I was very disappointed with my experience and won't be coming back.
author: Jaching H.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised by this little hole in the wall sushi place.

I was visiting from out of town and I am a total sushi snob. I found this place had nice yelp reviews and intriguing sushi pictures. Came here with a friend for dinner, waited 30 min to be seated (place is tiny only seats probably about 10).

Our order came quickly and WOW was it delicious. High quality fish and large pieces of it, just how I like my sushi. 

Also they had delicious saki and we split the saki trio which was more than enough. If I lived near by this would become a classic sushi place for me.

Prices are very justifiable for the food that they serve you!

Job well done!
author: Ashley K.

description:
This place is awesome! Most of the reasons why I gave this a 5-star is because their happy hr menu and the experience. First off, I love how it's almost like an underground hidden sushi joint. This place seats about 15 people at one time. 

The menu is legit with rolls, apps, drinks, etc. the basics! I recommend coming for happy hr which basically starts at opening (5pm). I recommend their spicy tuna roll, Philly roll, and their Shrimp tempura roll. Their Uni is alright but I do recommend trying it just once. 

Pair your sushi with some quality sake! I recommend their Lg Filtered cold sake which goes for about $18 premium and their Lg unfiltered sweet sake for about $10! 

This place will not disappoint! If you're looking for a higher quality sushi joint then go to a high end sushi joint but otherwise if you're just craving good ol' sushi (B-) then come here! This place is fun, friendly, and calm!
author: Allister D.

description: I went with John & Jessie and had a great time! We had the Rainbow roll, seaweed salad, plum wine, green tea Mochi, Rock and roll and California roll -- highly recommend it all!! :)
author: Brian W.

description:
Yellow tail collar was yummy, 4 stars.
Surfer roll, 4 stars.
Uni, 3 stars.
Seafood salad, 2 stars.
Rock n Roll roll, 3.5 stars.
Service 5 stars.

Good place to eat, I recommend it.
author: Martin R.

description:
This restaurant really didn't look like a sushi restaurant (or any type of restaurant) from outside, other than the sign that says "Sushi Time" around it. It looked like a glass tube of a metro train car or something sticking out from a wall.  The entrance was small, with lots of Japanese decorations, and the fun, cheerful decoration continued inside all the way from the entrance to the back. We were greeted with very warm smile and welcome by Japanese owner and staff. I was super happy to see that it was operated by Japanese people, that meant that I was going to have some good, authentic sushi!

Inside was a bit narrow, just like a train car. Even though it is located underground, the glass tube exterior brought in lots of light. In order to provide some privacy, they had bamboo and cloth covering on that side. Not many seating there, the sushi counter extended about half or a bit more than half of this "train car" shaped restaurant, and several tables and chairs behind it. Once it gets crowded, it can get a bit warm, since they don't have any window or good ventilation (they had a fan running at the back to provide some air flow). 

We went during the happy hour, and got some sashimi and sushi. They were fresh, nice portion, and very delicious. We were happy with everything we ordered, and even though the happy hour menu is not very much, but it was still worth it to go there for the happy hour.
author: June S.

description:
Would not have found this place if it weren't for yelp. This place is underground/hidden in the Castro around a bunch of small shops. It is tiny with a few tables and a bar. Very cutely decorated and would almost feel authentic but it is Chinese run, not Japanese.

I came here on a Saturday and wanted to order from the happy hour. +1 star that they have happy hour every day from 5-6PM. The happy hour prices aren't exactly that cheap either though. It is also +$1 per person for tea. For two, we ordered the albacore tataki sashimi $11 (4 pieces), two Alaska rolls, and a kamikaze roll. The albacore was a bit bland, and the dipping sauce that came with it was too sour. It didn't taste too fresh.

The Alaska rolls were $5.75 each. Fairly decent price and tasted good. No wasabi was given. I also thought the kamikaze roll was okay. Didn't try too many items here. The prices are high for the bentos, all ranging $19 and up. Quality of sushi and fish is average. Overall decent, not the best.
author: Christina G.

description:
Cool underground sushi place! The sushi is super fresh and since the place is very tiny, it is easy to get the servers' attention. If you sit at the bar, you can speak to the sushi chefs directly. 

The place is very small, though. It is a great place for 2 or 3 people, but not more than that.
author: Do P.

description: Sake flights and sushi. We loved this place! Prices were just right and service was awesome. Lucky we didn't have to wait long for a table. We will recommend to friends visiting!
author: Niccole D.

description:
So do you know about those sleeping tubes in Tokyo where Japanese businessmen too wasted on sake miss the last train to the 'burbs? They end up overnight in those little capsule-shaped compartments with their wives nary the wiser for their drunken escapades. I only bring those up because when I entered Sushi Time, that's what it feels like. I walked by the sandwich sign for the place all the time, so my curiosity got the best of me one evening and I gave it a try. I walked down the staircase (photo: http://bit.ly/1JvYCho), turned left and made the startling realization that the sushi bar and the tables next to the greenhouse-like window are all this place has to offer (photo: http://bit.ly/1HtEIS5). Am I in the Ginza?

It was a good thing I was there early on a Monday evening since I was their first solo customer. Even though they told me to sit anywhere, I sat at the end of the sushi bar assuming this place would fill up quickly. It did, and I was fairly well scrunched into my little space. Sleeping tube redux. The menu is full of sushi and sashimi treats though not quite as fanciful as Takara Sushi nearby. For a breather, I started with the no-risk $3.50 Edamame (photo: http://bit.ly/1Nupyg0). Pretty standard. I moved on to the $6.95 Kamikaze Roll, which turned out to be five pieces of yellowtail, avocado and scallion rolled in rice sprinkled with tobiko. On the same plate was a couple of Chutoro (Yellowtail Belly) Nigiri which were blessedly unaccessorized for maximum flavor (photo: http://bit.ly/1GYaapU).

For my entree, I ordered the $8.95 Baked Mussels, a quartet prepared almost like Oysters Rockefeller with the mussels mixed with crab meat, tobiko, panko crumbs and their own mayo sauce (photo: http://bit.ly/1HwlRrh). Even though it was fairly filling, they were just a bit too fussy for my taste. I probably should have gone for more rolls. Two young sushi makers were keeping busy in front of me, while one waitress handled the whole room. By the time I finished, I have to admit Sushi Time was a pretty adequate spot for a sushi fix in teh Castro, even if it does pale in comparison to the likes of Ino Sushi in Japantown or Akiko's on Bush in the FiDi. Unless you really, really want to eat in a sleeping tube. I don't think they let you sleep there though.

FOOD - 3 stars...sushi is pretty good, not outstanding and those baked mussels taste like they belong in another generation
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...sleeping tube
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...nice at first but increasingly elusive as it got crowded
TOTAL - 3 stars...tiny greenhouse of a sushi spot in the Castro provides a satisfactory sushi fix
author: Ed U.

description:
What happened to this place?!  This used to be an inexpensive and solid sushi place in Castro.  But I could not help feeling disappointed in my recent visit.

Sushi rolls were not holding together as well as they should and crumbled when I picked them up with my chopsticks.  Rolls were also not cut evenly -- resulting in different thickness among rolls.  Then I noticed that sushi rice tasted different from it used to be.  Did they replace sushi chefs, or something?  

We also had to wait for a quite while for my husband's order of vegetarian rolls.  The servers were very nice and offered us a complementary green tea ice cream.  The problem was that even their ice cream did not taste well.  It lacked any flavor.  Bummer!
author: Ryoko M.

description:
Tiny establishment tucked deep inside a subterranean arcade linking Market and 16th Streets. It's a very intimate and tightly packed place, with maybe a half a dozen seats at the bar, and probably just as many tables for two inside. If you're looking for a quiet, private venue for a date, this might not be the best choice. And although the offerings are relatively inexpensive for a sushi joint, the portions are quite small, and unremarkably average in terms of taste.

Decent enough if you want to stay within the neighborhood, but keep in mind there are better experiences if you have the time and patience to venture further.
author: Vincent L.

description:
I would say this place has the BEST sushi in SF + prices are relatively cheap for the AMAZING quality of fish! Such a random find and literally a hole in the wall... Space is very limited. Don't come here with more than 2-3 people because you might wait for a looooong time. 

I loved their sashimi six (2 pieces of tuna, yellowtail, and salmon) and unagi nigiri (eel). I've never liked yellowtail, but I can't stop ordering it when I'm here. The fish just melts right in your mouth. I have impulsive moments throughout the week to come here and order 5 plates of sashimi haha. 

I'm normally a roll kind of person, but theirs wasn't to my liking. Hello Kitty and Barbie doll were just ok even though ratings on Yelp were good. Not a fan of mango and lemon with my sushi rolls. There wasn't any sauce on top of the rolls so it tasted a bit unbalanced with just the tart and sour toppings of mango and lemon.
author: Christine C.

description:
Below average sushi rolls.

If you're going in for happy hour, make sure the bill is correct.

Best to spend your hard-earned money elsewhere that serves better quality food.
author: Inigo M.

description:
The salmon sushi!!!  It melts in your mouth. 

We ordered two sashimi plates and the salmon was our favorite. Everything else was delicious but the salmon was particularly mouthwatering good!!!!

I ordered kama, which is the neck of a yellow tail. While it looked a bit dry, one of my friends at the table and I totally devoured it.  Like animals. 

I'm a total rice fanatic and think they could do better in this arena.  They should use Kokuho Rose rice. 

The ambience is super sweet.  The place is tucked away from the main street and not that big. It's like we were taken back to a small Japanese restaurant in Japan.  We all enjoyed the food and had fun.
author: AnneMarie W.

description: Great sushi, coZy space, good price. It's in a weird anachronistic arcade mall thing that reminds me of my childhood. What's not to like??
author: Jake I.

description:
When I pulled up to park in a parking miracle moment in front of 2275 Market St., I realized Sushi Time was a joint I had been to many years ago. Since the mini-mall spans Market and 16th, a walk through revealed that the end section of 16th St. has been renamed to José Sarria Court. Kinda sounds like a saint, and I now guess that for some that might be true. When a familiar street name changes, and you don't notice for a decade, it is a mini revelation of the passing of time. 

The subterranean feel to this joint is like a sushi survival cave in the apocalyptic end of days. Combined the sushi bar and tables have maybe 20 seats, its an "elbow to elbow",  an up close and personal" dining experience. A urban/big city small joint experience, with varied life experiences of other diners being revealed in conversation that is far to close to ignore. 

Had the baked mussels appetizer which were good but not what I expected. In half mussel shell, the meat was a mixture of chopped mussel & fake crab. It was tasty. 

My honey was impressed when his bento arrived and the waiter removed the lid to reveal the 3 compartments.  The accompanying small salad & miso soup were pretty standard renditions. The "bento" Included a spicy tuna roll, sashimi and rice, it was ok. I had the sashimi dinner, the cuts of albacore, maguro and tai perched on top of a bed of shredded daikon & carrots in a rather unceremonious arrangement. It was ok. 

Service was attentive, sincere, and maybe enthusiastic with a level of polish that befits this type of joint. It was ok.
author: Matsuo U.

description:
Came here twice and both time the sushi were solid - I only nigiri as this is normally served in Japan. The place is small so try to come here early or late. Given there are only 5-6 tables and a sushi bar, I saw three chefs and three servers, so I'm impressed.   On the downside, they don't have much exotics or special imported fishes as you may find at other highly rated sushi bars.  

But compare to other "4" stars rated sushi joints, I'm glad I found this hidden gem. (It's a bit hard to find this restaurant as it's hidden behind another store)
author: Tom V.

description: Great spot for authentic sushi. Fish was fresh, rolls were good. Everything I tried was fantastic and their prices are extremely reasonable. This place is lovely.
author: Skye R.

description: This place and Eiji are my two favorite sushi restaurants in the hood. Their baked mussels are to die more, probably my favorite dish there. The sashimi and sushi are super fresh. If you want an authentic no fuss Japanese experience, check this place out. Keep in mind the venue is small so I don't recommend going with a large party.
author: Alex C.

description: Value seems good, the sushi is a little bit rougher cut. I've tasted only few sushi better than in this place and all at way higher price levels.
author: Colby G.

description: Eh... sushi wasn't remarkable. I had Crunchy shrimp and spicy tuna. We also had nigiri's and they didn't put wasabi between the rice and fish as it should be done traditionally. Keep in mind rolls are only 4 pieces each. Definitely not the best place to have sushi in the city. Customer service is poor.
author: Dopi A.

description: Staff were friendly and you can ask the sushi chef for recommendations. The sushi itself was not the best, but decent.
author: Louise K.

description: Cozy, reasonably priced and tasty. Exciting little place in a fun location. Best unagi I have ever had! Pretty real.
author: Ezra C.

description: Love this place for sushi. It is a very small hole in the wall spot but the sushi is great! We love it some much we often get it take out as well. The service is very prompt and the prices are reasonable for the great quality you get. It's the place I send all my out of town friends.
author: Maggie L.

description:
We ordered their salmon nigiri and three different rolls.
The sushi wasnt fresh, rolls tasted bland.
Even the sushi they sell at a local supermarket would taste better than this.
Also, service was slow as well- we had to ask the waiter to come to our table everytime.
Dont recommend at all.
author: John K.

description:
Adorable little place. I had a drink and appetizers here with my girlfriend the other night. We loved the ambience and the cheap (although limited) happy hour menu. The sushi was delicious and service was warm and homey.

I definitely recommend coming here although outside of happy hour it is definitely up there in cost.
author: Adrienne R.

description:
One of the best kept sushi secrets that's literally hidden underground in the Castro. 

The restaurant is tiny but cozy, hole-in-the-wall-esque and absolutely adorable! The service is extremely friendly and the price point is so reasonable for such yummy sushi. The husband and I usually order a bottle of the unfiltered sake special (which is only $10 for an entire bottle that we can split among two folks) and do a more bottomless approach with our sushi... basically, we order almost everything on the menu! 

We're so obsessed with their sashimi selection of salmon, red tuna and yellowtail, as well as the two chef's special nigiris, fatty tuna and spanish mackerel. In terms of the more fusion rolls, we love the Barbie Roll (crab, avocado and fresh salmon) and the Speed Racer Roll (tuna, mango and tobiko). Lastly, the tamago and uni nigiri are such classics and must-orders. 

For 2 people with an insanely gluttonous appetite and a bottle of sake to share, the bill usually comes out to less than $100. 

As much as I'd love to keep Sushi Time a secret, I must do the business some justice and provide the accolade that it truly deserves. 

Happy Eating, Yelpers!
author: Priya S.

description: This is a really great sushi place in Sf although it does take a while to find it! It's fun, colorful, and the staff are just as cool. I have yet to try out all of their sushi but my favorite so far is their GI Joe roll.
author: Geraldine G.

description:
I was excited to try a new sushi place... until I lost my appetite from the smell of being underground in the Castro District. Why did they build the restaurant here? I'm not sure. Maybe the rent was lower, which I could totally see why. The restaurant is super cramped, but the staff is nice. Kinda slow but whatever.

My friend and I started with the green salad, which was okay. The dressing was good. We ordered an assortment of nigiri and I thought the fish was decently fresh (yay) but the rice was mushy. The Barbie Roll (recommend by Yelpers) was also disappointing. There was no real flavor. Anyways, I had a good time only because I was with good company, and we ordered a giant thing of sake. I think I'm just really annoyed by the smell of the outside (especially when you have to wait to be seated) and how claustrophobic the restaurant feels. Not a fun ambiance. Horrible for a date but good for desperate sushi cravings.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
It's like eating sushi in a tiny Photo Booth. Small. Confined. Space.

Crowded. Claustrophobic. Must get air.

Okay, enough with the joking, but really this place is small.

How is the sushi? Small as well.

Is it spectacular? No. 

Is it worth the 1/2 wait? Gosh no.

It's just okay sushi served in a small confined space that mimics the crowded cramped restaurants of Japan.
author: Jack R.

description:
Sushi Time to get over there (this one is far too close to a real word to classify as a pun).

I call this place "Sushi Time Underground" and truly only just now discovered that this is, frankly, a lie.

That being said, the name made me feel like I was at a secret sushi rave. 

While it's not actually a rave, it is kind of underground and it's real small which literally means you're in Japan. Small = Japan. Everyone knows this. Small also means you feel really cool when you have a seat and other people have to wait.

The sushi is good sushi. It's not too expensive sushi, I think? Sushi is one where you really draw a fine line between quality and price. I usually err on the side of price but I am not often most. 

I recommend whatever you like eating at sushi places and, as always, order a large beer to drink out of a chilled glass. So Japanese.
author: Maya L.

description:
this place was pretty good! i was pleasantly surprised because it was 1) in the basement of a shopping center on market and 2) smelled INCREDIBLY FISHY. haha. gf and i sat down at the bar and immediately started with sapporo. the natural choice. we got 2 kinds of nigiri from the special menu - good but forgettable. we also got the crunch roll and the 10 piece sashimi to start.  the sashimi was super good! nice cuts of fish and tasted good.

2nd round was uni, eel, tamago, and the GI joe roll.  the uni was super creamy and nomsies, eel was as expected - yum, but the tamago was so cold! im not sure what i was expecting - the flavor was good, but the ice cold egg with cold rice was not stellar.

dinner for 2 - $52 each. NOT BAD AT ALL!
author: Christina L.

description:
A small but cozy sushi restaurant that serves wonderful sashimi and sake! It was warm (which was a great break from the brisk winds of September) and the service was wonderful! For a such a small restaurant, they have a lot of servers! I think it's great though, they are able to have customers come in and out. Fast customer turnover! A great place for a quick lunch/dinner. Probably not the best place for a meal where you want to sit and talk for a while. I suspected that they wanted us to leave right after we ate, but we were just wanting to sit, relax, and finish our sake. 

The salmon is very fresh. I had the salmon bowl, my friend had the assorted sashimi bowl, and my other friend got the bento box (which included: Eel, spicy tuna roll, salad, and 3 slices of abalone). She wanted the Clam Miso Soup to be switched out with the normal Miso Soup that it came with, and it was a simple switch of $6. It was definitely worth it. The Bento Box had a great assortment. 

The sake that my friend and I ordered was very clean and smooth. 

Highly recommend this place for sashimi lovers! Will be coming back here!
author: Leta K.

description: SHHHHH SUSHI TIME!  It's my go to Sushi spot in the city and it NEVER disappoints.  Be sure to get there early if you want Toro because it sells out quickly.  Some of the best cuts of fish on a consistent basis that I have found.
author: Jack R.

description: This is one my favorite sushis place in SF. Their food is really good, and it is actually super affordable. On top of that, it looks truly authentic, and it is a little hidden. The fish is fresh and the service is nice as well. Definitely a place to try in SF if you like sushis!
author: Sara-Fleur S.

description:
My friend and I tried this place off a recommendation, and it was one of the best I've ever had! Definitely make sure to go during their happy hour: weekdays 5-6pm. $5 sushi rolls, $2 edamame, $1 tea. We feasted like queens for less than $20 a person!

The entrance to the restaurant is great and so AUTHENTIC San Francisco, not the new SF that yuppies know it as. You have to search for it as it's in a strip-mall-type building and downstairs with a glowing neon "sushi" sign with an arrow pointing straight to the door. When you walk in you're welcomed to this teeny-tiny hole in the wall the size of a semi-truck trailer, decorated really beautifully and simple. It's intimate, fun, and a nice change of scenery from the new, clean-cut San Francisco that I'm not used to yet.

And the food is incredible. They have an abundance of tea, sushi, sashimi, nigiri, and maki choices, and I don't think you can make a bad choice. My friend had the Saba Nigiri and she said it was very fresh.

The wait staff is efficient and simple, no extravagance necessary when all you need is a good sushi fix. I would definitely recommend this to anyone as one of the top places to go in the city!
author: Jacqui A.

description: What a find!  This feels like one of those literally hidden gems -- it's tiny and feels like you are eating in a greenhouse.  I've lived in this neighborhood forever and overlooked this place.  Food was absolutely fresh and delicious.  Check out their tea menu too!
author: M M.

description:
Happy hour from 5-6pm is the best!! The sushi literally melts in your mouth. Try the sashimi 5 for $9. The large hot sake is also $5. The make rolls are huge! We expected little ones. The philly rolls were delicious! For the spicy tuna, note they do not have spicy mayo sauce and pretty much only use sriracha. 

I think we got like 10 carafes of sake. We got soooo drunk.

They did however, push us to leave around 7-7:30 which was understandable, but at the same time not the best practice. We weren't going to leave without finishing all of our sake!
author: Jeanne C.

description:
I'd come back multiple times a week to eat all their delicious sushi.

I don't think you'll find a fancy, chef's omakase on the menu with fish imported from Tsukiji, but that doesn't bother me because it's good quality and affordable sushi. During happy hour, rolls are $5. I was expecting a small portion, but they were huge! Tasted fresh, too. I ordered the Alaska roll w/salmon and avocado that melts in your mouth. All the rolls look pretty good so I can't wait to come back and try more. 15 of their 18 rolls are all less than $7 and makes my wallet and tummy happy!!

Also, super convenient to get to since it's super close to Castro St MUNI. Lots of street parking nearby too.

Beware, the inside is tiny so if that's not your thing, I'd go elsewhere. You can hear every conversation going on in the restaurant so that's kind of interesting. Still, service is fairly fast and I think they do take out!
author: Veronica T.

description: Easy quality sushi. Strictly sushi here. Great to sit at the bar. Price is fantastic for sf. Menus is big but similarities within rolls. They are cool with making substitutions. Seaweed salad always. The ginger salad is good but not the usual orange ginger dressing
author: Liz J.

description:
I miss sushi restaurants like this, great quality fish at affordable prices. This small, tucked away restaurant reminds me of a small sushi restaurant you can expect to find in Japan, or in a corner in NYC.

Fresh fish for the nigiri and large maki rolls that aren't drizzled in ponzu sauce like Korean sushi restaurants. The fish was served at the right temperature, the sushi rice was made well, you can't really ask for more especially at their low price point.

Also had a the chance to eat Hamachi toro nigiri as their special, and that was really tasty and had a melt in your mouth texture to it similar to fatty tuna/toro belly.

Service was good, happy hour is only in effect for the first hour the restaurant is open.
author: Steven C.

description: Been to at least 3 sushi places in Castro. I think this is my favorite so far in terms of freshness and authenticity. The menu is limited but good. It's somewhat a hole in the wall but definitely adds to the character. It may be hard to find at first originally as it is downstairs in the back. I'll be back.
author: Hoosie U.

description:
Great small space. Great sushi selection. Actually have multiple types of tea you can order. Sushi is very fresh. 
A little expensive but worth it. Minus no fresh wasabi.
author: Devlin D.

description:
It could very well be in a subway station in Osaka ( that IS a compliment)
The nice perfume of rice can be felt already from outside. 
Very good quality of fish. Affordable prices.
author: Bruno S.

description:
Quoted: What time is it? It's Sushi time!
If yer lookin' for fancy shmancy ultra deluxo this ain't it.
But it's a super cool place to grab some basic stuff.
Can't beat the subterranean ambiance.
author: Anthony A.

description:
My, my, this place is small and almost not noticeable.

Tucked in a corner of the basement of a courtyard...I only happened to walk by when I picked up food from Dinosaur next door.

The fish is fresh, the cut is pretty decent, and the waiters are courteous and friendly. I think as a sit-down place, it can be a bit dingy. Not to mention the out-side bathroom. The decoration is also more on the eclectic side, but certainly fun.

The prices are good considering the quality of the fish and the portion (at least for SF standards), so four whole stars.
author: Joe G.

description: The fish is always fresh and the rolls are made without too much rice. Perfection in a small, intimate setting - just like Tokyo!  Masa has done a wonderful job with Sushi Time.
author: Scott L.

description:
Sushi time was my first meal in San Francisco...and I wished I had ate somewhere else. Don't get me wrong, this sushi isn't TERRIBLE, I just expected better. I've just had better sushi at home, and thought perhaps I would run into some better sushi by the bay. 

Barbie Roll: Probably the better rolls of the three I tried. The lemon slice was a pleasant surprise, but sometimes could be too sour. 
Big roll (eel, shrimp, egg, spinach & gourd): Oh goodness, what is this? It is not sushi, it tastes like rice & egg in a ball. It was just too much in one roll. 
Hello Kitty Roll: ehh, nothing memorable

Overall, the rolls were okay, nothing special. It just wasn't memorable for me.
author: Annie N.

description:
About once a year, Yelp leads me wrong. I go to a highly-ranked place and am NOT impressed, or I go to a place that I enjoyed and later see that it has a terrible ranking.

So my friend and I chose this place because it was four-stars and because, walking past the little basement-style hole-in-the-wall, I had the impression that it would be more authentic (it is) and less expensive (it's not) than other Castro options. Also, I just wanted to see what was the best of the best in my 'hood before I chose to whom I would be loyal for the duration of my residence here.

I don't think this place is the one.

I knew it was small, but I didn't realize it was THIS small. "Narrow as a boxcar", said Ligaya T. in a review from five-years-ago, and that pretty much sums it up. I ride Caltrain to work and this place is definitely a fourth of the size of one of the train cabins I spend 45 minutes in every day, twice. It's TINY.

As a 6'6 dude, I can say, the seating is too small. It's like squeezing into the backseat of a Mini Cooper. I get it, there's very limited square footage... but that means that I'm not really comfortable, ever. Also, seated next to us was an annoying gay hipster and his LA gal-pal, each of whom must've been suffering from hearing loss from the other's lack of indoor voices. I'm pretty sure I could hear them debating the merits of Silverlake versus Los Feliz from the street out front, had I left... which I almost did. Except they were sitting two feet away and I couldn't hear a word my dining companion said because of it.

Bottom line: On an empty night, I think I'd like it. But every table was full, and I felt like I was in a middle seat on a Southwest flight. Too cramped, too loud, too little personal space. The food was tasty if not amazing, but it was a bit pricier than even the upscale places in the neighborhood, and the portions were small-ish.

It's rare that my rating differs so much from the 'mean' score on a Yelp review, but in this case, it's a two-star place for me. I left annoyed and tempted to pop into Barracuda on my way home for one more roll...
author: Sean B.

description:
I ordered Barbie roll. The size of the sushi is just right, one bite each sushi. The salmon is so juicy and flavorful. They add a small slice of orange on top of each sushi which creates a wonderful balance with the fat of the salmon.
I adore the ambiance. It's so authentic and makes me feel I am back to Kyoto. It's such a cozy place perfect for dinner
author: Amy H.

description: Still love this place. Servers are very nice. I dropped my chopsticks like 3x and they were there immediately with new ones. Can be a little cramped at peak hours. Sushi served was kind of warm this time but still tasty
author: Xue H.

description: Been going here for ten years and hands down the best sushi spot in the city. Impeccable service and it's unreal how fresh their product is (+ reasonably priced). Cannot rave about this place more and have legitimate dreams about their toro + barbie roll
author: Gabriele L.

description: Oh Sushi Time how I love thee, let me tell you all about this place. It's out of the way, tiny, and cute. The food is delish!
author: Mar G.

description:
I've been to sushi time since they opened (long time ago!) . I love this little hidden spot in Castro area. The restaurant reminds me of an underground izakaya style by looking at the Interior decorations from Japan. Eye catching and really cute. 

My favorite plates are tuna avo tar tar, baked mussels and hamachi kama. I always order same plates and they never let me down:) 

Everybody is super nice. I love this place and I want to go back there tomorrow!!
author: Erena S.

description:
I liked that this was a tiny, tiny place hidden in some sort of fitness mall. 

The sushi is cheap for the quality, but my friend's unagi bowl was surprisingly overpriced for the amount of food it turned out to be by comparison ($18).

I recommend the Shrimp Tempura Roll.
author: An Y.

description:
Absolute favorite sushi joint in the city! Literally a hole in the wall.  Intimate, fun, unpretentious.  Excellent sushi, well priced, authentic.  I've been coming to this place for years and it has never disappointed.  Barbie roll is my fave.  Love the fresh lemon on top of the salmon.  

Never wrote a review because I didn't want this place to get too crowded or sceney.  But I am ready to share it now. :)
author: Mel D.

description:
My go to sushi spot, the atmosphere, staff and amazing fish quality keeps me
Coming back! Started coming here when I lived next door and even though I moved across town I keep coming back, this might be my favorite dinner spot in SF!! My only reservation is that they aren't open on Sunday!Great happy hour as well! 5-6 M-S
author: Natalie O.

description: Cute, snug little sushi place. We only had to wait about 10 minutes for a spot at the bar.  I wouldn't recommend going with a large group during prime times and it is a small place.  Sushi was fresh and came out really fast.  Perfect for a date night!
author: Nicole M.

description:
I'm not sure how this place is 4 stars. One star for the food and giving them their second star for good service. I was underwhelmed and disappointed. Maybe the mistake was starting off with the happy hour menu which was pricey for the lack of quality fish. The sashimi we ordered was bland. The rolls were decent but I prefer sushi over rolls. The Hamachi kama was boiled.. Gross.. Definitely will not be coming back

Another tip... Avoid the bathrooms.. They will ruin your appetite
author: Christine H.

description:
Honestly I think we can call this one of the best sushi places in San Francisco!
I got the eel GI Joe roll and the Barbie roll, they were both amazing and I can't wait to try more of their delicious rolls!
author: Sev G.

description:
10/5... can I give that score?  If I could I would.

Sushi Time is the best slightly hidden secret in the city.

As far as inexpensive sushi that is of wonderful quality; Sushi Time never disappoints. 

Bento Box is perfect if you're hungry.  Sushi Combo A (B if you're more hungry) is served up with perfect Sashimi and the best Spicy Tuna roll one can find.  

The miso soup served without a spoon is nice and hot with perfect flavor and not overly salty.

The ginger salad with seasame seeds and a tangy peanut / ginger vinegarette is just perfect.  

This is by far my favorite place to start my Saturday night. 

Fair warning the restaurant is the size of a shoe box, so it is not good for groups even in excess of 4.
author: Andrew T.

description:
I've passed by this little hub of a sushi place many times without much thought but my boyfriend was curious to try it. 

Small but adorable! Definitely an intimate environment not a hangout spot. 

They offer a variety of teas. I got peach oolong and my boyfriend got chamomile. Mine was the best. Light and fruity!

We only ordered one roll so we can go out to try other places to eat too...yeah. Anyway, it was the Teddy Bear roll with bbq eel, cream cheese, and cucumber. It was pretty good!

I'm interested to try their other specialty rolls so I'm gonna be going back.
author: Sofia R.

description:
Sushi Time is a hidden sushi place http://media2.ct.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/jF-V2aOJBgI7X_Gwyo2ZZw/l located next to Dinosaurs (the only banh mi shop in that side of Market street). Eiji and ST are the most popular Japanese restaurants in this area. Far more popular than the always empty Daimaru Sushi, around the corner.

At first glance menu prices seem cheaper, but the rolls are a bit smaller than other places, so basically u get the same value as any other place. The food is just 3 stars compared to the best in SF, but around this area it's probably your best choice. I give them another star because service is excellent, friendly and very helpful. Decent place for takeout orders too. http://media4.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/G6X3c5JIs_M7k3mjPMUOjg/l
author: Luis C.

description: Love love love this cute underground sushi bar. Warm hospitality, cozy ambience, authentic sushi, high quality, super fresh and ultra tasty food. My new SF go to... and it's affordable! The fatty toro / tuna is to die for!
author: Sarah H.

description:
I enjoy coming here, it is a nice intimate spot.  
I give it three stars because i sometimes love the sushi, and sometimes it has too much cream cheese and throws my taste buds off.
However, the ambiance is great and so are the staff.
author: Carolina R.

description: I had the bento box. Really pricy (19 dollars) for the portion, but it tasted amazing. Wish I got more bang for my buck tho. The sashimi was fresh and tasty, so we're the sushi and bbq eel.
author: Dennis T.

description:
I visited sushi time for dinner. Ordered the g.i.joe roll and chirashi don. None of he dishes impressed me in taste.  I liked the unagi in the g.i. Joe roll, but other than that, it was...eh.  The chirashi was the standard fish you'd fine in a sushi bar. O.k. But not overwhelming. Service was slow since it was packed and all the groups seemed to have placed their orders at the same time.
A great place to try, but one I will not return to.
author: Marck N.

description: Really freakin good sushi. Sooo fresh and reasonably priced for sushi compared to other places in the city! Small hole in the wall and only open for a few hours, but it's exclusiveness is what makes this place special. Absolutely love this place!
author: Liz F.

description: Nigiris were outstanding. They just melt in your mouth.. Super fresh! The miso soup was also amazing. Very flavorful. This cozy little sushi place is definitely one of my favorites!!
author: Soundarya C.

description:
Everything about this place was great; from food, to service, to atmosphere.

As per the suggestions on this site, I ordered the Barbie Roll and it was delicious. Probably one of the best sushi rolls I've ever had. The salmon was like butter, and all the ingredients were rich and creamy. I also got the Speed Racer Roll, which was a hit and miss. A few pieces had lots of mango and were great, whereas most of the others had very little and tasted unbalanced. Also got the miso soup, which is especially great on a cold day.

The sushi menu is also great; from Astro Boy, to G.I. Joe, to Teddy Bear, this would definitely be a fun menu to explore!

I've mostly had sushi at buffets before, and the quality of food here was incomparably better. I was also surprised to find that 16pcs were more than enough for me to leave the restaurant feeling pleasantly full.

The service was attentive and friendly.

The atmosphere was terrific. The place is tiny and covered with Japanese styled wallpaper and knickknacks. Really felt like a hidden gem; the name "Underground Sushi Time" is absolutely perfect.
author: Drini C.

description: A-OK. Rolls are on the smaller side, but flavors are pretty good. I liked the one with mango in it a lot. Place is a little small, so I imagine there can be a wait, though there was none when I went last time for dinner (can't remember what day it was though). Prices are average.
author: Kathy L.

description: Absolute must try! Our FAVORITE sushi place by far! You may miss this little place if you aren't careful, it's a bit hidden. We went for their happy hour (5-6 everyday) and had 5 rolls, edamame, tea and mochi for about $40! The sushi is delicious, we loved the California roll made with REAL crab. Another favorite of ours is the Alaskan (salmon) and the Sashimi plate. They also have some cool specialty rolls. Service is good too.
author: Brigette A.

description: Happy that I made it to the happy hour. Not happy with the food. I ordered off of the happy hour so that my wallet would be okay but the quality of the fish and the taste was nowhere near what I had expected. The space did look very authentically Japanese, although I've never been to Japan before but the chefs behind the bar were Chinese. TL;DR: I've had better in LA.
author: Laura Y.

description:
It's absolutely criminal that I haven't written a review for this place yet. I come here all the time.

This is extremely cheap (compared to SF prices; probably $6-11/roll), extremely good sushi. Way better than Baracada sushi (down the street), which oversauces their rolls. The place is intimate (get ready to be close your neighbor) but surprisingly romantic and relaxed.

Get the sea urchin - it's creamy and cold; and the Barbie Roll - which is I believe California roll wrapped in salmon and thin lemon slices on top for a nice zing. If it's too sour, drizzling some soy sauce over it mellows the taste a bit and makes it even tastier.
author: Sylvia L.

description:
I first went to sushi time when I first moved to the bay area, about 10 years ago. This is the first time I've been back since that time. Sushi here is good, just the normal sushi that you find throughout the bay area. Their selection of rolls is not that extensive, but its sufficient.  I ordered the chirashi don. They were generous with the fish portions so no complaints there.

The place is very cozy so be prepared to nuzzle up to your neighbors. The only thing that surprised me is that you have to pay for tea. $1.50 per pot? That was a bit off putting seeing that you get it for free at most other sushi places.
author: Kenson K.

description: Sushi Time is a great find. I wouldn't have known about it without a local taking me there (it is off the street and not easily spottable). The sushi was excellent and well priced; several rolls, sake, miso, and salad for under $45.
author: Joshua B.

description: I saw many good reviews about this place so I gave it a try with my bf on a late Friday night. I gave 2 stars because their service wasn't that bad and the decor was pretty cute. We went there around 9:30pm and there were only a few customers in the restaurants. At first, I thought the place looked pretty decent and authentic but then when I stepped in, I could hear the chefs were from China and they spoke very loud in Mandarin and Cantonese then I immediately knew that this restaurant is not authentic at all and probably not that delicious also. My bf ordered Chirashi Don and he said it was the worst he have ever had, by visual appearance, those sashimi were not fresh at all and they only gave a little but with so much rich on the bottom. The portion was just weird. Whenever, I go to a Japanese restaurant, I will always order natto roll if they have it, and so this restaurant actually got natto roll! Unfortunately, the natto roll was so bad that I don't know what to say because natto roll is so easy to make, just put natto with the rice and roll it, like you don't have to cook it or whatsoever. The natto was very warm and a little like 2 - 3 only in one roll, ARE YOU SERIOUS?! I can go to 99 ranch and buy 3 packs of natto and only cost me 10 bucks. I was so disappointed with that and the maki rolls was terrible x2. The rolls were so blend and not even FRESH at all! I honestly don't know why there were so many good reviews, I hope it was just only a bad day for me but I will definitely won't recommand anyone to go to this place for AUTHENTIC Japanese food.
author: Tina W.

description:
Great spot for sushi! Price versus quality, you get a good amount and it tastes great. We ordered about 5 rolls and they were all good but I think I can pass on the GI Joe roll next time. Was a little underwhelming. 

The place is a small hole in the wall and it gets cramped so I don't recommend big parties trying to squeeze in without making a reservation. 

I would definitely go back though and for those expecting excellent quality, it's not that kind of place. You can go blow your money elsewhere if you want top tier sushi (Maruya, Akiko's, etc) but overall this is spot is great if your expectations are in check with what it is.
author: Hiroki M.

description:
Hubs and I ate here for dinner last weekend because we were craving sushi and it was close by with good reviews.  We liked it so much, we came back for dinner a few days later!  It's a tiny restaurant, to be sure, but it is simply charming, full of colorful Japanese items and art.  The service has been friendly and fast.

I personally loved the Barbie roll, and the spicy scallop.  The happy hour sashimi special is delicious and generous.

Anyway, I love this place!  So cute and the food is delicious.

In fact, I spied a woodblock print on the wall that I'm seriously considering asking if I can buy... Not many sushi restaurants are as charmingly decorated.  Also, sidenote, the last time we were there, it seemed as if they'd gotten their hands on an album of instrumental Disney theme songs, performed in unusual instruments, such as "part of your world" in Parisian style accordion.  Adorable!
author: Rachel S.

description:
Sashimi Ten (it's a starter, no rice but on a very lovely and delicious bed of daikon with a leaf of shiso, 6 different types of fish) $15.95 

Spicy scallop hand roll, $5.95, which is my personal favorite of all time, and always a test...of if I will be returning, and I will.  It was very good scallop, with the perfect blend of spiciness, rice, microgreens and a crisp sheet of seaweed.  (trust me a soggy hand roll is pretty nasty to try to eat)

GI Joe roll for $8.00 (unagi and cucumber inside with avocado outside and drizzled with some unagi sauce), nice portion, delicious, and worth savoring. 

Seating = small, cozy, and definitely a hideaway from the hustle-and-bustle of the upstairs.  (Limited seating, so you better plan ahead if you're coming in a large group!)

Service = friendly.

Prices = reasonable to cheap.  

Parking = I have no idea, as I came here by MUNI and like everything else in this area, I'm guessing public transit is a great idea, or learn to parallel park well.  

I'll be back for Happy Hour, some day...5-6pm!    Maybe I'll try one of their special rolls...like the ones with mango in 'em...MAYBE.
author: Fannie S.

description:
Small underground hole in the wall semi secret Harry Potter-esque joint. Ok I'm exaggerating with the Harry Potter but it's so tucked away I've never noticed it!! 

Sushi Time is a tiny intimate spot. It's a kitschy place decorated with origami and what I would call "leftover Japanese Christmas wrapping paper." There's really only the sushi bar and maybe 4 small tables. It CAN get busy here. I dropped in on a weeknight at 6pm and there was only one couple at the bar. Another time I was at Dinosaurs and peeked over to see that they were at max capacity with a wait list so I stuck with my plans of banh mi at Dinosaurs. 
I wouldn't necessarily make it a destination spot. If you're in the area and it happens to not be so busy, sure you can give it a try. 

They have a happy hour from 5-6pm. I can't recall the entire menu but I did a quick scan and saw some basic appetizers and basic maki on there. We got with 5 piece sashimi off the happy hour menu. Waitress was kind enough to offer it to us even though it was 6:02pm. 

In total we ordered: 

Sushi 5 ( 5 pcs sashimi)  - 3 salmon, 2 albacore.  Decent quality no complaints here. 
Baked mussels -  chopped green mussels with crab, tobiko and mayo. too dry. Needs more sauce and a little lacking in flavor. Maybe another ingredient. Cheese? 
Spicy walu roll - walu, avocado, spicy mayo.  The rich butteriness of the walu is lost in the mayo and avocado. Maybe not again next time. 
Astro boy roll - spicy scallop, mango, cucumber ,  & tobiko. YUMMMMM get this!!! Naturally sweet scallop with spicy sauce and mango is such an amazing combo. Then you get the cool crunch of cucumber and the pop of tobiko. Great flavors and texture, my favorite of the night. 
Hello kitty roll - mango, cucumber, tobiko, & albacore. It comes with a side of ponzu sauce for dipping, but it didn't compliment the roll at all. I just used a teeny bit of soy sauce instead. Although it sounded tasty to me, this roll was just mehhh ok. 

Spent close to $50 and I would have to say... I wasn't overly stuffed and as a matter of fact we went to Taco Bell after. Great for casual sushi, not the place for super high end sushi purist stuff.
author: Susy C.

description: I haven't had sushi this authentic since I was in Japan! The rolls weren't the California style, with jalapeños or all that sauce. It fish was soft, fresh, and phenomenal!!! The unlit street looks a little seedy, but I'm SO glad I listened to the other Yelp reviews and not my gut... my gut said DON'T EAT THERE.. but my gut was wrong...
author: Andrea F.

description: 4th time eating here. Love the freshness and quality of the fish especially for the price. Large rolls. Get there early if you want any Hamachi Toro. This is my go to place for sure.
author: T M.

description: Was just OK for me. Sashimi was warm and didn't appear (or taste) like high quality fish. Sushi chefs crank out the rolls, but need a little work when it comes to sashimi.
author: Justin R.

description: A great sushi spot for all you can eat. The service is great. The sushi is fresh and tasty. I am never disappointed. The specials are awesome. The bar is full and has plenty of sake for your choosing. I have been going here since it was barracuda sushi. It is a great spot to scratch that sushi itch. Always leave full and not broke. Rarity, I know.
author: Teo A.

description: Awesome hole-in-the-wall sushi spot on Market Street. I had a flashback to NY when entering the restaurant. Be there first otherwise I'm sure you're going to have to wait a while.
author: Shannon R.

description:
teen tiny under the ground, behind a glass door the entrance is found.

GPS can't help you, but I bet someone who wrote a review would gladly be your guide. Go with one friend, order tea, share rolls and bask in their awesome splendor. 

Don't go in a big group. Don't be those people. Read the poem i wrote above, k?

They take cards, they take cash, they're awesome about both. 

Rolls I ordered: Rainbow, Spicy Walu and Crunchy.

Rainbow was my favorite because i like variety, but the Spicy Walu was amazing and something I'd never seen in the Sushi spots of Illinois (yes i said sushi and the land locked state that is Illinois in the same sentence. dont' judge)

Would I go back? Absofreakinlutely. Amazing sushi at prices that don't freak out my boss when i turn in that travel expense report. 

PSA: And because this place is teeny tiny DON'T YOU DARE bring your kids in here unless they are the quietest-kindest-keep-to-themselves-so-freakin-well-behaved-you'd-think-they-weren't-even-there kinds of kids.
author: Jessica S.

description: Really awesome hole in the wall restaurant.  It's a bit tough to find at first since its off to the side of Market Street.  It really has an authentic Japanese vibe like the kind of sushi bars you'd find in Japan!  The sushi is also great since its more traditional rather than all the sauces and oversized makis that most restaurants typically have.  The fish quality is great, I had some really awesome saba nigiri here as well as toro.  If you really appreciate the taste of fish rather than dousing it in sauce, then give this place a try!
author: Bryson L.

description: Fresh and perfectly prepared nigiri. They even  took care of  small requests for my non-raw loving companion. 2nd time here and I look forward to it. The place is tiny. But that just adds to the attraction in my book. Place is hard to find. It's located in the small Plaza downstairs. I'll definitely be back, again.
author: Raul M.

description: One of my favorite sushi spots in the neighborhood. It's teeny tiny, with friendly waitstaff and fresh, delicious fish. Everything here is fantastic - the only downside is that because it is so small, it can be cramped and there can be a long wait at times. Otherwise, this is my go-to spot in the area.
author: Amy Y.

description: Loved it!  Large rolls, fresh fish, great happy hour deals!   Don't let the off street location scare you off ... Tiny but mighty!
author: Michelle A.

description: Good quality fish but not exactly a destination restaurant. Had the yellow tail sashimi, yellowtail belly and amberjack nigiri
author: Chinthrilla M.

description:
This is some of the best sushi I've had in San Francisco, and definitely the best for the price. 

The restaurant itself is tiny - just a few tables along the wall, and some seats at the counter. But holy jeebus, the food is incredible. Fresh, flavorful fish and a good selection of traditional nigiri and specialty sushi rolls. My favorite is the barbie roll: the salmon is deliciously buttery, and the little slice of lemon on top adds the perfect amount of acidic tang. 

There can be a wait, especially on weekends, but just pop to one of the neighborhood bars for a drink and you've solved that problem.
author: Laurel K.

description:
3 stars is an average rating for me. In other words my experience here was average in comparison to other places I've been.

Walking in was the interesting part because of the decor. Some of it was pretty random and other of it was authentic Japanese. The place is small and it wouldn't hurt to get some ventilation going.

It's kind of hidden location which made me kind of think that this place was going to be excellent. It wasn't, but I did enjoy my experience. The seaweed salad was good. Basic. 

We ordered three rolls spicy tuna roll, rainbow roll, Philadelphia roll. The spicy tuna roll was nearly not as spicy enough, it really wasn't spicy. they shouldn't be afraid to spice it up a little bit even though people can complain about being too spicy. After all, it is called a spicy tuna roll.
The rainbow roll I did enjoy it was good. It was very good.
The Philadelphia was okay, it was pretty dry for some reason, I feel like it could've been q.

The guy helping us was nice, I like the fact that you can't see the guys preparing the sushi. Great plus.
author: Karina G.

description: Visiting from Baltimore and found this in the Castro neighbohhood through Yelp. A bit tough to find, but it did not dissapoint. Quirky tiny restaurant on a lower level, however worth the effort.  Quick friendly service, and more importantly fish was good quality at a great price. Sashimi was fresh and good size,. The local favorite Barbie Roll was great.
author: Carrie R.

description: Fantastic sushi, very cute place. Love sitting by the bar. :)
author: Athanasios E.

description:
What a perfect little gem. Instead of the usual sencha, they offer a variety of teas. I recommend the momo oolong. Delightful. 

Also worth splurging on is the Dassai 50 sake. Don't shy away because of the licorice undertones. They really are understated and provide a good balance against raw fish of all profiles.

Oh, did I forget? The fish is melt in your mouth fresh. Maguro Toro for the win.
author: Sonya I.

description: Small hidden underground spot. Very fast service. Good prices for happy hour sushi. Nothing crazy here just good ordinary sushi.
author: Zita M.

description: Don't be worried about the basement location - they do serve an amazing sushi - as good as in Japan! Especially hotate!!
author: Andrew S.

description:
So, very nice rolls: speed racer was clever with mango and tuna, while astro boy also satisfied, with spicy scallop. Choice of sake drinking cups from a basket--cute touch. Not the cleanest place I've been but friendly and earnest and affordable. 

Hole in the  wall in basement of a Castro mini mall on Market; kind of a throwback to another, less glitzy era--endearing. A little hideaway; go now before it's 'discovered' and ruined by City poseurs.
author: Dave S.

description:
Fantastic little sushi place!

I needed a place to grab a bite to eat alone before meeting a friend for drinks. It's kind of tucked away but not too hard to find. 

I was seated at the end of the bar. The place is tiny, but super cute and the decorations are quaint. I ordered an Alaskan roll and a tuna roll. It was great sitting at the bar because I could watch them prep my food. I also had a pot of grapefruit green tea.

The food and the tea were all delicious. Not the BEST sushi I've ever had, but delicious nonetheless and the whole bill was no more than $15. I would definitely go back and recommend the place to a friend!
author: Liz C.

description:
The barbie roll was delicious as everyone else has said. This is a nice quaint spot for a date. When I say quaint I mean it is REALLY SMALL and dim. 

The place is quite hard to find since it's in a mall and you have to walk downstairs to find.

The way they deliver your checks is cute since they put it into a little bamboo box, makes it seem like a present yet asking you for money.
author: Dorris W.

description:
I have been haunting this little gem for years and it is always great, fresh, consistent food and great service.  The sushi, rolls, teriyaki, salads (etc) - everything on the menu - is excellent.  The staff are always very friendly and accomodating and make you feel very welcome from the first second you walk in the door. 

It is a tiny place, so don't try to book a birthday dinner party for 25 of your closest friends (or even 6 of your closest friends).  Better yet, save this great place for a romantic dinner for 2 (or maybe 3 - this is San Francisco afterall).  Also, get there early,  as the tables do fill up quickly.
author: Matt S.

description:
The wait was at least an hour long, which was way longer than it was supposed to be. When my friends and I arrived, the host(possibly the owner) told us to write in a name and phone number to call when seating was available. He told us that we should have a table in approximately 20 minutes. I waited outside the shop while my two friends went to repark the car. 

After what semed to be 45 minutes and no phone call, I walked inside to see if we would get a spot soon. The man told me he called me a while ago, which was strange since I didn't have any received or missed calls on my call log. My phone was working just fine, since I took a phone call from a family member ten minutes after reservations were made. Before I could explain this, he interrupted me and said my party would have to wait.  After a few minutes, he waved me in. Seeing that the other two members of the party weren't with me yet, he tried to push me out with his hands. He didn't care that they were two blocks away walking over here(finally parking) What? Seriously? I can understand him not able to seat an incomplete party, but was pushing really necessary? I don't think I did anything to him alarm him either. Wah. Sheesh.

 When my friends arrived, we were seated, had excellent sushi and improved service. I'm rating this place two stars based on my personal experience with their service. If you're interested in this place, try coming when business isn't too busy and make sure your full party is there when its time to sit. Haha.
author: Vaneza A.

description: My friend and I were driving around SF trying to find sushi on a Monday night (many of the restaurants are closed) and stumbled across this gem hidden in a strip mall off Market Street. This place reminds me of a fort -- blanket-like drapes and all. And the sashimi was freaking amazing. One of my new favorite places!
author: Mel G.

description:
My girlfriend and I were on vacation in SF, and decided we wanted to get some sushi. After reading some reviews for various locations, we decided on Sushi Time. We could not have been happier.

She had the Sake Don (salmon and rice) and I had one of the sushi dinners. We added an order of Barbie rolls to it (California rolls wrapped in salmon and topped with a sliver of lemon). The servers were attentive and present, but unobtrusive. I forgot they were there until I needed them--and when I needed them, they were there before I had a chance to look up.

The place only seats about 20, and it got very busy around 7:00. Keep that in mind.
author: Steve C.

description:
Their sushi rolls are deliciously-yummy; however, the place is small and kind of uncomfortable sitting closely with others. Every little conversation, you can actually hear.
We have difficulty finding it at first but found it after 10 minutes. Would be nice if they upgrade their place and moved to a bigger area and not hard to find. Overall, our experienced at Sushi Time was good. I'd give their food 4 out of 5 stars. Service was okay, I'd give it 3 out of 5 stars. Their staff was super friendly and very welcoming, I'd give it 4  1/2 out of 5 stars. We wouldn't mind coming here again if we're close by.
author: Jackie A.

description: Typical Chinese operated sushi place. Charge for tea (pots). Hamachi kama was like baked, not real fried. Sushi overall is acceptable.
author: Fatima L.

description:
Love this sushi place!  Came here with a bunch of friends after the wait time at Lime was just TOO long, and what a pleasant surprise!  The food was great, the but service was even better.  Plus, we all ordered bottomless mimosas for only $7 a person!  

Let me tell you -- THEY KEEP THEM BOTTOMLESS.  

We couldn't even keep track of how many mimosas we each had, as the waitress came back and refilled them even better we needed to ask for more.  What else can you ask for?
author: Liz W.

description: Very fresh sushi. Fish and vegetables all high quality. My favorite was their mango roll. Friendly service in a small, casual yet intimate environment, Reasonable prices!
author: Karen J.

description: Great, fresh fish and friendly fast service. Come early as the place was full by 7:00pm. It's a small spot, maybe about 20 customers max. Reasonable prices, we ordered 9 things and it came up to $60.
author: Jo-Anne L.

description: I love love love sushi (have gone out for sushi for the past few days and can't stop!) and Sushi Time may be my new favorite place for cost/quality ratio. This place reminded of the real Japan. It is so cute and hidden. We kept on ordering more and more. Couldn't stop. Baked mussels were AMAZING. The Barbie roll. Toro. Sake. Spicy tuna. Everything was so fresh, tasty, and delicious. PERFECT. And no wait. I am going to dream about it all night. Shoot. I don't think I ate any vegetables. Just fish. Not that I have *any* regrets. Need to return ASAP!
author: Andrew K.

description:
The food was good and I'd go back.

It's a small space and the night I went there with friends it got quite warm inside.  

It's sushi in the city, so it's not inexpensive dinner but Sushi Time wasn't a break the bank type of place.  I got a bowl
author: Asa R.

description:
Tiny sushi place hidden from Market street. Sushi time has the best sushis and rolls in the neighborhood for very affordable prices!

 The best is probably their sushi special - you might get fatty tuna with a bit of luck.

Be ready to wait for a table if you are going during the weekends. The place is small and cannot fit more than 20 people.
author: Thomas R.

description:
Sliver of a spot in the Castro.  In a mini mall down a flight of stairs you will find this tiny den of sushi goodness. 

The fish was so fresh.  I gorged on hamachi toro, butter fish, spanish mackerel, uni and ikura.  The pieces were so delicious and sufficient but not so big you felt you were going to have to make multiple bites.  Then I also decided to try the Speed Racer Roll and Barbie Roll.  The later was with crab, avocado inside and topped with salmon and fresh lemon.  The other roll came with tuna and mango and tobiko on the outside.   What I really liked was the simplicity of the rolls, their kitchy names and the combination of ingredients wasn't off the crazy.

A glass of sake and a large Asahi to wash it all down.  I sushi rolled myself right out of there full and happy.  It's always SUSHI TIME in my book so this place definitely hit it out of the park for me.
author: Caesar R.

description:
Sushi Time is definitely a hidden gem. Hidden in the literal sense too in that it's inside a small mall/plaza. It's a small and quaint sushi joint. luckily we didnt have to wait and sat at the bar. 

we got the 10-piece combo from the appetizer section and it was DELICIOUS. we also ordered the 5 piece walu special which was also super tasty. we were still a bit hungry after 15 pieces and had a great experience so we ordered a rainbow roll which was just as good. 

sushi time definitely does not dissapoint. also, it's a great date spot but you probably dont want to go there if you want to talk about anything personal.
author: Janet Y.

description:
Super cute little underground place. Been a couple times and never had to wait (small groups only as there are only 8 tables total). 

Great quality, love the Barbie roll. The slice of thinly sliced lemon is perfect!
author: Mario P.

description: It was good, price is so reasonable. Some tiny little place, fishes are fresh, must try the Barbie roll.
author: James F.

description:
Like everyone says it's pretty hidden. Small little place, maximum capacity at around less than 20 people. So be sure to call or something to see if it's full or not. Parking might be a little hard to find during the day.

SALMON!! So fresh it feels like it clears your nasals when you lay a piece on your tongue. The rolls were awesome, including their names!
author: Hui L.

description:
Great place, great service , great sushi. Very creative menu and solid execution. 

Service - friendly, fast, efficient. 
Food - top quality; varied sushi menu that goes beyond the bore of other places without getting whacky. 
Atmosphere - small place w tight seating; upbeat but not noisy; not a romantic date night setting, although the comical touchy feely 50-yr old creepster and his 25ish dimly lit date sitting next to us might beg to differ. 
Crowd - wide range; all pleasant, not a fedora in sight. 
Favorite bite - Tai Carpaccio
author: B A.

description:
The food was ok. Not amazing, but decent.
For sake- they could not give a sample to decide between two options, even though they do sell by glass.
Sticky table tops.
