Tuna avocado tartar was sweet, which is weird.
Ikura nigiri- barely any ikura in it, which is disappointing.
The fish is fresh, so I keep it 3 stars.
author: I B.

description:
Go during Happy Hour.  You will not be disappointed.

Fresh. Affordable. Delicious.

Need I say more?
author: Colleen L.

description:
I ordered the sake dan.  The salmon sashimi very fresh and buttery - the freshest I've had in a long time, and the FRESHEST I've had in SF.  In contrast, the butterfish (aka escolar or super white tuna) - tasted kinda funky - definitely not fresh.
Rice was seasoned well and at a good temperature, though I tend to like my rice a tad bit more vinegary.

Located in a tiny/awkward strip mall, the restaurant interior is super small, only able to seat maybe 20ish people.  No reservations, but you can put your name & phone number down, and they'll call you when a table is ready.
author: Jeanne L.

description:
Sushi is great. Ikura was fresh. Delicious. A new favourite. Staff was very friendly. I would definitely go back again. 

Apricot Green Tea was delicious. 

Rolls we got: 

Barbie
Rainbow
Spicy Butterfish
Butterfish Sashimi
Salmon Sashimi

Loved all of them. Love the spicy butterfish roll. So delicious. 

Great value for the price. We were FULL and paid only $70-ish. 

Delicious sesame ice cream to end the meal. Cheers to the staff.
author: Sara M.

description:
I simply cannot get enough of this place. If I could eat here every single day I would, and I would not grown tired of it, I tell you.

Last night we had the Rainbow, Salmon Skin, Speed Racer and Spicy Yellowtail rolls. The Salmon Skin roll has always intrigued me but for some reason it creeps out the folks I normally go with. I finally ordered it and it was average...actually the first average roll I've ever had here. So I don't recommend that one. I think I've tried one of every other roll on the menu and they are all delectable.

Don't forget the Miso soup and Edamame along with a Large Hot Sake. It's so cute that you get to pick your own cups!!!
author: Jennifer P.

description:
We were on a mission for sushi and my date was determined to find this place, so off we went to the Castro on a Wednesday night at 9pm. A tiny sushi place with rave reviews on Yelp? I was down. We walked down Market Street to no avail, but then we saw a small opening of what looked to be an indoor mall area across the street. We ventured over there and there it was -- the neon Sushi Time sign!

The location makes it seem secretive and kind of trendy, but I love how intimate it is. There's a bar area with about 8 or so seats and another 8 tables for 2. Walking in, we were immediately greeted by the host/waiter and seated in a cozy corner. On the table there's a small container of soy sauce, a little plate for your soy sauce, a napkin, and wooden chopsticks held together in a wooden case. It was simple and cute. 

We ordered some sake (which turned out to be too much to finish for either of us). When you order the larger size, it comes in a cute glass and they let you pick out your own shot glass to pour it in from their little collection.

Between the two of us, we ordered the Barbie Roll, the Spicy Tuna Roll, and the Rainbow Roll. Not too long after we ordered, our rolls were delivered to us all laid out on a single plate. They were all nicely put together and I almost didn't know where to start! The Rainbow roll was tasty and just as I remembered. The Spicy Tuna roll was pretty average, though mild when it came to the spice. The one that I was pleasantly surprised with was the Barbie Roll! Maybe it was a hidden chunk of wasabi that I had mixed in with my soy sauce or the zip of sourness from that unassuming bit of lemon so delicately placed on top of each piece, but there was a spicy/sour flavor that just popped out at me and it was GOOD! I can honestly say that it was my favorite of the meal and one of my favorites ever!

I think our total came out to close to $50 after tax. The prices are pretty average compared to other places I have been to. I think the thing that put our bill over the top was the sake that we barely made a dent in. 

The restaurant is a cute date night place because it's small, intimate, and casual. Yes, you have to ask for a key from the host to use the bathrooms, but it's all part of the hole-in-the-wall ambiance of the place. The staff is very polite and attentive and the food is great! Sometimes you have to be careful about the quality of your food, especially if you're eating raw fish, but I didn't question this place at all. It looked amazing and tasted amazing!

For their service, ambiance, and unique sushi rolls, I hope I get to come back again!
author: Leana L.

description: Super fresh and very well priced!!
author: Luke A.

description: Small space but very cozy and a good environment. Barbie roll and the baked mussels are a must try. Prices reasonable and great food
author: J R L.

description:
The sake was better than the meal.

The sashimi tasted fishy and frozen. We ordered butter fish, uni, maguro, shirk maguro, salmon, and yellowtail. No wonder the prices were so cheap!

Service is friendly, but so were the gnats that keep flying around your food.

Wish I could give a better review since I had been wanting to try this place forever. Sadly I won't be back :(
author: Kristen C.

description:
Ok...so we are sitting here waiting for the waiter to calculate the to-go orders' tab, which takes 15 min while we are ready to order. We order and of course the two sushi makers are making the to-go order first. It takes 15 min to get 5 pieces of cut raw fish set at our table. What's worst, we are the only customers here, besides the ppl who ordered to-go, who will be back in 20 mins. Was so glad we beat the rush...

Food was okay...would recommend the Astro Boy Roll.
author: D V.

description:
Sushi time is my NEW favorite sushi place.  (Ok, other than the Tsukiji fish market or Hama-Ko).  But seriously, this place is awesome.  The staff is friendly and happy, the place is cute, the food is excellent, and you can't beat happy hour!!!!!!

Mmmmmm.. sushi-time!
author: Alex H.

description: Had a mixed feeling about this place. The first time was a very pleasant experience as both my partner and I enjoyed the food.  Very authentic Japanese food. Try their uni sushi!  However, my partner and I got sick when we tried the second time. It might be due to the food not being freshly made the second time.  You make the judgment !
author: Alanda B.

description: Best sushi I ever had in San Francisco so far! fresh and delicious. The owner is friendly too. Salmon is yummy. I like their rainbow roll and barbie roll.
author: Melinnie A.

description:
Sushi Time feels like Tokyo in the winter. The restaurant itself is a tiny thimble; the location inside a very weird minimall spanning 16th Street and Market Street is perfectly evocative of similar eateries in Shinjuku or Shibuya stations.

The staff are very polite and the sushi is always fresh. It's a cosy bite and won't destroy your wallet or leave you wondering about the provenance of the seafood.
author: Chris B.

description: we got here right before happy hour ended at 6 and ordered almost everything off the HH menu.  rolls and sashimi were basic but fresh.  4 rolls and 2 apps for less than $50.
author: Helen T.

description: I've gone to Sushi Time once a week for about two years and it is the absolute best hole-in-the-wall sushi gem in the city. Great spot for a date, excellent service, and incredible fresh fish (try the Uni with Quail Egg Nigiri and/or any Unagi Roll). Not too expensive either. 10/10 experience every time :)
author: Brad L.

description:
Excellent quality sushi & rolls.

Funky location at the rear lower level in a small strip mall at Market & 16th. Very tidy space with only a handful of tables & nothing really cooked I noticed on the menu aside from tempura rolls.

Service & quality of the food is top notch.
author: Miguel S.

description: The quality has gone downhill, unfortunately. They either changed owners or all the chefs are different. It's gone from excellent, semi-traditional Japanese sushi with excellent rice to mediocre Chinese-made sushi with squishy, underflavored rice.
author: Jacqueline A.

description:
it's about time I give my favorite sushi resturant in SF a review. Everyone here is so sweet and welcoming, the sushi is ALWAYS fresh.. Never fishy. And the prices are unbeatable. Short and sweet review, explains it all.
Incredible hidden gem:)
author: Kayla C.

description:
Definitely make a reservation if you're going on the weekend. Heck, make that reservation two-three days ahead.

The fish is astonishingly fresh and the beers so deliciously cold. It is a little hard to find but it's definitely one of those semi-hidden treasures. Also, it's a little cramped, especially if you're one for ample space but it does make talking easier.
author: Zooey I.

description: We tried this place on a whim. Glad we did. Haven't eaten inside, we always order for take out. Inside looks comfortable. But man their sushi is awesome! we are never disappointed! Have tried their sushi rolls and nigiri sushi. Always fresh and delicious! Service is fast and friendly as well. Definitely worth checking out! You wont be disappointed!
author: Farheen B.

description: Buttery melt in your mouth fish. Delicate and delicious tuna avocado tart tart. Perfectly salty edamame. best sushi experience in sf is here.
author: Jessica F.

description:
Don't see what all the fuss is about. Sushi is decent and the location seems novel, akin to sushi spots you see on TV in subway stations and malls in Japan. There's really only room for about 15-20 people in the whole place. I thought it was pretty neat.

But it's not Japan, it's just priced that way. Quality of fish was good, but nothing special. Staff was friendly and it got pretty busy after we sat down. I think it's worth checking out but I don't know if I would come back again.
author: R K.

description: I started the night with some really good Sake and Edamame. I got the Sushi Combo B, which was 7 pieces of Nigiri and a Spicy Tuna Roll. Overall, the quality of the fish was excellent, and the price was pretty decent. My combo came with Miso soup and salad, which was very good. I would have been able to find the place if a friend had not pointed it out, but the atmosphere is really nice. Its a very small place, so seating is limited, but I went on a Wednesday night and was able to get a table easily. Making reservations is probably a good idea if you plan to gon on the weekend.
author: Bryan M.

description:
This is one of those hard to find hole in the wall places but definitely worth finding!  I ordered the sashimi (6 pieces for $9.95) and it was SO fresh. The meat literally melted in my mouth. I also ordered the seaweed salad ($3.95)...it was very tasty and the portion size was decent. We also ordered the ebi gyoza (shrimp) and also the tofu and herb gyoza ($5.95). Their gyozas are homemade, with a nice thin shell and very good flavor...much better than the typical potsticker-type gyozas at many other Japanese restaurants. Their chicken teriyaki meat balls ($5.95 for 5) were homemade and very delicious also. 

Overall, very affordable for Japanese food, delicious and fresh ingredients, and good service. I will definitely come again. The restaurant is very small though (total of 6 to 7 tables of twos and a bar area with about 6 chairs) so come early!
author: Angela F.

description:
Lovely and sincere service from the Japanese wait staff. ( not sure if he's the owner or co-owner).

Very cheerful and caring towards the patrons. 

Food was so good and tasted so fresh.

Small place that's all! Pls remember to make reservations ..
author: Tristen N.

description:
Hands down this is the worst place to get sushi for the fact that after eating here you are glued to the toilet! The sushi was sub par at best and the sake only made it bearable. 

The fish is obviously not fresh. I would not recommend this place to my enemies. Goodbye,I have to go to the bathroom now. Thanks Sushi Time!
author: Dave B.

description:
Started off with a yummy miso soup with veggies (potato, carrots...) I have never tried a vegetable Miso soup-- but was curious! and now I will be ordering them if I ever see them again on menus. -- definitely try it!

Seaweed salad was standard. 

Tea's we're fantastic! Mint & Citrus one was refreshing, yet soothing.

While the sushi wasn't as creative as some other sushi places get. The fish was fresh which made each bite delectable. 

Can't disagree with Yelp's 4 Star Rating for them! Also, all this food (3 sushi rolls) with tip ended being just around $40.
author: Lee R.

description:
Wow, this place gets four stars for atmosphere alone.  My husband and I were very apprehensive when we realized the restaurant was in what i can only describe as the basement of a tiny open air mall.  

When we entered the restaurant it felt like we were transported to a different world.  Perhaps a subway station in the bowels of new York or Tokyo?  So much fun.   Tons of decorations, and a layout you have to see for yourself. 

As for the food:
Sake:  we found a very nice bottle (Hikoshima maybe?).  it was nice and smooth.  They brought a box of mismatched glasses out and we got to select which one we wanted to use.  Fun!

I'm vegan so my choices were a bit limited, but I was delighted by the following. 
Miso soup!   They had a vegan option!   Thanks sushi time!   It had a good amount of tofu and seaweed, yummy.   

Veggie roll:  fresh and very tasty. 

3 veggie salad:  they had three salads in one, this was a special.  Asparagus with a very light and delicate dressing.  This was so good, I could have eaten a bucket of it.  Mixed green salad, again a very nice delicate dressing.  Finally a wakame salad that was soooooo good I ended up getting a second order of just that 

My husband is omnivore and he said the quality of the fish was great, nothing to write home about, but much better then your usual hole in the wall. 

My two disappointments.  I came here because I wanted to try the vegan Gyoza featured on their online menu.  At the restaurant they told me they are no longer allowed to serve the cooked foods, too bad!  

My second disappointment was that they had a cold tofu entree on the menu served with 'chicken sauce'. I enquired as to whether this was vegan and they told me, no, it has pork...  Weird.  Maybe this was a language barrier.  

Overall, very nice.  We'll be back.
author: Evelyn N.

description:
Our favorite sushi place in the city. Really well priced and great food.
Always get walu if they have some.
author: Peter L.

description: So this place is REALLY hard to find; it's tucked away in a small little complex. But this place is a gem! The sushi quality was great, decent portions and great pricing. I may have just found my go to sushi spot.
author: Eric C.

description:
So, we were originally planning on going to Sushi Zone, but the wait was unbelievable. We ended up here, underground in a weird little mall. Definitely worth it. The wait was about average (25-30 minutes on a Friday night at 8), so it certainly had that over Sushi Zone (still haven't tried that place, but I hear good things). 

Food: quality. I can't remember all of the rolls that we had, but the astro boy was REALLY good. The fish seemed fresh and it wasn't over the top with sauce, so you could really taste it. 

Service: Amazing! It was just two people, so maybe I should come back with 8 to see how it is, but they were on top of it. We got our food quickly, our waiter was very attentive. It was no nonsense, they came with the food, filled up your drinks, asked basic questions and left you alone. I really appreciated the "no hovering" aspect of the service. 

Drinks: this is the only reason why Sushi time lost a star. It tasted too...alcoholic I guess. 

Other than the saki, I'd definitely recommend this place and intend on coming back!
author: Sonia J.

description: My favorite sushi place in the world! I will wait the hour to sit in one of the 9 tables. The Barbie roll is fantastic., the sushi is always fresh. Just absolutely no comparison anywhere else in the city. I've tried, but I always come back to you!
author: Lana S.

description:
There are better options out there.

About the food:
The fish was just okay.
A bit too much wasabi on the nigiri I ordered.
The barbie roll in particular had the smallest slivers of lemon I have seen on this type of roll.
All of the sushi (nigiri, rolls) seemed miniature when compared to other places.

About the place:
Service is slow.
The place is small and cramped, but unique.
They use non-disposable chopsticks, which is nice.

For Japanese-style sushi (i.e. nigiri), there are better (albeit more expensive) places in the area for sushi, like Eiji.
author: Glendon M.

description:
Yes its in the basement, and yes its small. That doesn't change the fact that the service is good and the sushi is fresh!

I love that they don't smother the fish in sauces. It doesn't need it. The Walu butterfish Sashimi is a must. It was sooo tasty. I also really enjoyed the yellowtail and scallions roll, simple and good. Overall, a casual and cosy spot to grab relatively inexpensive and great sushi!
author: Natalie N.

description:
By far the best sushi place around.
Great price, great staff, great food.
I enjoy coming here, because it is not overly "sauced" for presentation. It is great sushi and it doesn't need to be overpowered by extra sauces. 
I enjoy that it is small, as the sushi is always fresh. The also have gluten free soy sauce here!
author: Dat P.

description:
This little tucked away Sushi restaurant is a wondeful find. We've actually walked past it several times and finally ventured in to try. You can either enter to it on Market Street below the Alex Gym, or from the 16th Street side at the Dinosaur Vietnamese Sandwich shop.

They were offering quite a few specials on our first night there, and we tried most of them . . . . . each one delicious. 

Starting out with the Miso soup and Cucumber and Seaweed salad was a nice introduction, then the rolls and Nigiri started coming and we could have eaten all night. 

Very excited to go again to see which specials they will be offering. And really nice that they are locate underneath our favorite S.F. bookstore, Books Inc.
author: Mickey A.

description:
My second Yelp review goes to:  Fave. Sushi. Spot. Ever!  
Great date spot btw!  Please see end of review for after dinner spots.

PRICE: 4
Decent for what you're getting.  IMO, not cheap but neither pricey.  Took a date months ago (yes, I PAID), and from what I rem, we ordered the tuna tartar, several yummy rolls, a large sake and hot tea.  With tax/tip it was $63.  BUT if you forgo the sake/tea, it'll be less!  

P.S. They do offer a Happy Hour.  Check website for details.

FOOD: 5
Yumm!!  Faves include:  the tuna & avocado tartar (fresh & delish!), Barbie Roll (that thin slice of lemon outside the salmon/avocado/crab just hits the spot!), and amazing fragrant hot tea (i think it was peach or apricot).

AMBIANCE: 5
Fabulous - literally tiny, very cozy, dimly lit, cute homey decor and coat rack in the back.

SERVICE: 5
Great, friendly, but it is a tiny restaurant that does not take reservations, so be prepared to wait on a busy night.

LOCATION/PARKING: 4
Very hidden in the Castro. I remember it previously being called Underground Sushi Time, and it really is - you go downstairs from the main road to enter.  Parking - well it is SF.  Circle for street parking.

COMPLAINTS:
Minor, but you need a key to use the outside restroom.  And no reservations.

REC AFTER DINNER SPOTS:
Within walking distance in the Castro, there's Sweet Inspirations where you can enjoy a HUGE piece of triple berry cheesecake, and then stroll over to the fabulously trendy Lime for a STRONG drink with the friendly gay bartenders!  

Enjoy, Yelpers!
author: Ella W.

description:
I came here during a weeknight with my friend and oddly enough, it wasn't a place I have noticed and I've probably walked by it several times. The restaurant is inside another building for those who are looking. Anyways, they were busy and we put our names down on the wait list and decided to wander around since they told us it was going to be about a 30 minute wait. After walking around in the other stores, we receive a call telling us that our table was ready but we were 10 minutes away and we told them that they could feel free to give up our seats to someone else and we'll take the following seats and they told us that they'll hold the seats for us. I was pleasantly surprised to hear that and made our way there as fast as we could.

When we arrived, we got seated immediately. I ordered Rock N Roll and a Dragon Roll and my friend ordered a spicy tuna roll of some sort and something else that I couldn't quite catch as well as some nigiri. Both of my rolls were delicious but I think I might try their shrimp tempura roll next time since having two unagi rolls gets to be a bit overwhelming with the sweet 'bbq' sauce they drizzle on top.

All in all, I had a great experience here (and extra points for holding our seats). I definitely see myself coming back. One thing to note though, the place is actually quite small so you should probably expect to have to wait but it's worth it.
author: Richard C.

description:
Very small and kool little Sushi Joint in the Castro. The wait was about 30 minutes. I was really worried how stuffy it got inside. But once we sat down, it wasnt that bad. 

We ordered the Astro Boy, Barbie Roll, Gyoza, Crunchy Roll. 

Everything was just ok. Nothing that would make me want to come back here. Just a ok sushi joint with good flavors and fresh seafood. Thats it. 

Prices are reasonable so you dont have to dish out a arm and a leg for some good sushi.
author: Joseph G.

description: This spot is legit!!  Had take-out a couple of times in the last week or so from this place.  Their sashimi is fresh and prices are fair.  Not good for large groups as this place is quite small.
author: Leland H.

description: Hands down the best sushi I have found in the city so far. Definitely a hidden gem of fresh sushi and great service. Rolls are large and quality exceptional.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
This place is hard to find as it's in a building so you won't spot it from just driving around. Also, it's super small...it can probably only fit 20 ppl or so. However, the ambiance is intimate and slightly romantic. 

We got the astro boy, barbie roll and crunchy rolls. My favorite was the astro boy as it combines scallop and mango. Yum! Who knew it worked so well together. For the barbie roll, I thought the roll was okay, but there was bit too much lemon on it. Finally, the bf most enjoyed the crunchy roll but that's because it's fried.
author: Margaret R.

description: Love this place!  Fav is Barbie Roll and their sashimi and specials are always fresh and delicious!  Try them!
author: Dave C.

description: The service was very nice but I thought the fish quality was sub-par. We had the barbie roll, rainbow roll, spicy yellowtail, mackeral (nigiri) and philadelphia roll. The only one I liked was the philadelphia roll which as you may know is not really authentic sushi! It's a cute location and awesome staff, but I wouldn't try this again of my own accord.
author: Sonya Z.

description: Having tried so many different places I would say sushi time scores average to high average. The sashimi was great but the Philly role only average. The service is nice but the place in general rather underground.
author: Chris S.

description: Large portions and fresh fish.  Cute hole in the wall.  My favorite spot in the Castro.
author: Jack T.

description:
We went to Sushi Time for the first time tonight (a Saturday night). Very, very, very good experience!

We arrived around 5:30pm there was one open table and a few seats at the bar. We decided to sit at the bar. It's a small restaurant but somehow it works. Their happy hour is between 5pm-6pm so we made it in time for that -- we ended up getting a great value for our money. They play good music that isn't intrusive at all. The location itself is a bit tricky and it would be easy to walk right past it without knowing since it's located down a flew flights of stairs and isn't visible from Market Street. Parking can also be a challenge, so be prepared to walk if you drive -- Muni may be the nest option if you live in SF.

The service was outstanding -- the sushi chefs and the waitstaff were very friendly, attentive and they each thanked us when we left.

As for the food -- we ordered various rolls and each tasted fresh and satisfied our craving for sushi. 
Specifically, we ordered-
--California Roll
--Philadelphia Roll
--New York Roll
--Barbie Roll (highlight of the meal for sure!)
--Mango Mochi Ice Cream (delicious -- and perfect way to end the meal!!!)

5-star experience. We definitely plan to return!
author: M. A.

description:
My first experience here was really good.
Lets start off with some pros:

Teas and food: The food you get is worth your money. We started off with two teas. They have a really good selection of infused blends like peach apricot. It's a MUST to get if you come here. For an appitizer, we got the tuna tartar. Presentation was great, along with the taste. I forgot what three rolls we got but they were okay. The sashimi is very fresh and melts in your mouth. It's sliced thinner so it was a different texture to other sushi places that serve it thick. MMM. :)

Setting:  The place was very tiny, but very cozy. It's a nice dinner place to take someone out on a date. You're most expected with a friendly welcome and great customer service. IF YOU'RE PLANNING ON A PARTY OF 6+ THIS IS NOT THE PLACE. It's more of a home-y place for a small group.

Price: Altogether, the price came out to be around $60. Which is pretty average for a good sushi dinner. What can I say, you pay for what you get! 

Cons:
Parking: Hard to find if you're going there for a late night dinner. Streets can be a bit confusing. Also the location of the place is pretty hard to find. If you're planning on using an Iphone for directions, you'd feel as confused as I was. 

To sum it up, I would go here again because it was very YUMM. The searching is worth it guys.
author: cheryl c.

description:
Tonight was probably the third time I left the house with the intent of finally trying Eiji. This time, I wasn't too hungry to endure the wait and I was alone, so the number of seats available wasn't the issue. No, this time, they were just closed. "Sorry for the inconvenience."

There used to be a cheap, crappy sushi place on the corner, but it took a good long look at itself since the last time I couldn't eat at Eiji and realized that it was living a lie. That is to say, the place on the corner is now a Chinese Restaurant.

And that's how I found Sushi Time. Or "Underground Sushi Time" as the sign says. As you have read a dozen times by now, it's tucked away inside a deceptively deep outdoor mall that takes up the corner of Market and 16th. Entrances on either street are sushi-accessible. 

Rock'n Roll - the weak link. I realize now that they don't serve cooked food at all. So no hot kitchen. No broiler for the eel, either, I guess. Which makes me wonder where the eel came from because even though it was served cold, it was still formerly broiled.

Speed Racer Roll - fun. It took a few bites for me to figure out that when mango is in the equation, even more wasabi than usual is required. Otherwise it was a bit too sweet.

Wild salmon nigiri - fresh. The end.

I sat at the bar, drank my fresh sake, ate my sushi, and didn't bother nobody. The atmosphere was cozy and cavelike. The service was prompt. I'll bring a date next time.
author: Will R.

description:
Definately, I had a mix feeling about this place.  Yeah, for the sushi quality,  it is a 5 star *****.  In the  scale of increasing tenderness and sweet lip:  for example:   tai (red snapper), shima aji (amber jack), kanpachi (greater amberjack, and a personal all time favorite). Advanced  sushi eaters deviate from Tuna eating seeking for the perfect texture.    Please note that: albanoe was available on weekends' special menu

Last week, I tried something very adventurous:  slowly boiled, simmered stingray 'arm' (believe it or not)  Eihire nitsuke. But, whoe!!  What an adventurous  experience.

The cooking is extremely well executed: thick savory soup to mask the naturally fishy taste, slow cook allow the meat to soften, and the 'bone' was crunchy and edible. But yes, the natural fishy taste will keep me away for a while

Diners are allowed to buy one piece of sashimi at a time - very affordable in this expensive restaurant. That makes Tai - red snapper $3 for a tasting / brief satisfaction.


That being said Kabuto has other more tangible creative dishes: specialty sushi  that you can't find anywhere else. Everyone talks about Cerviche, it was perfectly executed, the halibut was extremely tender and soft, with perfect light flavor of lime and salt

At first,  I thought about ranking it 3 stars.  The main reason was because the restaurant is rather shabby looking. There is no ambiance for the money you are paying.  The space is so  small and so crammed, such that the wall bare except for a couple of odd decors. Most disappointedly, the waitresses are very busy and less friendly, unlikely to engage in a passionate sushi discussion with us, well, and  perhaps, I strongly suggest that, it is the intensity trickling down from the sushi counter chefs.

Sushi chefs are tense and serious, lack of smile or communication even to those sitting at the counter. That is zero words, zero interaction. That really killed one of the best part of the dining experience. If you come here alone, you will be alone forever.And if you come here with a group, the restaurant can barely accommodate.

Fighting between 4 stars or 3 stars.......
author: Randal M.

description:
By far and away, the best sushi I've had in San Francisco. Everything was yummy and extremely fresh. Plus, the staff and decor made me feel like I was back in Japan.

In short, this tiny place is huge on yummy.
author: P Z.

description: My two sons (7 and 11 years old) INSIST on going to Sushi Time on their birthdays. Yesterday was no exception and, again, the restaurant delivered an exceptional dining experience. From the intimate setting with authentic Japanese design to the very attentive and accommodating wait staff to the delicious, fresh, high quality sushi, we were wowed for the ___th time. I highly recommend this place.
author: Barry J.

description:
Tucked in the folds of businesses catering to the gay population of the Castro is Sushi Time. I've been looking all over for a decent "budget sushi" and I was glad to discover it in my own backyard! You can dine here for less than $25 and you'll get fresh and decent cuts of fish. There's no skimping in the portion either, though I wouldn't describe it as generous.

Sushi Time's address is on Market Street,but  the actual location is as everyone says is "underground." I don't mind it at all because it reminds me of restaurants in Japan where it's not uncommon to step down and into a cave-like food establishment. The Japanese decorations create a cozy atmosphere to an otherwise fairly cramped space.

Although not rude, service at Sushi Time could be improved considerably. It's surprising how the servers often fail to pay attention to the diners considering how small a space they have to watch. The servers strike me as scatterbrains. The kitchen is always a little slow, so perhaps despite the smallness of its size, Sushi Time may be understaffed or lacking trained employees. I noticed the main chef is Japanese with Chinese helps, one of whom appears to be in his sushi training currently.
author: Rina W.

description: Such a lovely place. The quality of the fish was amazing. Honestly the only thing I could complain about is the place is relatively small, but I guess that's what you get in SF. It was pretty stuffy in there as well, but for the food and the great service, definitely somewhere I would come back to.
author: Heather T.

description:
This little hidden gem has the closest ambiance I've seen to being transported to an authentic sushi bar in Tokyo. It's cramped, dark, and cluttered with cute, eclectic decorations.

They have creamiest tuna avocado tartare with a hint of fresh garlic.

The rolls are good, but nothing outstanding.

Make sure to take notice of the wonderful little touches they have here including the wooden pepper shakers, wooden box for the check, and chopstick holders.

The owners and sushi chefs are very friendly and stayed after the restaurant closed to chat with us.
author: Mark Y.

description: This is really a hidden gem for super fresh, inexpensive sushi. This is the only place I would get uni - it's oh so fresh. There is always a wait there, but it's worth the wait.
author: Lien N.

description: Came here on Friday before going to see hardwell and I was not disappointed ! This place is hidden in the back its kind of underground like a basement , it's a pretty small little restaurant but they serve delicious sushi :) super fast and great costumer service .
author: Nancy G.

description:
You can't go to San Francisco and not eat Asian. We were looking for a place to fill the "Japanese" category for our trip. Found this place on Yelp and boy did it not disappoint! First off, best Miso soup...EVER! Filled with flavor we could have drank a gallon of it (well not really but you get the idea). Next we had some great sushi. Not usually a fan of tempura sushi but here, the batter is light and crispy. Combine that with fresh shrimp and we have another winner.

This place is so good we went twice in two days! It's sort of hidden in a mini mall so you have to be looking for it, but trust me, it's well worth it. Great prices and stellar sushi.

Best I've hand anywhere in this US!
author: Brad F.

description:
My friend and I had reservations at Hanna Zen at their new location but unfortunately they were canceled due to some private event. So she scrambled to find a place for dinner and ended up picking here because of the yelp reviews. We got off at Castro station and started walking. We arrived in front of a supplements store and I commented... "this is it?!" Little did I know it was downstairs, almost underground like. Because of its' small capacity, waiting for a table is more often than not. However we were served immediately to a cozy table for two by the wall. 

This place is like a time capsule where time has stopped. The ambiance is soothing and intimate, perfect for dinner dates. The menu has variety and the sushi is so inexpensive. their speciality rolls are usually $10 and the others are $3-6. Sashimi is a bit pricier but oh so worth it! Everything is so unbelievably fresh, the fish just melts in your mouth like "I can't believe it's not butter!" pun intended. We ordered a Hello Kitty roll, Crunchyroll, Garden roll, Sashimi, Wakame salad and Genmaicha. Come with a big appetite because this meal is filling. Restrooms are besides the restaurant, I think a token is needed from the waiters. Our waiter was very attentive and nice, topped with an orgasmic sushi experience, tips were a ++
author: Mindy X.

description: Two people recently recommended this place when sushi restaurants in the Castro were discussed so I was curious to check it out. We went on a weeknight around 7 pm (party of two). Although the place is small (only tables for two plus the bar) we were seated right away. We ordered the sashimi mix, a couple of pieces of nigiri plus the GI Joe roll that was recommended in some reviews here. The food was OK but nothing really stood out. I did like the atmosphere (when was the last time you heard Katibim at a sushi restaurant?) and the staff was friendly but the food was not particularly interesting.
author: Vladimir P.

description:
I've had their sushi rolls to go, and tonight I dined in.
The ambience is really chill: it feels like you walk into a Japanese hut with bamboo shoot walls and low lights, topped off with some eclectic eastern art and an open sushi bar. For $25 I shared half of a Philadelphia Roll, New York Roll, Spicy Tuna Roll, Eel Nigiri, and Fresh Albacore Nigiri (my highlight), + a big Sapporo and a glass of Sauvignon Blanc. 

The city's sushi in general has been hit or miss for me, nothing yet has blown my mind. This place was a hit!
author: Kevin L.

description: My favorite was the yummy tuna poke appetizer.  A bit cramped in space so I wouldn't expect to have a private conversation here.   But the wait staff were amazing and the sushi came out quickly.  Although I never felt rushed.    The fish was fresh and I enjoyed everything I ordered.  I would definitely come back for a quick bite.
author: Frank A.

description:
Sushi time is fantastic if you are just about high quality fish. The fish was incredible, and the price was quite affordable. I didn't try any of the more adventurous rolls, just nigiri and simple rolls. 

This is a small place and the service is pretty slow, but just come for the fish.
author: Brian S.

description:
Some secrets are best kept.
Sushi Time is one of those and here I go, opening my mouth. *sigh*

In my book, it's always sushi time.
:the neighborhood spot you can always count on.
:tiny enough you shouldn't show up with your entire fan club. 2-4 people max.
:budget friendly but still great quality fish (think $20pp)
:combo dinners, playful rolls (think: Speed Racer) and a slew of salads and appetizers worth trying.
:colorful decor, in that playful Japanese style I can't begin to describe
:tucked away little nook that's best kept between you and me
author: Alissa A.

description: I normally order take out but I decided to actually dine in with my date. First off, I'd like to say that the atmosphere of this restaurant is very warm and welcoming. The service is very good, they treated us well. And the sushi is good as well. I will definitely come back for more.
author: Dennis L.

description:
Love the location of this place, all underground and hidden from the street view - it'll make all your hipster friends jealous that you're in the know.  

Ambience-wise this is a good place for a casual dinner w/ a friend or significant other but probably not so great for a date - getting a table was a bit of a pain and once we sat down they seemed to be in a rush to get us out.  

Food-wise we stuck to rolls which were tasty but nothing too exciting - a plus is the rolls are pretty big and inexpensive.  We had the GI Joe (OK), Rainbow Roll (good), and spicy yellowtail roll (excellent) - I'm not a fan of spicy mayo on my rolls but their mayo is excellent, I recommend any of their rolls with this sauce.  Again, the rolls are generally good but next time I plan on checking out the sashimi/nigiri.  The seaweed salad is also tasty - not too sweet and just the right amount of chewy.  

Overall 1 star for the super-secret location, 2 more for the tasty rolls, and a 4th star for having creating that tasty spicy mayo....
author: Rosers M.

description:
Oh, the elusive five star rating.  It's well deserved by Sushi Time!  And who would have guessed?  A VERY inconspicuous hidden little (and I mean, little) place on Market Street, in the Castro, tucked away in some random mini mall type arrangement.

My roommate recommended this place, saying, "it's SUPER cheap."  That's why I went there last Saturday night, and was a little annoyed to find that it actually wasn't THAT cheap.  It's average in price - I got a yellowtail maki roll (just yellowtail and scallions) for $5, a spicy tuna for about the same, and a salmon / avocado roll for around $5.50.  That sounds super cheap, but you only get 6 pieces instead of 8 in each roll, so if you're a sushi lover or just have a big appetite, you'll probably need 3 rolls, if you stick to the not so fancy items on the menu.

Also - our rolls came out at lightening speed.

However, if you go during happy hour (5pm - 6pm), this place IS super cheap.  They have a good selection of rolls for a dollar or two less than they normally are.  Yes, our experience was so phenomenal on Saturday night that we came back on Monday.

But trust me, the rolls are worth every penny.  Each roll has a VERY generous chunk of fish.  This is not one of those places that skimps on the fish, and tries to over compensate with way too much rice.  No, none of that here.  And the freshness, oh my...

Finally, I have found my go to sushi spot.
author: Ashley M.

description: I'm not a sushi connoisseur but I know Sushi Time is fantastic. The Barbie roll is a must and the miso soup is by far the best I've had. The guys that work there are polite and prompt. It may look like a soccer dugout or a bus stop but it's a wonderfully cosy and intimate restaurant.
author: Dan C.

description:
One of my favorite sushi spots in the city - I used to live around the corner and went at least once a week!

Staff is very friendly, the space is a bit tiny (which only adds to the ambiance, in my opinion), and the decor makes the space feel warm and cozy.  The restaurant is slightly hard to find, as it's down a staircase (if you're on Market St.) or behind Dinosaurs (if you're on 16th).

The fish here is *incredibly* fresh - nigiri standouts are the sake and hamachi, which both melt in your mouth!  My favorite rolls are the Barbie (california roll with salmon and a tiny lemon slice on top), which is refreshing and delicious, spicy hamachi/spicy walu, and the Astro Boy roll, which has scallop, mango, cucumber, and a small dollop of spicy sauce on top.  I also love that you can choose your own sake cup :)  

All in all, a great spot to grab dinner before a night out in the Castro!
author: Katie F.

description: Small and intimate. Delicious sushi and great service. Everyone who works here is very friendly. Love this spot!
author: Kellsie F.

description: Cutest sushi place I've ever been to! Very attentive staff and fast service. The sushi was amazing! I'm definitely stopping by again when I come back to SF!
author: Sydney N.

description: An incredibly charming place. The food was good, the people were friendly and it seemed incredibly intimate and homey, like the people running the place did so out of love rather than out of mandated/salaried habit. To be honest, I did not know places like this existed in San Francisco and I was on a high having discovered one.
author: Donald C.

description: The (wild caught) salmon nigiri was fresh and flavorful.  And the hotate and amaebe ones were wonderful too.  But the butterfish had an unpleasant, not-so-fresh fishy taste.
author: Warren L.

description:
The short:  Funky, fresh, fun!

The long:

I've lived in the castro for a little over 2 years, and my boyfriend has lived here for 8.  We've never really noticed this place, although we occasionally see signs near the muscle-powder store.  I happened to be looking here on yelp for a late-night dinner when I saw that this place had great reviews.

I ordered the dishes I thought were the hardest to serve well:
Uni with quail egg, bonito with lime and scallion, white tuna, and a tobiko hand roll with shiso.  Their sake list had 5-6 different cold sakes, none of which I had heard of.  I had 3 of them, and they were all fantastic and corresponded quite well to the tasting notes.

Everything was super-fresh, expertly prepared, and delicious.

This place is an absolute jewel.
author: Cameo W.

description: Love, Love, Love Sushi Time.  Yes, it's a tiny place and the menu is simple, but I think that's what gives Sushi Time such charm.  Masa, the owner, is the best and he finds the freshest tasting sushi grade fish in the bay area.  We've tried a lot of sushi places in the upper Market area and this is the best, hands down, for simple, perfectly executed, fresh tasting sushi.  A lot of the negative reviews on here focus on the wait, but if you can't wait for a true sushi chef to work his craft on your meal, maybe you should go pick something up at Safeway or Baracuda Sushi a couple of doors down.  Just sayin.
author: Jeff H.

description:
The boyfriend and I dined here the Saturday before Valentine's Day for dinner.  By the time we found parking and arrived to this place, we were starving and happy to be in a restaurant that didn't have many people and a long wait.  

This place is extremely intimate.  Like, I-can-almost-touch-dude's-shoulder-who's-sitting-in-the-table-next-to-me intimate.  The decor is festive and fun, and the bathroom isn't found in the restaurant itself, but outside it's doors and shared with the rest of the strip mall.  Just ask for the key.

Without us even knowing, we arrived during their happy hour which called for $4 rolls (which I found was just $1 off their regular price).  So we decided to order the Spicy Tako and Spicy Tuna Rolls from the happy hour menu.  From the roll specials, we ordered the Crunchy Roll.

Out came the rolls and they were pretty small.  Only a few pieces per roll and they all fell short in flavor. I was expecting to be WOWed, but unfortunately, that wasn't experienced here.
author: Alma R.

description:
I was skeptical of this place walking down the stairs but as soon as I walked in I very much liked the ambiance and decoration. The restaurant is in a small basement but very nice and cozy. The staff is friendly and the food is definitely good for the price. The best part was when the waiter brought a box full of sake cups so we could pick whichever we wanted. I thought is was cute :) The sake was great too.
Overall, it is a nice place to have good food. Not for groups larger than 5-6 people though.
author: Azi Z.

description:
I always reminisce about Japan when I come here. Not sure why, maybe because it's such a cozy restaurant with great food. I like everything I order here, so there's no need to list what I had. One thing that stands out, because I don't think I had this anywhere else, is the Sabagari roll. Combination of mackerel and ginger is very unique.

Good service, pleasant experience and fresh fish!
author: CatsPjs Z.

description:
Hidden away from the world is Sushi Time.

There's a sign. It's the right address, I promise. But where the hell is it?

Underground, though a strange and sort of outdoorsy-indoor mall of a building, is teeny tiny Sushi Time.

(Side note: I was sort of laughing to myself about the fact that Rachel C and I were trying to go to Sushi Zone, and ended up at Sushi Time. Hilarious names, IMHO.)

Itty bitty Sushi Time may be small, but what it lacks in size it makes up for in flavor. All of our rolls were pretty great... however, some were more flavorful than others (par for the course, I believe). Philly rolls have cream cheese in them and are super bad for you, but for some reason this one was especially fantastic. The spicy tuna was well done, and the eel was delicious here. (I could have lived w/ out the scallop roll.) The sake/beer/wine list is short but pretty alright -- though I felt bad for Rachel C, as she's not a sake drinker, and that seemed to be the focus of the drink list.

If you need to use the restroom, you need to get a key. Gas station? Yes. Charming? I'm not sure. Sushi? Delicious and well worth the strange setting.
author: Rachel F.

description:
My new favorite sushi place in SF but still, NOTHING beats Sakana in Phoenix.

Going again this evening for happy hour sushi then to Sakana next week.  Yummy.
author: Anthony D.

description:
I've been on ANOTHER sushi binge lately but literally just found this place while walking on the street with the GF and boy am I happy I did.

Sushi Time is tucked in the corner of the bottom floor of a complex full of colorful businesses inspired by the Castro that really made me fee like I was in Tokyo. The place is small and when we went there was no wait so we bellied up to the sushi bar.  

The prices are reasonable but the freshness of the fish is worth it, really.

The Walu lived up to its butterfish name and melted in my mouth.  A big roll of Walu runs around 5.00.  We also had the Hamachi rolls, 5.00, with green onion and again the fish was fresh and immediately disintegrated in my mouth.  We ordered some nigiri which was also good but the Walu and Hamachi stole the show.

The service was very attentive and overall a great sushi experience.  Definitely a must go if you are gonna go sing a couple tunes at the Mint.
author: Richard N.

description: I've lived in the neighborhood for years, and for whatever reason had never visited Sushi Time until this past Saturday night for my boyfriends birthday.  I have to say it's by far the BEST and freshest sushi in the Castro.  Super friendly service, I love these guys.  Try the G.I. Joe roll and the Spicy tuna.  Delicious.
author: Joseph Y.

description: This restaurant is small so good for dates and small intimate groups.  Their rolls were okay and the nigiri wasn't that spectacular.  I've had better grade quality fish. But the serving for the rolls are pretty generous.  I wouldn't go out of my way to come here again.
author: M. T.

description:
Kinda cool that it's underground and reminds me of the real deal in Japan. Nigiris have always been fresh and soft, though their rice is hit or miss (last time too dry, other times too moist).  Rolls are of the solid B to B+ variety. 

They don't take reservations, but if you go with a small group (2 people) you probably won't have to wait more than 15 minutes. Not good for larger groups. Service is decent, but not the highlight. 

For some reason it's my go-to sushi spot of the moment, guess I just like the intimate feel, minimal wait, and good fish quality.

Disclaimer: Sushi Time is a sponsor and I work for Yelp
author: Jeremy S.

description: Sushi zone was too long of a wait and we took a long stroll to ST.  What a wonderful meal.  Very delightful.  Can't wait to go back.
author: J H.

description:
This place is literally a hole in the wall. I don't recall a door when I walked in, haha.  It is also not visible off the street.  It's located inside a mini plaza within a building.  If you are walking on 16th street towards market, you'll pass the original IKE's Place and you'll see a sign that points you inside.

It's very small and cramped place...no I really mean it. This place is small. It can't hold more than 20 people by my guess.  But it's just utterly charming and the sushi is good.

Astroboy and the rainbow roll are great. Didn't care for much else.  The portion sizes are pretty small in that the actual sushi itself is just smaller than most other places.  The prices should be readjusted accordingly.

I went out of my way to go and try this place. I wouldn't do it again.  I would suggest this place as an alternative if the lines at IKE's or a Kitchen story are out of control. Better places in the city for sushi
author: Christopher M.

description:
Alright... this place is not THAT good. It's not bad but I don't think it's Kabuto or anything. Definitely does look like you walked into a submarine. The place is SMALL! Fits 14 people on tables plus some on the bar. Waitresses were nice but slow. At the end, we wanted water but NONE of us got any, besides two that already had theirs a while back.

If you're looking for beef/chicken teriyaki, not the place. Lots of sushi options. 

I tried the:
Hello Kitty Roll ($.8.00): Mango, cucumber, with hamachi on top (I think, can't really remember). Served with a side of dipping sauce.
 -This was good cuz the fish was fresh but other then that, I found it really boring... Not really a lot of flavor to it.
Rainbow Roll ($9.50): Crab inside and tuna, yellowtail, salmon, shrimp, eel, avocado outside.
 -Again, fish was really fresh but a Rainbow Roll is just a Rainbow Roll, besides having fresh fish compared to some other restaurants..

No fried Ice Cream????

Prices was definitely reasonable for the fresh fish but all I felt while eating was is the guy next to me gonna step on my LV purse since I have to put it on the floor cuz I had NO room! I would still come back to try the other rolls since they do sound pretty good.

**For the people that find me weird for taking pictures of everything I eat, it actually helps because they charged us for 2 Rainbow rolls..**
author: Juliane N.

description:
Was nearby Dolores Park and had a sudden craving for some sushi. The closest and best rated spot was Sushi Time, located in the heart of Castro and Market. 

This place is hidden in between buildings, right past a tattoo shop and a GNC type store. Very small and intimate place to dine. 

First off, if you are looking for bento boxes with the usual miso soup and a choice of meat, this is not the place. They specialize in specialty sushi rolls.

I tried the Astro and Dragon roll. Astro was actually pretty good. I don't remember exactly what was in it. But WOW. I've had many dragon rolls in my lifetime, but this stood out from all the others. This was the freshest, yummiest dragon roll ever. The crab meat had a bit of a buttery taste to it. The avocado, unagi, rice was soooooooo money. 

They also have $4 happy hour rolls and sake/beer. It starts at 5PM when they open until 6PM.
author: Chris E.

description:
"What do you want for dinner?"
"I don't know..how about japanese?"
"Amici's?"
"Japanese?"
"Amici's?"
"Japanese?"
"Okay."
"WoohoO! ^_^" (I turn manga when this happens)

Zaoh was closed. So in comes the power of yelp and m3h 1337 skillz of t3h haxx0rz--and I find Sushi Time. 

Turns out, no delivery. No problem, I have a CAR! TAH DAHHHH (I'm really excited about this because I haven't had a car for like, a year). So we ordered edamame, the Kenchin Miso Soup, Mango roll with avocado and cucumber, Maguro nigiri, the Barbie roll, and Crunchy roll.

The maguro was super fresh and tasty, and my favourite was the Crunchy roll. I've never had BBQ eel before, so this was an interesting take on flavor that totally appealed to me. The kenchin miso soup was also super delicious, I highly recommend it instead of just plain ole miso. When we went inside to pick it up, it was such a SMALL space, but so intricately decorated with trinkets that we decided we would be back for a sit down dinner.

Also, their wasabi IS hot. If it isn't, it probably just means you hardly put any on there, and so your next decision SHOULD NOT be to put a crapload on your piece of sashimi. If you make that decision, be prepared for the consequences and me laughing at you.

...I mean WITH you. That's what I meant.

Just sayin.

Oh and I saw Heat! Like, a few years too late. But why was that woman so attracted to Robert De Niro?? He's not George Clooney, so come on. 

WTF.

(this review was brought to you by Jaime's PMS)
author: Jaime L.

description:
I'm a big fan of Sushi Time. I came here for dinner on a Saturday night and had a great experience. The pro's: Food, Service, Value, and Environment. The con's: Wait times, parking, and limited seating. 

Pro:
Food/Value: We ordered some one off pieces of nigiri, and Sushi Combo B, which I thought was a great value. Overall I was really surprised by how delicious the food was and how reasonable the prices were overall. You'll find other sushi places that are a lot over the top and will charge you a lot more but Sushi Time does a good job of giving you excellent food at a great price. 

Service: Our server was very prompt and friendly. Excellent Service. 

Environment: I listed environment as a pro and a con because on the one hand Sushi Time has a great fun/light environment but on the other hand the seating is extremely limited and cannot host large parties. I've never been to Japan but I kept feeling that Sushi Time was plucked from the streets of Tokyo and dropped in Castro. 

Cons: 
Wait Times/Limited Seating: Since the seating is so limited I could imagine people experience long wait times. We got really lucky and just walked in but got seating in under 15 mins. We must've just hit the right spot because the dinner rush had arrived right behind us. 

Parking: Sushi time doesn't have a parking lot of their own but you can find parking in the residential neighborhoods on the other side of Market street.
author: Ken C.

description: Sushi Time happy hour is the shortest happy hour of all time, but if you're in the Castro between five and six, it's not to be missed. While the restaurant is mostly empty, the sunshine streaming through the hand-wallpapered windows highlights the extremely cute and small decorating. The sushi is nice and cheap at $4.50 a roll, but the atmosphere is what really makes it.
author: Maggie G.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE. 

I'll sum it up:
Small
Adorable
Good music
Great ambiance
GREAT sushi
Affordable
HIGHLY recommend!

Great for:
Happy Hour
Casual dates
Dinner with friends
author: Michelle G.

description:
Eating sushi with my (sushi)dreamboat is one of lifes greatest pleasures. And as sushi is so often overrated, overpriced, and underperfoming on my tastebuds, I am constantly being "forced" to try new places. Enter iPhone, yelp, castro. Sushi TIME!

Got the Astro Boy (mm), Barbie Roll (MMM), White Tuna Nigiri (so buttery smooth, delightful with Ponzu), and another one that I can't remember but had mango and scallop, also delish.

Ugh, can't wait to eat here again.

Word to the wise (?), this place is super tiny, with about 6 2/3 tables running along the left side of the restaurant, and a bar for about 6-7 people. So be prepared for a cozy atmosphere. Lulz at the lesbian conversation, sitting next to me. 

"I don't know HOW to be a woman." GURRRRRRRLLLL
author: Gaggan B.

description:
Fish is fresh. 
Sushi is really tasty and unique flavors.
Service is great and food making was timely!
Prices affordable.
Very small place, but great ambiance.

If you want good, FRESH sushi, in a small intimate environment, come to Sushi Time. Only AFTER ordering 6+ of the special rolls for 3 people, and exclaiming, "Damn that's a lot of rolls. It MUST be sushi time" did I realize the name connection. 

Small touches I ENJOYED:
- When you order sake at your table, they bring a large basket filled w/different types of sake cup designs and ask you to "Choose your cups." I really appreciated the idea of giving diners a CHOICE of which cups they personally liked and wanted to use, no matter how insignificant the decision.
- My check came in a small , cute, wooden box.
- The final credit card bill came in another wooden plate of similar texture.

It's the small things that make a restaurant stand out :)
author: Gina R.

description: Go! Its the best sushi place I've had in a while simple, clean, fresh flavors.  The fish just melted in your mouth. The rolls are simple as in not a ton of different fishes in every roll but good amount of ever singular kind--more fish than rice. Place is small and cozy and gets filled fast d/t very small seating. Its inside this indoor shopping center which is weird.  Check it out!
author: A V.

description:
Delicious sushi in a really cute place! Our first sushi place since moving to San Francisco, and we are hooked - it's bound to become a staple. Great for a date, or a quick dinner alike.

Beyond great sushi, these are good people: my girlfriend left her purse here - with several hundred dollars of cash in it - and forgot about it for two days, and when we finally remembered they had it ready for us, all intact and untouched!
author: John R.

description: Some of the best sushi in SF.  Get your name on the list and head over to Destino for cocktails.  Guaranteed good night out!
author: Liz C.

description:
My favorite affordable sushi in the city own run by real Japanese.

it just feel like you are in japan in this little tiny tube room. the service is perfect, the food is just like you want. they have a big selection of all sort of sushi and always improve their menu with new recipes.

just writing about it makes me hungry, I want to go back there again and again!
author: Titoconsume f.

description:
Finally tried this place after years of walking by and wondering...and so glad we did.  It's now high on my list of favorite sushi spots in the City.

Cozy, "hole-in-the-wall" atmosphere and friendly service, combined with delicious sushi at good prices.  There was a bit of a wait, but they take your cell phone number and call so you can roam the neighborhood while waiting.  We especially loved the unagi and walu nigiri, and tai carpaccio.  We'll definitely be back to try more.
author: John R.

description: Incredibly mediocre Japanese food without the hospitality.
author: Sushi S.

description:
It's been a while since I've been to Sushi Time - almost one year if I recall correctly.  A bit shocking since this is our most regularly visited restaurant in the neighborhood.  So I was pretty excited when we finally made plans to come back.  I wasn't sure what to expect since the recent feature in Yelp.  The place is small and a lot of traffic can cause changes.

1) They don't take reservations anymore - not a big deal

2) They don't carry any more of my favorite Udon noodles, which were just as good as the special rolls - much sadness on my part

3) Special Rolls were still good - love the barbie and crunchy

4) Other Rolls were disappointing - made kind of sloppily, what happened?

I did notice they have a new sushi chef and maybe that's why the quality of the workmanship isn't where it used to be.

But I'm not sure if this is one of my favorite go-to restaurants anymore - boohoo!
author: Jean K.

description:
The best-tasting part of my meal was the tap water.

One of the worst sushi experiences I've ever had.  Can't begin to understand how this place has such high reviews.

The room is terrible -- this strange tube-like space that seems like it was added to a mall as an afterthought.  You'll feel like you're eating sushi in a mobile home.

The service was good, it was just everything else that was terrible.
author: David L.

description:
I was so close to giving this place 4 stars. The place is tiny, with an awesome decor, and has a very personal feel to it. The sushi was fresh, tasted good, and their pricing is reasonable.

Too bad the service was anything but personal.  Our waiter was somewhat rude, hasty, and brought out some of our sushi a good 15 minutes before the next set of rolls.. which is FINE i guess, but not particularly enticing, and a little weird considering we weren't eating family style, so some people at our table had to watch us eat until they got their food, when it was our turn to watch them eat.

My other minor complaints are that the spicy scallop roll was NOT spicy in the least.  And, sushi came without any pickled ginger and I had to ask for some. What kind of sushi joint doesn't automatically give you ginger?

Anyways- I'd go back. Sushi was solid and fresh, the wait was minimal for a Tuesday night, and the overall vibe is cute.
author: Roxane W.

description:
Japan, oh Japan! If I hadn't found Sushi Time on Yelp when I was browsing for Sushi in the Castro last year, I would have missed so many amazing "happy hours" here! And I use that term "Happy Hour" lightly, as this place is as big as a can of sardines, and if you're not here early, you may be packed in it like one!

Sushi Time offers an extensive happy hour menu with very reasonable deals. It's perfect for the post-work food-binge and talk-purge. I only wish the HH last longer, although I imagine that would be bad for business! 

Give this place a try, and you'll be pleasantly surprised. It's my #1 HH and Sushi Special joint in the City!
Note: The wait can get crazy so arrive early or call ahead of time to gauge.
author: Andrew C.

description:
It was a thursday night and I was exhausted from work.  My brother wanted to grab sushi.  I can never say no to sushi, but this night I almost did because I was so tired!.  He told me he use to go here once a week and i won't regret it!

We ordered:
-san salad: includes seaweed salad, asparagus, and tofu salad.  I didn't think it was too special, but it was very refreshing!
- barbie roll: crab, avocado, salmon, and the lemon made the roll very refreshing!
-astro boy roll: spicy scallop and mango! This was my FAVORITE roll.  It was SO tasty!
-spicy scallop hand roll: This sold me!  I never really loved raw scallops, but man it left me wanting another roll! this is a MUST try!
- hotate-raw scallops...SO GOOOOODDDD!!!
-shiromaguro: White tuna.  Very different than the regular raw pink tuna.  It was very buttery!
-sake: fresh salmon
- maguro: red tuna

the tataki...and the raw scallops in the end..SOLD ME!  I can't wait to share this very special hole in the wall with someone.  I've never had fish so fresh!  It's a must try!!.. MUST!
author: Joanne H.

description:
You must visit Underground Sushi Time!  I love the intimacy of this restaurant, the service, and most of all the food.  

I found this place on my last trip to San Francisco -- it was just a fluke.  But last weekend I made sure to stop in for some rolls and hot apricot tea.  It's so different from the noisy sushi restaurants in Sacramento. This place is quiet and clean and it just has a good vibe.

If want a place for an intimate dinner at an affordable price, this place is worth a stop.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Only draw back is that I can't bring more friends in here for a group dinner. 

I love the underground  aspect, I feel like this is my little hideaway. 
The sushi has always been really decent, the rolls have been creative and spot on, and the service is good. 

It's been a great casual date spot next to my house for years now. No distractions, good prices.
author: Tasha A.

description: Probably the best sushi I've had in SF. Definitely the best sushi I've had in the Castro. The space is tucked down a flight of stairs from Market (level with 16th if you enter from the back of the building). It's small, but the acoustics are surprisingly and it's incredibly easy to hear the person(s) across from you. Best roll hands-down: Barbie.
author: Zach N.

description:
An average place for sushi.  Fish was ok fresh.  Sushi rice was the main downfall... over-seasoned with vinegar, and the rice was too stiff. 

My hamachi was actually decent, but my friends were not overly impressed by the rolls or sushi.

Small place with cosy seating. I didn't like the funny smell in the restaurant - just gives me a sneaking suspicion that either the place was not completely clean or some fish had overstayed their time.

Overall, passable as a reasonably priced neighborhood joint, but not somewhere I look forward to revisiting.
author: Thomas L.

description:
Stellar little sushi place that may become my "in SF" favorite because a) its close to where I live & b) the prices are reasonable.

We showed up on the early side, around 6:30, so I can't comment on the wait during peak times, but we were able to walk right in and get a seat at the sushi bar.

While we were figuring out our order from the fresh fish of the day, we decided to get a small carafe of sake.  After we ordered, the waiter came back with a box of sake glasses that looks like something you might find at a garage sale.  Some glasses were in a matched set, but others were loners: single glasses that were unique and interesting, but did not have a mate.  This was a very charming way to start off dinner at this hidden gem.

After making our selections of the fishes we would devour, the sushi chef offered up his suggestions for what was best that day, and even suggested we upgrade our hamachi to the otoro he had in that day for $1 more.  $1 more?!?!?  I'm used to paying upwards of $10-20 for two portions of otoro at the fancy sushi joints in the city.  But here, we weren't paying much more than the typical sushi prices!

Once the nigiri was gone, we moved on to other interesting concoctions like the rolls and a hamachi collar.  Now, I'm used to slightly pungent, fishy tasting collar, but this one was spectacular and cooked perfectly.  The only, minor problem with the preparation was the lack of a crispy skin, which i come to expect from a good collar.  However, in this case, cooking the skin to crispy texture could have impacted the perfectly cooked nature of the fish meat itself.

Finally, the staff couldn't have been more polite and accommodating.  They were always there and waiting for our next request, and served everything with a smile.

I'd recommend this place to any of my sushi-loving friends, but just don't pack it so much I can't get my seat at the bar. ;)
author: Brian F.

description: What I like about this spot is that the sushi is incredibly fresh. Many of these sushi places are similar but I can see the quality. I would try.
author: Richard R.

description: Delicious and fresh, perfectly portioned. The spicy yellowtail is outrageously good. Reasonably priced. If there's a wait, I don't mind--I just head to the bookstore upstairs.
author: Kent L.

description: Freshest fish I ever had in my sushi. Wonderful place with a very nice atmosphere. A bit hard to find but definitely worth those minutes you'll spend looking for it.
author: Misha C.

description: Sushi time is a cute little venue with good food, decent prices and an attentive staff.  I thoroughly enjoyed my meal there and will definitely be back sometime soon.
author: Ben N.

description:
Definitely a must for Happy Hour (5pm-630pm).  We came here on a Monday and were practically the only ones there, but it was cute, dimly lit, and cozy.  At first, we were worried because the sign outside made it seem shady.. but as we descended down the stairs off of Market, we were warmly greeted and settled in quite nicely.

We shared a large hot sake for $4 and got 3 of the $4 rolls (california, alaskan, and spicy tuna).  We appreciated the real crab in the california roll, attested by the presence of a rogue shell piece.  The astroboy roll ($6) was awesome!  I was craving scallops, and the spicy mayo and mango combo of the roll was something I'd never experienced before.  Yummm.
author: Mads M.

description:
I went to this place one month ago.I can't say this is
Japanese quality as perfect,but it was pretty good.recently 
many Korean and Chinese restaurant provide Japanese foods.this
place is not like that.
Although this is tiny,crowded,not Japanese chef and bit expensive,they have good services,customers,no partiality for customers.
I was so happy to eat dinner with my friend at Sushi time.
I think Japanese owner runs this place!!
Absolutely come back here!!thank you!!!!
author: S V.

description: Bomb.com (I wish this didn't auto-link; I'm just trying to make a point). Definitely a hidden gem. Sushi is ridiculously good and not expensive. Hidden location and atmosphere inside make you feel like you've stumbled onto something really special. You can't go wrong with anything on the menu, but if you want something off-the-charts good, get the seared albacore appetizer (a special). It is seriously one of the best sushi items I have ever eaten in any city. Note: this place isn't about frilly rolls drowned in fusion sauces; this is real, really fresh, really delicious sushi, sashimi, nigiri, and rolls.
author: K H.

description:
A friend recommended this place to me, so after many nights of walking by and seeing the cluster of people waiting outside for a table (it's a small, but cute space), I finally got there early enough to grab a seat at the sushi bar. 

First and foremost, this place runs efficiently, so don't think about personal space (I think this makes the spot more "cozy") and the sushi was pretty darn good - however, after looking around, I wish I would have adventured more into some of their more custom rolls. 

I sat next to an older gentleman who had been going there since doors first opened, so if he's been that loyal, then I think I'm going to make an effort to frequent the establishment more often as well.
author: Leslie T.

description:
For this price, you get everything that's worth.

Taste is pretty decent and you can see that they make them with heart. The shrimp Tempura sushi we got were fresh and tasty. It easily became my favourite dish.

Price is decent too. $9.XX for a crunchy roll is a standard price everywhere I guess.

Staff are quite attentive and friendly. We went there during peak hour. There were only 2 servers serving around 30 guests. They were very busy at the time but they still managed to refill water and asked if we were satisfied with our food.

The only complaint: They charge extra for tea ($1.50-2.50 per cup), which is unusual for Japanese restaurants.
author: Mel C.

description:
I love this spot! It's a hidden gem on the ground floor of this complex in the castro. Tiny venue with 5 tables and some seats in front of the sushi bar. 

Everything I've had here is consistently excellent! 

Highly suggest:

san salad - variety of 3 salads
shrimp with veggies gyoza - the wrap is thin and perfect - not too doughy like most places
All the rolls are amazingggg! 

Great service, authentic and great tasting sushi.
author: T J.

description: The Albacore Tuna Tataki and Red Tuna were the BOMB! receommend it for sure
author: Will D.

description:
Fantastic! I don't know that anyone would just happen to see this place from the street as it is tucked away in a small cranny off of market st. But don't be fooled: small size, big taste. They have two excellent sushi chefs and, because the restaurant is small, they serve it up quick and fresh. 

Great place to take 2-3 people. Friendly service, fresh sushi, charming ambience. I'll be going back...
author: Adriel S.

description: Great sushi!! Fresh flavorful and unique combinations. Favorite was the Barbie and the butter fish rolls.
author: Alyssa S.

description:
This place is ok.  I guess it might have been better if I didn't have such high expectations coming in after reading the reviews on yelp.  The reviews are right about the price and and food quality, but I guess the experience was soured a bit from the beginning.  My roommates (party of 3) went to check this place out on a friday night.  When we got there, it was already 9 so we figured the line couldn't be that long.  The place is extremely small and hole in the wale but it does remind me a typical restaurant in Japan..they do an awesome job with the decorations and laid back Japanese decor.  We walked in and the place looked half empty.  There was one couple waiting outside and I couldn't understand why there was a wait when there were so many open tables and they weren't reserved either.  I believe it was the owner who was taking care of the sign up list.  There were 7 table ahead of us and i kept looking around and there were 4 open tables.  All the names had phone numbers next to them.  The hostess explained they needed to call all the 7 numbers first before they could sit us.  I believe this sign up w/ your number and wait for a call when your reservation method is so stupid. It is bad for business...you should never have open tables, especially when it is a friday night and those empty tables could be working on getting turned over.  Instead we saw two more empty seats open up..this was after 15 minutes of waiting outside seeing half the place empty and the entired sushi bar was empty..another 5 mins passed and then they said ..5 more minutes to wait if the tables on the list don't call back.  They really get rid of the calling the sign up sheet system.  We waited 20 minutes for an empty sushi bar...i've never seen such an inefficient system.  They would give the list a call..and wait like 10-15 and if the people didn't show up, they would seat the next.  They should be like everyone other efficient restaurant and call out and if your not in the waiting area...you move to the next on the list.  Stupid rule..kinda soured our experience but but anyways, enough with the bitching and on to the food.

We ordered a crap load of food.  I had the GI Joe, Rainbow roll, San-sald, and Ikura over rice.  The sushi rolls are small but the prices are on the spot.  Many of the rolls are just $5.  The san-salad was one of the better salads I've tried in the city...not a knockout but satisfying.  The fish on the rolls were outstandingly fresh.   The meal all in all was pretty good.  We slapped on a few bears and sakes and the bill came out to be about $140 for 3 guys which included a satisfying round of drinks.  

I would recc this place only for parties of 2 as the place is really small.  I really wasn't that impressed...I'd only go back during happy hour where the food is even cheaper and who can argue with that.  I was quite skeptical at first when I walked in because I was one of only 3 Asians in the restaurant as far as customers go.  I eat out a lot and I know a lot of good places but the asian rule usually is when it comes to asian restaurants is if there are more white people than asians sitting down, then the place can be decently good but not outstanding.  The rule was correct in this case.  I think this place was not bad...the pricing point is what would make me go back but I've had better.  For the same pricing point if not cheaper...but better food (but hole in the wall setting), try Tani's Kitchen in Westlake shopping center.  I'm loyal to that place because I still haven't found a Japanese joint that had such good food for that cheap.
author: Eric H.

description:
Top notch sushi!! The fish was fresh, good presentation and good portions! Barbie roll is the way to go!! 

The place was hard to find because of its hidden location, but this adds to its charm and ambiance!
author: Christopher C.

description: I love this place. It looks like is used to be an old flower shop. They have very fresh fish and you can taste the difference. Too many sushi restaurants have mediocre fish but this is not one of them! The staff is super nice and not too intrusive. It is a nice romantic get-away dinner for not too much damage on your pocket book.
author: Denise L.

description:
At first I was kind of iffy about eating here, but when I tasted the food, OMFG. BOOOOOOMB!

Party of 6. Filled up the sushi bar. Place was kind of small and cramp, but it was alllll good. We ordered California Roll, Tekka Maki, Crunch Roll (twice because it was HELLLLA good), Rainbow Roll, Teddy Bear Roll, and a bunch of other rolls, and everything was DELICIOUS. The waiter made a rude joke, which kind of pissed me off at first, but I was like whatever. Overall, good experience, and definitely good food!!

And if you look at my past reviews, I dine at sushi places a LOT. I rarely give out 5 stars for sushi joints, so if I give this place 5 stars, it's DEFINITELY good!
author: Kim V.

description:
I've been here twice.  Had I rated it the first time, it would have been a 3, BUT, this time we ordered right.  Here are some hints:

1) Order a few Nigiri
2) Ask the waiter exactly what type of roll you want and he will either tell you what it is or have it made.

Will definitely return.
author: Dishar R.

description:
With a name like "Sushi Time" and its underground den location, I wasn't thinking good things about this place at first.

As soon as I walked in I liked it.  It's very small square footage wise, but makes up for it with a lot of personality and a great intimate feel.

As we waited for our sushi, the names of their rolls kept our group laughing and smiling since all of us have the sense of humor of a 5 year old.

The Barbie Roll and Astro Boy Roll were phenomenal!  I scarfed down a few other types of rolls so fast I can't remember what they looked like or were named.
