This is by far the best sushi I have had - Can't wait to go back.
author: Stacy Y.

description:
Decent priced Sushi, tasty rolls, teeny tiny spot. Love the choose your own saki glass from the collection in the wood box. Service was overwhelmed but courteous!

Definitely a cool place to check out if you like eating sushi underground (almost like being a submarine except all the fish is dead and atop rice).
author: Nikki M.

description:
I visited Sushi time for the first time last week with some friends from out of town. I was blown away by:

1) The restaurant. The small cozy feel of the restaurant makes you feel like you are in a sushi bar in the back alleys of Shibuya.

2) The Nigiri Sushi. DY-NO-MITE. The Hamachi melted in my mouth. Insanely fresh.

3) The Vegetarian Sushi: Shitake Mushroom roll. Mango, Avocado and Cucumber roll. Very tasty, I will definitely bring my Veggie friends when they visit from Texas :)

4) Mango and Green tea Mochi - Only the Hamachi melts in your mouth faster!!!

5) Price - tres resonable.

I will be back soooooooon!
author: Sahir S.

description:
I figured my first Yelp review should be for one of my most favorite restaurants of all time - Sushi Time!

It's not fancy pants. It's more of a get-friendly-with-your-neighbor's-elbow kind of joint, but I LOVE it. Love the lack of space. Love the Japanese chefs and the fresh fish that melts in my mouth. Out of obligation, I keep trying "other sushi places" in the hopes of topping Sushi Time. I'm pretty critical when it comes to this stuff (in all things, actually) - and Sushi Time is still my #1.

So, until I leave San Francisco, I will keep returning to Sushi Time. 

P.S. Try the baked mussels... they are heavenly!
author: Anna H.

description:
I love this TINY sushi spot in the city.
Its a little hard to find which is a good thing because it hasn't become trendy like some spots in the city. They serve simple but fresh sushi which is a good combination and the prices are super cheap.

Be aware though that if you are bringing people other than yourself, your whole party has to be present to be seated. A little weird but necessary when you notice how small this place is. 

Great happy hour as well...highly recommended!
author: Brenda I.

description:
Tiny, tasty and CUTE.

The food here is pretty decent. Most of what I've ordered and eaten have left me happy and satisfied. But I think what really makes me really adore this place is it's location and decor. Squished little underground room. The charm is irresistible.

Tried out the happy hour for the first time a couple days ago and was quite thrilled. There was foods aplenty, drinks aplenty, and still monies aplenty in my wallet. Between the two of us I think we ordered 6 rolls, some sashimi, uni nigiri, and 2 large sakes (I love that they let you pick out your own sake cups from this basket filled with cute mismatched cups). All for about $60 including tax and tip. I was nearly too full to walk afterwards. That is a fantastic sign.
author: Jennifer N.

description:
Had dinner last night w my daughter and we both loved their food. The Albacore tataki
was divine. I recommend having it with their perfectly cold Asahi beer. For sure we will be back!
author: Katarine Q.

description: Thus far, my favorite sushi place in the city. Yes, it's a little small, hard to find, and they won't seat you until all of your party is present, but the food is divine. Order the hot sake, and they present you with a basketful of cute little sake cups. You choose your sake cup. How delightful! Being from an island, I've had my fair share of good sushi, and a lot of bad sushi. I really enjoyed the rolls from here.
author: Heidi H.

description:
I would give it a 3.5 if I was allowed.  It's better than 3 but not quite a 4, maybe even a 3.75??

I was looking for a new sushi spot to try and after a Yelp search on my phone, I decided on Sushi Time.  I drove by, saw a sign where I was anticipating a restaurant front window.  I ended up giving up on it because I didn't really trust a random mall-like sushi joint.

A month or so later I was again looking for a new sushi spot.  This time, after reading all the yelp reviews, I decided we'd give it a shot, alley restaurant or not.  I was pleasantly surprised.

It is a quaint spot.  Small, can probably hold 15-20 people.  The fish was fresh and I have to agree that the Astro and Barbie rolls (as suggested by other yelpers) was quite tasty.  The fish is fresh, portion size for nigiri isn't bad.  The rolls aren't giant like some of those big fancy rolls.

The price is really reasonable and that's always nice.  I'm a huge sushi fan and would eat it for every meal if I could afford it.

Overall, I'm glad I tried it.  Don't be fooled or turned off by the location.
author: Becca L.

description:
Man, this place is awesome. and small. really small. I also enjoy the weird downstairs path you have to take to get there. 

You want fresh fish and rolls with weird names? DONE. What about good prices and a friendly staff? SURE THING. 

Spicy walu = awesome
Mango with fish and sushi = delicious

It's basically what everyone else loves about this place that makes it my new favorite place for sushi. no need to talk more about how much i like it. just go there.
author: Young L.

description: This place is definitely one of the best sushi restaurants in town for the value. The Barbie roll is awesome and the sashimi is fresh. The sushi place we used to go to has gone downhill recently. We were glad to find this hidden gem. The ambiance is cool too - it really feels like a hole in the wall place that you might find in Japan.
author: Aaron P.

description:
Roll's are only 5 maki -- not a standard 8. So even at happy hour, 5 maki is $1.20.

Just sayin'...
author: Alex M.

description:
Tried for the first time yesterday, just plain awesome. Great quality fish (started out with the sashimi six), reasonably creative rolls, and a friendly staff in a cozy little hole in a shopping center. 
I had the spicy hamachi and the eel with mango, both were excellent, with a good mix of textures, fresh ingredients and great rice with a solid hint of vinegar (the way I like my sushi rice). 
I'll be back, especially since we were able to get right in, as opposed to the wait for sushi zone, which we abandoned after 45 minutes (and had another hour to go). Pleasantly diverse sake selection and warming miso too. It was good enough that we got "Dessert Nigiri" so we could stay longer.  
Go if you like: Fun atmosphere, good sushi
Don't if: you like your sushi joint extra minimalist, you enjoy waiting
author: Casey J.

description:
This is my favorite sushi place in San Francisco.  It's tucked underground a few paces from Books, Inc. and Lime.  What I love to order at this this cozy place is:

1. Astro boy (scallops)
2. Tuna tartare (love it with the avacados)
3. Hamachi kama (grilled yellow tail tuna collar)
4. Uni (sea urchin)

The service here is usually spot on and the waiters and chefs are friendly.  I wouldn't recommend coming here during prime dinner hours with a large group (more than 4).  It will be hard to find a table.  Also, don't come here if you are hoping to have a private heart to heart with someone.  The tables are pretty close together.  Otherwise, I love, love this sushi place!
author: Thang H.

description: This place is hidden away downstairs and very intimate.  It feels like a secret sushi spot.  Not the very best but pretty good sushi. The roll with mango and avocado with spicy scallop  is very good.  I usually don't like scallop sushi at all but this was delicious!!! I'll be back.
author: Julie B.

description:
Had dinner here on Friday and I still can't stop thinking about it!

Butterfish (walu) sashimi was our starter and a definite highlight. Service was extremely attentive. If you order sake, they have you pick out your own sake cup out of a basket!  We had the butterfish, the san salad, the Barbie Roll (awesome!) and nigiri cuts of sake, maguro & unagi. We then ordered the Astro Boy Roll to finish.  It was sweet and a great way to finish off our dinner. 

This small, affordable, casual yet not cramped sushi bar is an absolute find.  I greatly recommend it and cannot wait to go back.
author: Jessie S.

description:
This is a great find!

Lots of interesting specialty rolls. My friend and I had the Barbie Roll, the Teddy Bear Roll and the Spicy Yellowtail. All were delicious and beautiful to look at. I'd definitely go back.
author: Shayna Y.

description:
A date place this is not; this is a good, inexpensive hole in the wall that serves it up quick and tasty.  Went here last night (Tuesday) and we were seated immediately.  The fish was fresh.  The ambience is simple and downscale, and the seating arrangement is very tight.

Sushi Time's neither exceptional nor unique, but it was friendly and overall worth visiting if you're a neighborhood local.  Still, there are dozens of better options if you're mobile.
author: Matt S.

description:
The food is probably 2 to 2 1/2 stars but their service was awesome so I guess i would have to round it up.  Warakubune was closed so I had to check our Iphone to see what was around there.  Sushi Time here we come.  Sarah D and I went searching for the well hidden underground restaurant on Market and 16th.  This place is well hidden all the way in the back of this commercial complex.  I heard great things about this place but it just didn't do it for us.

We had:

Albacore Tataki (It was good......probably a 4 star)
Hamachi Kama (good but have had a lot better.....shimo, sakabune on post, and goemon)
hamachi and salmon sashimi ( it was ok)
astro boy roll ( I didn't like this at all........spicy scallop and cucumber with mango roll)
barbie roll (this is probably their signature dish crab avacado salmon with lemon)
california roll (you know me and california roll...........I always have to order it.............it's ok)

47 dollars

Not bad................If you ae into rolls then this is the place for you.
author: jason g.

description:
I love this place!
The fish was fresh and good. 
We ordered the tuna tartare that is mixed with chunks of avacado... delicious 
The snapper special was OUT OF THIS WORLD! I still don't know what it was other than raw snapper in some sort of super sour oil/sauce. 
Sake was brought to the table with a wooden box filled with little sake cups (all different) for you to choose from.
The seaweed salad was crunchy and savory.
We ordered many rolls with raw fish and with cooked fish and they were all very tasty.
The albacore sashimi was melt-in-your-mouth perfection!
It's tiny and its off the street in an underground strip mall and it's open til 10:30
I will go back as soon as the opportunity presents itself. Love it!!!
author: Edi B.

description: LOVE this place.  I can't believe I've never seen it before last week!!  Was super fresh, yummy, cozy and just the perfect place for a cold winter night.  Staff was friendly, attentive and kinda nerdy sexy:)
author: Jeffrey B.

description:
I wasn't even a huge fan of sushi before Sushi Time!

I was the -- I-dont-eat-sashimi, I'll-have-the-crunchy-catapillar-roll, ramen-favoring Japanese food eater. However, upon gracing my humble taste buds with the delectable rolls here, I've thus been converted. 

Favorites: Barbie roll, tuna tartar, Astro Boy roll, any of the cold sakes.

Watch out though, it gets crowded around dinner time and the place is tiny. Also, your entire party must be present to be seated. Bonus: you can put your name down and they'll give you a ring while you're perusing the Castro shops on Market.
author: Vicki T.

description: My go-to favorite sushi place. What really makes this place great is the location. Me and my friends sometimes call this place "underground sushi" because it's almost build like a separate little house inside a larger room. Really cozy, pretty intimate and really good food. The fish is excellent.
author: Rasmus A.

description:
What an amazing little hidden Gem in the Castro!  I have been hearing about this place for years, and finally  took a chance and went on down to this cozy lil sushi spot.

WOW! My mouth is still watering thinking about this roll they serve called the "Barbie Roll"... I haven't been there in 3 days, and it's all I can think about.   I tried their "rainbow roll" and it's definitely more fresh than the other 2 sushi joints in the castro!  Super reasonably priced and EXCELLENT Sushi!

HIGHLY RECOMMEND!
author: Amie B.

description:
Sushi Time is pretty darn good, but a bit hard to find if you are new to the city. After spending an afternoon apartment searching Tom and I decided to unwind in the neighborhood known as the Castro. We were in the mood for sushi per our usual cravings. Sushi Time was brought to our attention courtesy of Tom's NFT San Francisco iPhone application. We were wandering around SOMA and decided to check out sushi reviews near us. Sushi Time was high up on the list, so the hunt for this gem began.

Once we finally found the restaurant in the basement of a mini-shopping area off Market, we were pleasantly surprised. This extremely small restaurant had a nice, cozy vibe and great service. Although, we were not at all impressed with the sushi presentation--we did love one item off the delicacy menu. The tuna and avocado tarter is fantastic! Maybe we were a bit in awe of the grade of seafood, possibly the sake we had to celebrate our move, or we were just really hungry--whatever it was, I was blown away by this dish. Give this place a whirl whenever you are in SF and in the mood for cheap sushi!
author: Nichole P.

description:
this tiny restaurant is tucked away below the streets of castro.  the place is covered wall to wall with stuff.  whether its fabric or hanging paper decorations.  there isnt much space.

service is simple and very quick.  if you order sake they bring around a basket with different cups.  ive seen this somewhere else, i cant remember where.

the people at the sushi bar speak cantonese. the sushi is super fresh.  the ikura and also tobiko were super cold.  tamago was good.  we had the walu sashimi and the pieces were suprisingly super thick.  i said super a lot.

this is one japanese restaurant that wont leave you super hungry.

they charge for tea though
author: claudia y.

description:
Prices are low, food is decent.  There's nothing terribly special about this place.  The menu was reasonably well-executed but didn't make a huge impression.  

After reading the other reviews, we really felt it would be a worthwhile trip across town to try this place.  Should have just run to the sushi restaurant down the street.  

Though the service was completely acceptable, the restaurant is very small, has a hole-in-the-wall feeling and is lacking in any ambience whatsoever.
author: Lindsay N.

description:
I actually found this place, courtesy of other yelp-ers. And boy, am I glad I was warned of the potential sketch factor. This place is below ground level - in a mall of sorts. The only advertisement you see for it is one of those folding street signs like they use for barber shops and open houses.

The place is TINY. No joke. Don't bother coming here if you have more than 4 people. The food was tasty and the prices were great (all things considered), but no 5-star rating due to the UNBELIEVABLY SLOW service. Seriously. I aged about 5 years in there.

I'd probably go back again, but maybe at an off-time.
author: Anna G.

description:
The Sushi Time is a strange and curious animal.  It's small size means tight seating for it's inhabitants.

The beast's restrooms are located outside it's main cavity.  Patrons are issued a key on a big stick.  

Spotting The Sushi Time is difficult.  It is nuzzled in a shopping center, so you must walk down a small flight of stares to find him.  It's location is well documented.

Sushi Time, tick, tick, tock.  ashai bee-ru oh ko-de saw!
author: Jay B.

description:
It's a small miracle that despite the stellar Yelp reviews, this casual, itty bitty little sushi factory always has a seat when I need one. Tucked into the subterranean bottom floor of a random building in the plaza, you'll find its photo next to "hidden gem" in Merriam Webster cross-listed under "affordable eats" and "neighborhood joint". 

Narrow as a boxcar with five tables and a bar, they don't take rezzies so I'd never dream of bringing more than one nomming partner. However, make sure that whomever you choose appreciates a dash of Japanese kitsch with their oh-so-fresh fish. Oh, and $5.50 hot sake. 

Like Ivy R says, "Sushi Time is one of my favorite times of day."

Kampai!
author: Ligaya T.

description: In a little cave down a set of stairs is this hidden gem. Welcoming you into this cozy little tunnel are some of the nicest people around. On the front of the menu is a unique selection of teas (all good). The nigiri is nice and fresh and the selection of special rolls are more than delicious. They come bite sized (will not crumble all over your lap) and aptly named (Hello Kitty roll, GI Joe roll, Astro Boy roll). Try 'em all!
author: Z L.

description:
Man... After going to the gym we were super excited about Warakubune only to find out that it closes on Mon and Tues! 

Luckily my gfs heard about sushi time before. 
Now peeps! Beware! It may look sketch and low quality from the outside but it is the PERFECT HOLE IN THE WALL! 
You come down and here is this cute little place. Everything comes from the sushi-man directly (cause we know that some sushi places makes mexicans cook their stuff LOL) 

Everything is very well-priced and the waiter is super friendly. He always has this BIG friendly smile on his face even when we came around 9 PM. 

Ordered the shiro maguro, tuna and avocado appetizer, and spicy salmon and everything was amazing! SUPER fresh, delicious, and.... OHHHH. 

COME. COME HERE SAN FRANCISCO! you'll LOVE it!
it's a good place to come to if you wanna impress somebody. 
makes you feel like you know all the secret places in SF. LOL
author: Miss C.

description: They use a thin layer of rice for their sushi. I love it!
author: Regan T.

description: I've been in search of a delicious, fresh, sushi place in the city.  This place is bomb.  It's very intimate so there's often a wait but it's worth the wait.  The special rolls are so good the Walu Roll & the Zuke are my favorites.  I love this little melt in your mouth sushi place
author: Heather K.

description:
3.75 stars

I came for happy hour on Tuesday. However, because this place is small, they don't seat until the entire party has arrived. We got seating at 6:25, 5 min before the end of happy hour, but they still let us order off of the happy hour menu.

FOOD: I had the Sushi Combo B. Regularly, it comes with miso soup, salad, 7pc. nigiri (tuna, salmon, yellowtail, albacore, white fish, shrimp, egg), and 5pc. spicy tuna. For an extra 50 cents during happy hour, you get a small sake or ice cream. I also had their smoked salmon nigiri. 

Their nigiri was okay. Their cuts weren't stingy, but they weren't overly generous either. They put wasabi under the fish. I wished they put more, and used more potent stuff, but I guess they gotta appeal to the masses. White fish? I didn't know what it was, but it had a good texture. Their smoked sake was good, but it can't compare to Sushi Sho's (TRY the smoked salmon after the regular). The spicy tuna was weird...

SERVICE: The waiters were great -- very polite and accommodating. We came in a group, 2 stag, 2 couples. They knew to ask if we wanted separate bills. The food came out, pretty much continuously. Nobody was left w/o food for long. Also, these guys came to fill up my cup of tea/water every time I running low. I drink a lot, and they come justintime. Merveilleuse et magnifique!

GROUPS: Came w/6. Seating right away at 6:25. We left at around 8, but there was always space enough for a party of 4. Might be iffy when things get busy. 

NOTES: Their nigiri is decent for a fair price. Def come again when in area. Try the stuff on their chalkboard/ask for specialties. Not super hard to find, but you gotta be trying.. and on foot. Parking is OKAY -- found parking a block away into the residential zone.
author: Stanley L.

description:
Obscure location. This sushi place is inside a shopping arcade and I didn't even realize there were shopping arcades in SF. Strolling in, I was thinking more "WTF, where are we going?" then "sweet what a cool place". Once inside though, you get a feel for this very tiny sushi joint.

Service is prompt and the menu is, well, typical. Sushi's, sashimi's and hand rolls, oh my. Our party of 3 pretty much went bonkers with the ordering. Overall, everything was delicious although I would say the portions are small - but really, what sushi joint serves huge portions? It's definitely a no frills restaurant though which, after all the posers and schmancy-ness this city sees, is always welcome when out on a weekday. And who doesn't love techno music (let me just say, techno NKOTB remix) bumping in your ear while chowing down on a piece of tamago?

In the end, it's another commendable sushi joint to hit up when you're around this part of town.
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description:
This is a tiny place that has about 5 tables total and a bar that seats 7 or so. Once inside, it feels like it could be the local sushi joint somewhere in  my hometown (in Japan). 
Nothing fancy, just plain old good food. 
The chefs are all Japanese, even if the servers aren't (not a problem at all, just a fact :))

They use really great fresh fish, and you can tell in every roll and nigiri you order. 

I haven't established a favorite roll yet, but you can't go wrong with the happy hour rolls at happy hour prices (~$4). But actually, most of the rolls aren't too expensive to begin with ($5-9 on average). I do really appreciate that even their happy hour rolls don't try to fatten the sushi roll up with rice-- they have a great ratio of fish, etc to rice.
The spicy walu is really good-- the butter fish is so tasty!

The seaweed salad here is delicious and it's one of the biggest portions I've ever been served in a restaurant!
author: Saori E.

description: Wow, this place is tiny! The food was good, even though I'm not a big sushi fan. I try to eat at sushi places that offer numerous cooked sushi options. If you're like me, this is NOT the place to go. Almost the entire sushi menu consists of raw seafood. Aside from that, the ambiance was great. Definitely a spot to hit up if you're on a date. Don't come here with a big party unless you're willing to sit at the bar.
author: Erica F.

description:
Hidden away below Market lies a little sushi place called Sushi Time. The husband and I checked it out for happy hour and were pleasantly surprised by the quality of fish.

The spicy tuna roll has got to be one of the best I've ever eaten.  Seriously. It was fresh and the tuna felt like it wasn't just the leftovers masked with mayo and sirachi and drowning in rice.  There was plenty of green onion and pea sprouts in it and was presently beautifully. Just $4 during happy hour! 

It is one of those places that  is in between the hyper authentic and super Americanized scale. They have the guilty pleasure of spicy tuna rolls, but also have fantastic nigiri pieces. 

I didn't care for the speed racer roll . . . what was I thinking ordering mango, tuna, and tobiko together? Eeeek.

Everything with the ginger and scallion placed on top was fantastic!!!!
author: Tina P.

description: Great little dive downstairs of what looks like a strip mall on Market.  The sushi is fresh, the rolls decent (nothing that will blow your mind), and the prices are reasonable.  Great place to bring a friend from out of town and try and show off your knowledge of hole-in-the-wall cuisine.  All of the seating in this restaurant is 2-tops and a sushi bar amounting to MAYBE 40 seats at the most so my advice - don't show up at 6pm with a large group expecting to be seated before the end of dinner service.  Other than that, you're good to go!
author: Sean H.

description: I have seen this little Sushi restaurant for years and since we love sushi we finally tried it.  Loved this little trailer size sushi place, very warm and cozy, nice lighting and little trinkets hanging everywhere.  I can imagine this is what the sushi places in Tokyo might be like.  This is nexpensive as far as sushie goes and all the sashimi was very fresh, great texture and very flavorful.  The rolls were tastey also and had fun names.  This will be our new local.  We have been there twice  in the last month already.  Surpisingly busy the last time I was there within an hour of closing time.  Service was very friendly and efficient also.  Loved the miso and tea was excellent.
author: Kevin D.

description: Nice hidden place. Good and cheap sushi! Must go back
author: Pierre L.

description:
It's a cute little place that's staffed by Japanese (not Korean or Chinese) folks, so you know it's authentic.  The decor's adorable, but let me repeat:  this place is LITTLE.  By little, I mean SMALL. By small, I mean CRAMPED.  This is a sushi place for Little Bear and Goldilocks--Papa Bear and Mama Bear would not fit in here too comfortably without feeling like the roof might collapse on them.  

Okay, maybe I'm exaggerating a bit.  After all, this is apparently the average size of sushi places in Japan.  So I guess if you want a true Japanese sushi experience, Sushi Time is the place to be.  

Quality of fish is average, but if you go during Happy Hour (5 - 6:30), you're only paying $4/roll (select rolls), and $2/sake!
author: Yvonne P.

description:
Sushi Time is one of the best bargains in San Francisco to get good sushi and sashimi for a reasonable price. And you real bargain hounds (me say Woof!) will love the happy hours they have for $3 sake and $3 beers.

I know I like the food when I eat too much and drink too much. 

It happened here.
author: Kyle B.

description:
Owner Masa-san has a hidden gem on his hands here.  This is by no means the best sushi restaurant I've been to, but it is one of the most comfortable, perhaps even lovable.  The space is puny, with four or five 2-person tables and a sushi bar that seats about 7 or 8.  It's all laid out in one rectangular room.  What you see when you walk in is what you get.

Masa-san himself is a friendly man -- an unpretentious cast member in his own little play.  He works with a small handful of dedicated, personable, occasionally garrulous sushi chefs, all of whom are quite good.  Because the place is so small, you can watch an itamae prepare sushi from anywhere you sit.

One of the reasons I like this place so much is that Masa-san has a perspective on food, which proves that he cares about the quality of what his diners eat.  For instance, he does not serve toro.  Why not?  Because of its reported mercury levels.  That's fine, although ironic since Masa-san is more interested in what mercury can do to us than in what we do to bluefin tuna by overfishing it.  In any case, he is careful about where he gets his fish, and this care becomes palpable when you bite into a piece of sashimi or nigiri sushi.  Their hamachi and shiromaguro are among some of the best I've had in town.  Although the actual fish selection is smaller than, say, Ebisu, it is consistently good.

Another reason this place is a winner is that you don't have to endure the clumsy ministrations of a waiter.  Just sidle up to the bar and start ordering from your itamae.  You can even tell him how many pieces of sashimi you want instead of being forced to eat 5 or 6 pieces of prix fixe fish.

If you've got to have cooked food at your sushi restaurant, you can't go wrong with the baked mussels.  Unfortunately, one order is too large for one person.  Trust me, I've tried to eat a whole order myself.  They make the baked mussels to order, so enjoy other delicacies while the mussels slowly bake for 20 minutes.

It's a great little date joint, but I wouldn't go here with a party of more than three.
author: Andrew L.

description:
This place is charming in a tumble-down-the-rabbit-hole kind of way.  It's teensy-tiny and tucked away in the back of a small shopping center at the bottom of a staircase.  This is potentially a good thing because the restaurant is about the size of a railroad car... and half of that is taken up by the sushi bar.

This is one restaurant where the awkward location and tiny dining room work in favor of the establishment, though.  The overall feeling was warm and cozy; a mini retreat from the bustling Castro above.

The food was very good and the staff was friendly.  I went with two friends of mine and we tried everything from the Astro Boy roll to the GI Joe roll to usual favorites like Yellow Tail and Spicy Tuna.  The food tasted fresh and was prepared very well (no falling apart on your plate nonsense).  The miso soup was also deeee-lish!

Our trio had 8-10 sushi rolls, salad, soup, and a few beers and our tab only came out to $30 per person with tax and tip.  Not bad!
author: Matt C.

description: I was a little hesitant when I would walk by this place. All you basically see is a sign and its not exactly a fancy sign either, so I assumed it was a sketchy underground hole in the wall. How could they possibly have quality sushi? It is really tiny, but its amazing inside. Great atmosphere and more importantly amazing sushi! I wouldn't recommend coming with more than one or two friends though or you may never find seating. Fast, friendly service and fresh delicious sushi at really reasonable prices.
author: Melissa V.

description:
I'm so STOKED to find this gem!  I just feel bad it has taken me so long.  I suppose it's because it's tucked away a bit; Even when I was trying to find I passed it by, because it's actually inside this indoor courtyard area, and it's tiny!

Small though it may be, they've done a great job to just make it feel cozy and quaint.  Ambiance aside, the big find here is quality of fish.  Sure, plenty of places will offer you sushi, but often you can just tell it's not great fish, or they try and mask it with a bunch of sauce, fruit, cream cheese, and other things.  Not Sushi Time!

We were happy with every dish we ordered, though we'd wished they had some more creative desserts.  The icing on the cake (or, the tobiko on the California roll?) was the very reasonable prices.

I will most definitely be back!
author: Corey C.

description:
The last time I went, I brought my mother and we were enjoying a peaceful dinner out after having not eaten together for years because we had finally been reunited. I found her in Britain and flew her over. It was a magical moment, the slightly dark, cramped trinket filled Japanese sushi capsule was the perfect place for us to find out more about each other. We weren't enjoying the sushi or rolls (they were alright) as much as the ambiance and conversation -- the music was French influenced covers of perfection. The murmur of conversation and occasional laughter from the other tables lent to a friendly atmosphere and made everything just feel good. 

Then out of nowhere a f---ing Pikachu slowly entered through the door and started begging for sushi. We all tried to ignore it but it kept making these horrendous screams while it crawled around the floor. 

I threw couple of pieces of agedashi tofu at it since I didn't care much for them and it jumped on our table for more food. Ugh.

So I b-tch slapped that Pikachu through the cutely decorated/covered glass windows and continued on my magical evening in Japan, er, Castro. Mmm.
author: Charles T.

description: Oh man. Freshest fish I've had in a long time. We had the famous Barbie roll, which is as good as everyone else says it is. Wow. We also started with miso soup and the cucumber seafood salad, which was really delicious too. Also had four other rolls: Rainbow (amazing), Bincho (my fella liked it more than I did, but delicious nonetheless), California (great and packed full of fresh crab with sesame seeds on top), and spicy yellowtail (YUM), and some pieces of nigiri salmon (omg yum). All with hot sake and Sapporo. Was really hard not to go right back to this place three more times on our short visit to SF. But we will be back on the next visit! Also, prices are so right and the service is super friendly and fast. We sat at the sushi bar, and I'm so glad we did.
author: Erin B.

description: When we walked it it felt very tiny, but the atmosphere felt like it was authentic.  They had run out of most of the specials I initially ordered.  The fish was very good though, tasted very fresh.  The salmon was so buttery and easily the best thing I had.  I would definitely recommend this place.
author: James S.

description: The first time I ever came here was for dinner since sushi zone was closed & I'm so glad I found this place. It's hidden and feels like an underground sushi spot (kinda small), but really cute & cozy. I ordered the seaweed salad, miso soup, a bunch of the same rolls twice aka the G.I. Joe roll, astro boy, and barbie roll and they were all good. I prefer coming here for HH though since beer & sake is sooo cheap & it's cute how they let you select your own sake cup from a huge basket of sake cups they have. For HH I'd order the spicy tuna roll, avocado + eel roll, salmon+avocado roll. Simple yet fresh and tasty!
author: Diane L.

description:
- food: very fresh, flavorful
- atmosphere:  tiny, somewhat cramped at the bar
- staff:  adequate
- price: great value

additional info:
- nice, hidden sushi spot
author: J. B.

description:
I am sushi personified.
Not really, it just sounded good.
I take it back I am sushi personified.

I have eaten sushi at many places around the world, or actually most of the time i eat sashimi.

My favourite sushi place in San Francisco is SUSHI ZONE but from times to times when it is impossible to get a table there i have always gone to Sushi time, the fish is fresh, the place is cute, the service is good and the prices are Ok.

The reason  why i give this place only two stars is because of my last visit there.
I was seated at the bar with my husband, we ordered edamame, miso and sashimi combo, we got the fish and it was tasty and fresh, while i was i was eating my food I was also watching the chef preparing rolls and sashimi and to my surprise i witnessed the chef DROP a big piece of tuna on the FLOOR, at first he did not pick it up, good i thought, THEN when he thought i did not see him, he picked it up fast, started cutting and  later on he served it.

I was SHOCKED and for that reason i will not go there again.

Sorry Sushi Time, i did like you guys.
author: cecilia k.

description:
Some say the space is romantic, come on folks lets tell it like it is - this place is small and fairly cramped.  I hope you like the people sitting next to you, because really they are sitting on top of you.  You know when you keep making awkward eye contact with someone, so you try really really hard not to look back, but after a couple of minutes you cant help yourself so you look, and sure enough they are looking at you too?  Well that kept happening with me and the toddler sitting diagonally from me.  Since the kid was no more than 4 years old, it was not that awkward, but I can imagine the same thing happening with an adult.  

On to the food.  There are lots of rolls and nigiri options.  The best thing I had were the homemade shrimp gyoza.  They were clearly made in house and were perfectly crunchy on one side and served piping hot.  The fish seems decent, but only the quality of the salmon blew me away.  We ordered the gyoza, three rolls, carpaccio, and two orders of nigiri and the total was $50.  Kind of steep for what we ordered.  The server was doing his best to keep up with the full restaurant, but he kept swiping my shoulder and elbow each time he brought a dish.  I get the place is small, but it really just felt cramped and uncomfortable.
author: Dana H.

description: I split my sushi love affair between two places. Sushi Time and Ebisu Sushi in the Inner Sunset. Both places are consistently good and won't break the bank. I choose Sushi Time when I'm feeling like a quick dinner with a lovely atmosphere (they're only open after 5pm and have seating for about 20 people).
author: adam m.

description:
This is my favorite sushi place in SF, so far!

I've lived here 6 months and been to about a dozen place in SF and this is my favorite. The quality is really good, and the price is right. My boyfriend and I go and never spend more than $25 each for full bellies. 

The ambiance is really cute, it reminded by boyfriend of Tokyo (he's been, not me). 

One time we did go and the salmon in our roll wasn't the freshest. However, all the other fish was really tasty and delicious. Just ask him what is fresh. I heard a table behind us ask, and he told them of lots of good sounding fish. 

One time the owner even gave us free ice cream! The black sesame ice cream is delish and the green tea is really flavorful.
author: Kealie G.

description: Best sushi in the city. Great date spot.  If you order sake you get to choose your own glass which is a nice touch.
author: Matt S.

description: Cozy atmosphere, fresh fish, good rolls, friendly  staff and their cabernet was decent, I'd go back.
author: Natalie M.

description:
I like this place, and I'll tell you why: it reminds me of Japan.  "But William, shouldn't all Japanese restaurants remind you of Japan?"  Why yes, strange-voice-from-nowhere, they should.  But many don't, really.  This place is just a tiny nook of a small shopping center in the middle of the Castro.  It seats maybe 14 people total, plus like 6 at the sushi bar (not 100% sure about those numbers) but the point is that this place is itty-bitty.  Just like many restaurants in the Land of the Rising Sun that look like they're just a  bedroom-sized space of a larger building, or the living room of some guy's house.  

So yeah it was pretty intimate, and the lighting was dim as well so it's a nice place for a date..  except when Grace and I went there we sat next to this girl who was talking pretty loudly to her friend about some terrible date she went on.  Why do we keep ending up sitting next to these loud people who talk forever to say nothing?  First the voice immodulation guy at Burma Superstar and now this.  

Oh yeah, and we're like 95% sure the table next to us got our sushi that we ordered (the Astro boy and Barbie rolls) because they ordered after us and got theirs way before we did and so for a long time while we were waiting for our sushi we were just watching the girls at that table eat our food.  TORTURE.  

Anyway the rolls were good when they finally brought them to us (oh yeah, the girls next to us ordered 3 rolls and we ordered 2, and the plate they served our rolls on was obviously meant for 3 rolls, so... lets put two and two together here).  What impressed me here the most though was the generous portions of high-quality fish they put on their nigiri sushi.  Oh man the seared white tuna was just so fresh and buttery I wish I was eating it right now.  

The San Salad is good too (3 salads: a tofu and mixed greens, an asparagus and sesame paste, and a seaweed salad).  

Good rolls, great fish, so-so service but all in all I give them 4 stars.
author: William S.

description: Holy sushi! This is the type of find that makes me addicted to yelp reviews. The tea...the fish....the tiney off the main road location all make me love this place. So happy to have found this place. Do not try to come here w a huge group. It's a small cute place. We sat at the sushi bar and enjoyed the personal pots of tea (lots of flavor options). I ordered the yellow tail sushi and it was the best I've had. Melted in my mouth. The salad sampler was also a good pick. We will be back!!!
author: Kara D.

description: I've been going here for years and years. The restaurant is a tiny space very reminiscent of Tokyo.  Masa, the owner, is extremely friendly and welcomes me by name. I'd love it just for the neighborhood feel alone. However, the sushi is really, really good.  Masa's collection of Japanese kitsch is fun to admire. I'm sometimes surprised but never disappointed. Give it a try.
author: Kevin W.

description:
I've only been here once.  It was recently, and I was lead here by friends who live in the Bay who had read a glowing review written by a local foodie.  

It delivers.

Sadly, it blows away any sushi that I've had recently in my town of Los Angeles, and it's packaged in a teeny, quiet, non pretentious environment.  

If you are in SF or visiting, check it out.
author: Jimmy G.

description: The Barbi roll is both unique and fantastic, mostly because of the lemon on top, which I never would have though to add to sushi.  I also love the fact that the tiny size of the restaurant makes it feels like a place I'd actually find in Japan.  I've been to a bunch of sushi restaurants in SF and think this one is the best.  My only suggestion: offer an IPA or some other non-pilsner-y beer.
author: Bob L.

description: I really love this place.  Very, very small so get there when they open if you want to get a seat right away.  They play pop music which is very funny.  Sushi is super fresh, relatively inexpensive, the have happy hour items and I just like this place, period.
author: Debbie G.

description:
WHAT TIME IS IT

IT'S SUSHI TIIIIME MOTHERFUCKER

Okay so we started off with some hot green tea and the san salad. Later ordered the GI Joe and Crunchy Rolls, some sashimi, a couple spicy tuna and scallop hand rolls, some salmon and amaebi nigiri, I think that was it...

It was all so good. Sashimi slices were thick, and the nigiri had perfect fish-to-rice ratio. The unagi and shrimp tempura in the GI Joe and Crunchy rolls were warm and just melts in your mouth. Friendly staff. I'm so happy we happened upon this place on Yelp. I'll be back~
author: S. D.

description:
The upcoming analogy is for all my east coast homies (Chesapeake Bay Bridge-Tunnel in the houuuuuuuuseeeeeeeee):

Remember basements? Yeah, me too. They seem like mythical creatures out here. They often had wood paneling and tile ceilings, an old tv (possibly still with dials) and a ratty, yellowish couch from the late 70s or early 80s. 

Now remember the day you discovered the door under the stairs? After jumping to the ground from the third stair up from floor, you finally realize there's a door under the stairs that leads to a little closet. The room is small, it feels like something is above it, but the entire space feels magical. Like your own personal hide-out. It's not your typical shape. It's not very practical either. But it's all yours. 

Sushi Time feels like that room... with the mood lighting of a shrine. 

You walk inside (well, if you can find it... it's in a confusing building and I wasn't initially sure what floor or staircase to take to get to it) and the entire place is to your left and probably the length of two couches put side-to-side. All the tables (maybe 8 or 9) are two-tops so don't plan on coming here during a busy time expecting to feed all of the Huxtables. There are about 10 stools at the sushi bar if you're feeling adventurous.

This place does sushi and they do it WELL. Almost the entire menu is dedicated to the craft of nigiri, maki, sashimi and rolls. Everything was SUPER fresh and clean. Not clean in the sense that the fish was washed, but clean in that the the parts of each roll were placed together perfectly rather than looking like a sloppy joe of the seaweed variety. 

We ordered:
Speed Racer (tuna, mango & tobiko)
GI Joe Roll (BBQ eel, cucumber and avacado)
Rainbow Roll (crab, tuna, yellowtail, salmon, shrimp, eel, avacado)
One other with fried shrimp
Seaweed salad

All were delicious. Not a single one paled in comparison to another. Our total came to just under $40 and I left feeling it was worth the cost. 

If you can find this place amongst the yellow-striped walls of the bookstore, Gym SF, random printing place and the shop with really buff dudes in tank tops sell protein powder, you will be handsomely rewarded.
author: Jared S.

description:
I pride myself on being a sushi snob and generally hard to impress, however Sushi Time has delighted me time and time again.

The atmosphere makes me feel as though if I were in some side street of Tokyo enjoying real Japanese cuisine. The interior is small and compact, but incredibly comfortable and pleasant. The restaurant itself is a small, trailer shaped nook in the mini shopping area off of Market.

Now, the food: AMAZING. The fish is some of the freshest I've ever had in San Francisco...not to mention relatively affordable for the great quality. I always order the 12 piece sashimi, but ask the chef to choose the freshest pick of the day. So, there's always something new to try and never a disappointment. The rolls are extraordinary! My personal favorites are the Astro Boy, Kamikaze and the Crunchy roll. To top it all off, I've had some of the best and freshest uni and scallops here I've tasted in my life. -Perfect for nigiri! 

Friendly service, great prices, cool atmosphere and some of the best sushi San Francisco has to offer! If you love fresh fish, it's definitely time for Sushi Time!!!
author: Coco P.

description:
So it was about a year during the holidays when I came here with a group of friends. Definitely would not recommend big groups or parties to come here though the foods pretty fresh and tasty. The place can probably fit at most 15 people. The place is decorated really nicely....really felt like I was in one of those small japanese restaurants in Japan. :] Good side, the fishes were really fresh. Loved it! esp. when the bf is very critical over food. 

Check it out during happy hours! Certain sushi's and beer's are a couple of dollars cheaper.
author: Eudora Z.

description:
I stumbled in here last night after taking myself out for a drink and a few smokes on the patio at Metro (corner bar at Noe & Market, not Le Metro or Metro Caffe) and took myself out on a one girl nigiri FEAST. 

Taking yourself out on a date rules because you know, I am a sure thing and I will take myself out for breakfast the next morning instead of awkwardly kicking me out at 5am. I will not call 5 days later to say that "i'm not really ready for a relationship right now" nor will I drop off the face of the earth and ensure that I will never, ever see one of my favorite pieces of jewelry that I very stupidly left at your house. 

Nope, taking yourself out on a date is much more fun because I can sit at the counter and watch the sushi chef make 8,000  rolls in the span of 30 minutes instead of having to listen to you drone on about nothing. I can drink ALL of the Asahi and I will not have to fight for the last piece of of the "spanish mackarel" nigiri special, which the waiter recommended to me and was seriously out of this world good. I can also have ALL of the green tea mochi and I can order the the cold tofu appetizer smothered with miso paste just because it sounded good (and it was!).  

 I can then walk home, all satisfied & happy & high off all of the raw fish & don't even have to think about getting rid of embarassing things out of view in my room or how the fuck I am going to get home. I seriously think Japanese food has anti-depressant qualities. Time to dump the Lexapro and get on a steady diet of J-food instead.
author: Maria D.

description:
I'm yelping in happiness just thinking of my meal here. 
Let me see. 
$30
1 small, warm ambiance
2 large sapporos
3 quality, succulent rolls of barbequed eel, scallop and mango, and a shrimp crunchy roll of flavors 
4 balls of mochi 
5 GOLDEN STARS!!!!!!!!!

oh and a patridge in a cherry blossom tree.
author: Daniella B.

description:
SU-SHE  TYE-MMMM!!!

So apparently studying Russian has fostered in me a love of transliteration and spelling things out phoentically in all upper-case letters.  Why?  I couldn't tell ya - thats just how it is.

Oh, and before I forget, I should mention that Sushi Time is magnificant (afterall this is supposed to be a review for the place).  This weekend some friends and I were seeking a sushi restaurant to meet at.  Ideally, one conveniently located nearby public transportation from the Inner Sunset and a short drive from the Mission.  Yelp led us to Sushi Time.  Again, Yelp was right (god damn Yelp - always being right...).  

Sushi time is hidden away underground with a sign that is difficult (if not impossible) to spot from the street.  Instead, watch for the address, enter the little cave-like entrance way nearby - and follow a flight of stairs down to the entrance to this street-car sized sushi haven.

My entire party agreed that the Barbie Roll, G.I. Joe Roll, and the sardines were fantastic.  Good vibe, comfortable atmosphere, and great food at extremely reasonable prices.
author: Matthew H.

description:
Underground sushi is a nice, cozy spot that has a really great ambiance and reminds me a bit of the St. Mark's Place vibe (NY). I live across the street so it's really convenient to go to.

 The servers are really friendly and their demeanor makes me smile each time I'm there. I love that you get to pick your own sake cup when you order a bottle.

The happy hour is great (5:30p - 6:30p) if you're into the standard rolls and like hot sake. They also have some really good tataki on their special's menu. I've also had their vegetable gyoza which is super tasty. If you're into amaebi they have a great plate that is presented really well. Their uni is good but not as plump and fresh as Eiji or Daimaru.

The wait can be a bit long if you don't get there early since it's so small, but it's worth it. Sometimes their sushi chef's can get backed up and it will take a bit longer to get your food, but you won't be disappointed.
author: craig s.

description:
I once bought my fellow sushi whore friend a watch with pieces of nigiri instead of the numbers on the dial. Why did I do this? Well, because we are dorks and dorks like goofy stuff like that, but more importantly, so that we could always say...

"Que tiempo, Stephy?" 

"It's sushi time, fother mucker!!" 

Well, finally there is a sushi joint that gets it and named itself appropriately, because when it comes to sushi, anytime is a good time and I have the dwindling bank account to prove it! 

Last night, I was taken here by a coworker and was definitely curious as he billed it, "Underground sushi" Ooooh, how mysterious. Well, underground I don't know. I mean, it's actually just down a flight of stairs, but hey, I'll go with it. 

The place is about the size of my livingroom and totally charming. It's cozy, it's kinda dark and you are practically sitting on top of the person next to you. Last night we were seated next to two lesbians that absolutely refused to smile all night and I think their names were Debbie Downer and Depressing Dolores, but even in spite of their negatory vibes, we still had a nice time.

As for what we ordered, the 5 fish sashimi plate, a yellowtail roll, something with eel for my buddy and some edamame. All were decent. Not exceptional, melt in your mouth worthy, but for a Monday nigh meal on the cheaper side with booze, it was a fine deal and I will be back. Oh yes, I will. What?
author: Stephy S.

description:
Typical sushi, typical food. 

This place has about 10 2 person tables aka it's the size of my living room, haha. Do not come here with a big party or else you won't get to eat! We made reservations for 2 people for a Friday night and it worked out fine. The place was somewhat hard to find since it is somewhat underground. It's not in plain street view but there is a sign that says SUSHI TIME and points to a flight of stairs leading downwards. 

KATSUO TATAKI SASHIMI
I normally wouldn't prefer to eat raw fish but I gave this one a whirl. The fish was fresh because it melted in my mouth. 

SAKE
We asked the server for their best sake and was present with a $14 one in a small jug. The jug came out to be about 4 shots each and best of all, you can pick your own shot glass to use! They give you a wood basket of about 10 shot glasses in there and you can pick according to your liking. 

Their rolls aren't big, and they're bit sized which is good...

G.I. JANE ROLL (bbq eel, cucumber & tobiko)
Typical BBQ eel roll. Nothing too special but everything was fresh!

ASTRO BOY (spicy scallop, mango, cucumber & tobiko)
Spicy scallop + mangoes seem to not mix but this was interesting. 

BARBIE ROLL (crab, avos, fresh salmon & sliced lemon)
I think this was my 2nd favorite roll coming close to the crunchy roll. The finely sliced lemon on top definitely added to the flavor. 

CRUNCHY ROLL (shrimp tempura, bbq eel, avos, cucumber, tobiko & sweet eel sauce)
We ended up ordering 2 of these! It was THAT tasty. Yum. 

Dinner for 2 which included 5 rolls, 1 appetizer, and 1 small jug of sake came out to roughly $70 after tip/tax. 

I wouldn't come back here in the near future, but possibly in half a year or so. I think there are other Japanese restaurants and/or Sushi Bars that I have been missing out on in San Francisco. Any suggestions?
author: Heidi C.

description: Great sushi, average price, cute atmosphere. I'd go back. For some reason I still kinda like Sushi Zone a little bit better.
author: Mark S.

description:
So its Friday night, my date had flaked on me, and I'm feeling like some hard-core sushi/sake rehab is necessary. Somewhere small, quaint, cozy and close. Off the top of my head, I quickly go through my short list of local sushi joints: 

Sebo in Hayes Valley: Great sushi, but a tad too trendy and spendy for my mood. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz/VkaWWpI6IvHTov5-_cJlag

Ozumo in the FiDi: Ditto above, minus the "great sushi" part. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz/PNxwbgtfdpldd3CyJFIw3w

Red Box in  the Tenderloin: Not feeling like making friends with drug dealers and hookers along the way. At least not tonight. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz/Kl6lQfhhRurgJeBAyb7gyg

All those great places in the Richmond/Sunset: Too far for tonight. 
http://www.yelp.com/search?find_loc=San+Francisco%2C+CA+94175&action_search.x=0&action_search.y=0&action_search=Search&cflt=sushi&nflt=Inner+Richmond%5ESan+Francisco%5ECA

Eiji in the Castro: Food Radar went off the charts when I passed here last. Perfect, small, neighborhoody. But there's a 1.5 hours wait. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz/-zetzVfO4X0dpiiTmjdeKg

Hama-Ko in Cole Valley: Perfect too. But an even LONGER wait. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz/uSL7-qazmxfJq3IAqi3Gcg

Finally I turn to Yelp and it leads me to Sushi Time... tiny, unassuming and within walking distance. Perfect. Located on the ground/basement floor of a mini-mall shopping complex, the exterior looks like some kind of mad-max submarine, and when you enter, there are only about 7 tables and a sushi bar in the long narrow space. A cool underground New York/Japanese vibe, reminds me of Decibel or Sakagura in NYC. 

Don't expect private conversation, you're crammed in like sardines and  can overhear everything your neighboring tables are saying (Psst to the couple at the next table: It seemed like you two clicked after just this first date. Best of luck.) 

With limited space, and staff consisting of one waiter and two sushi chefs, the waits were long - 20 minutes for a table to open up, another 20 minutes for our poor harried (but cute) waiter to take our order, and another 20 minutes for our sushi to arrive. Even then, we had to remind our waiter to get us plates... then napkins...  then soy sauce... then the bill. 

Worth the wait? Unfortunately, not really. The sushi was average-to-good, but not the kind of melt-in-your-mouth delectable goodness that I had been hoping for, especially after such a production procuring the goods. 

But the bill was surprisingly affordable, which makes me think that this is a great place to grab some neighborhood casual sushi if you're expectations aren't too terribly high and you've got some time on your hands (or a free night after say, getting stood up on a date).
author: Umami Y.

description:
TOTTTemo honkaku teki de oishiii~!

I truly love everything about this place, except for the fact that they're closed on Sundays. I was bummed when I came here on Valentine's day (remember how it was on a Sunday this year?) and it was closed! :(
author: Soo T.

description:
Neat little tucked away sushi joint in the bottom of a little mall area in the heart of the Castro. This place doesn't take reservations, so have a back up plan if you're having a date :).

All the sushi making staff is ultra serious about their job which is really cool. They were making sushi at super fast speeds for the 10-15 tables in this place. The rolls I ordered were decent, I wasn't blown away by their roll styles. I can't really describe what bothered me but I wasn't feeling it.

The server was quick to refill my tea every time I finished a glass. I had a good meal, just nothing was stand out for me.
author: Michael S.

description: I had high expectations because it seemed like an underground place. You know those small shops that maybe only the neighborhood may go to, the places where the food is simple but great tasting ... :( Anyways I got the sashimi dinner. When it came it was weird. The fish all sort of stuck together. Like it was sitting there for a while or something, left me with a weird vibe. Nothing really stood out except for the salmon. I wasn't a fan. I personally am not the biggest fan of salmon in the first place because it's sort of oily in this form. But this was really oily. It was definitely not my fave.  Large cuts, but bigger doesn't mean better :( I don't know I guess I might have caught them on a bad day.
author: Greg G.

description:
This is a great date spot.
Great fresh items.
Original rolls.
Snarky decor.
Needs more ventilation!
Sit at the bar and you'll be able to have a conversation 
without straining your voice, save it for whispering 
sweet nothings in the ear of your admirer later in the evening. 
Especially if they have picked up the tab. 
Order lots of sake(I like that they let you pick out your sake cups)
and be sure to order the baked mussels-they are divine. . .
author: Kia B.

description:
looking for sushi in the city, there's 1,000s of options.

want to eat sushi where nobody can find you, either find someone who owns a basement or go here. the food is good, prices are good, the staff is good. the music during our visit was CRAZY. i went with jonny bobby g, it left that much of an impression.
author: Ameer N.

description: Amazing food, service, and atmosphere. I love this place and would come more if I lived here. Price is very reasonable for the high quality sushi you get!
author: Anna T.

description:
Sushi makes me so happy.  I have had some bad sushi and some good sushi and I know the difference.  I had some good sushi at Sushi Time.  I went with a friend during the week after work.  It was not particularly crowded upon first entry but became crowded much later in the evening.

The service was good.  I was not blown away by the service but the sushi more than made up for the less than stellar service.  I had the BBQ Eel and it was so good.  I'm sure many people felt like I did, that Eel would be very, very bad.  However, it's really good and I know love to have it whenever I can get it.  They had good eel at sushi time so if you are trying it for the first time, stop by.

On a side note, I liked the decor.  It's a small place and might be crowded later at night but a nice stop in the city.
author: Adam B.

description:
I went here last night and can honestly say that I found my new favorite place to get sushi!  Don't let the location fool you! It may be downstairs in a strip mall, but it is a treasure!

This is the freshest fish I have had in the city, hands down.  I think we tried close to everything on the menu (as far as Nigiri goes).  Sushi Time is very big on presentation and the chefs have mastered cutting lemons and limes into the thinnest slices imaginable to garnish each piece of fish.  The ahi tuna tarter (with avocado and asparagus) is a fabulous appetizer (even though we ate everything out of order)! ;) I have never eaten so much sushi in one sitting in my life!  I literally had a sushi high the whole night and into this morning (I guess that is also because of good company)! ;)

And with sushi, must come sake!  They recommended a great bottle of filtered sake that was really smooth, and the unfiltered sake we ordered was not too sweet and also delicious.  

Lastly, but most important...everyone there was super friendly and all smiles!

We will definitely be back soon!!
author: Carlyna R.

description:
This is THE hidden gem of the Castro.  I've passed by the building hundreds of times and never knew such a high-quality sushi place lurked within.  A very intimate space and great decor combine for a solid atmosphere.  And the food was great for the prices.  I got the sashimi platter- this was probably the freshest sushi I've had in SF proper.

Props for the Sapporo.  Goes great with any Japanese meal.

Side salad was underwhelming, but that's kinda irrelevant here (and was compensated for by the rich miso that had a light garlic flavor to it- I think they get this by using non-veg broth)

Well worth the price.
author: Jeff A.

description:
Yum Yum. If you like sushi this place will certainly rock your socks off. Fantastic menu with so many rolls to choose from. An entire section of veggie rolls, sashimi to boot, and CHEAP starters....done and done! 

Astro Boy roll- scallop, spicy sauce
California roll- you should know what this is
Mango Cucumber roll- exactly as the name lays it out
Smoked Salmon sushi-2 pieces

Edamamme, seaweed salad, 2 sodas

All this deliciousness for only $30.00 (take someone here on a date and you won't go broke or hungry)!
author: Theresa T.
Stephanie P.

description: Woohoo!  After an arduous search for the best sushi in town, we stumbled across Sushi Time.  Not only is their Happy Hour (7 days/week) a great deal, but the sushi is unbelievably fresh and filling, and their teas and sake are fab.  Win!
author: Jillian Y.

description:
Love these guys!  It's a tiny out-of-the-way place with a really intimate i'm-in-a-submarine feel.  Sushi was good.  The tataki tuna is excellent.  Happy hour is great, super cheap hot sake.  Staff is great.  Masa, the chef, found out that I was learning Japanese and then would only speak to me mainly in Japanese- which was difficult, but a welcome challenge.
Also, you get to pick your own sake glass from their collection of different shapes and sizes.  It's got a nice home-y feel with nice food.  sweeeeet.
author: willi f.

description:
Everything about this place is done right, without being an uptight put-on. that is, the prices are moderate, the portions slightly larger than average without being garish and making you worried that it is old fish they are trying to get rid of. the fish is fresh and the little touches on rolls, or the saba don't swamp the fish in some covering flavor. 

It just goes on and on like this. i really like the place, and always feel satisfied when i get the bill.
author: harty s.

description:
If it weren't for Yelp, I never would have found this place because it is literally underground, and I am so glad I did because it just became one of my favorite sushi restaurants in SF.  We missed it the first time we walked past because you have to go down the stairs and into this strange mini-subterranean mall.  

Once you enter Sushi Time, though, it is as if you have been transported to a sushi joint in Japan.  Tiny, cozy, and unbelievably cute.  I was cautiously optimistic based solely on the ambiance.  We ordered the chriashi, baked mussels, and Speed Racer roll.  After I had some of the salad and miso soup (that comes with the chirashi), I was enthusiastically optimistic.  None of the wilty greens that look like they came from a plastic bag at Safeway that you might get at other sushi restaurants.  This was super fresh and looked like each piece had been placed into the bowl by hand.  There was that much care and attention to detail.  The miso soup was... superb.  It actually tastes like miso and seaweed, and not like the hot watered down soy sauce that is sometimes served at other places.  The tofu was also extremely smooth and very, very good.

After that, I was eagerly anticipating sushi that was just as good, and I was not disappointed.  All the fish was extremely fresh and well cut, the sushi rice was perfect, and the baked mussels were delicious.   Service was friendly and prompt, and prices are reasonable.    Capped off by fun background music, including a lounge singer's cover of Madonna's "Material Girl."  It was, in short, a dinner that made me very, very happy.
author: Leslie L.

description: It feels like your going into a Japan town mini mall and then your sitting in a tightly squeezed train car...the observation car of the train that is. The  sushi is very fresh and very good. Sunomono is refreshing and good also. Salmon was like it came right out of the river and on to my table. The kind of good that when you are enjoying it so much you are taken to a far away place and seem forget that the people seated an inch next to you are making out practically on top of your table. It's really that good. My advice is to try to get there a bit early so you can get a table or sit at the sushi bar.
author: Noe'lle M.

description:
I cant wait to go back to this little hidden gem and take my sushi-loving friends.  Our meal was delicious, fresh, affordable and was served up with efficiency and wonderful service.  The place is small, and if we lived closer, it would be a place to get take-out. 
The space is small and cozy but very unassuming and although you are sitting elbow to elbow with the table next to you, its ok, the food pretty much takes over and you ignore the boring conversation of the couple next to you as you eat pieces of fresh salmon-wrapped crab roll.
Everything we ordered was absolutely fantastic, especially the sashimi.  
I need to find an excuse to go back...but that shouldn't be too hard because in my world, its always Sushi Time!
author: Nilu r.

description:
This was my first sushi experience in The City and Sushi Time did not disappoint. Their happy hour specials are terrific - only $2 for a tokkuri of hot sake.

Lastly, I've had a lot of California rolls in my day, but Sushi Time's version were some of the best.
author: Julia D.

description:
Hold on, how come I can only give 5 stars to Sushi Time?  There should be a special 10 star rating just for this place.  I love, love, love me some Sushi Time.  The wait staff are the nicest in the world, the sushi is fantastic... and they always have my Octopus wrapped perfectly!

I can easily run up $100 dollar bills here stuffing myself and getting tons of large Sapporos.  I'm not saying that they are expensive, they are priced perfectly but I just can't stop when I'm there.  It's the cutest little little place too.  Almost hidden like it's a secret, only 6/7 tables and a bar.

I've been going there for years, I've eaten every single thing there and talk all my friends from out of town there (see Daze below) and everyone just loves it.

It's impossible for me to go anywhere else.  I just cannot say enough good things about Sushi Time
author: Steve P.

description:
I can't tell you how happy this place makes me!  I have never had a bad meal, service or experience here.  The music is sublime with covers of famous 80's songs; versions you would never identify until it gets to the chorus...."Oh my god, it's Our Lips are Sealed"!  

The space is small and very intimate.  PERFECT for a date and no more than four people.  Any more than that and you just won't fit.  The rolls are just damn good, and you must have a Barbie Roll.  Trust me...get the Barbie Roll!

Don't ask for a copy of the music BTW....they won't give you one.
author: Mike C.

description: 3.5 stars, but I'm feeling generous today.  This was a nice little find.  When you're walking on market street you won't find it right away because its tucked inside downstairs in an indoor plaza.  The restaurant is small and quaint.  The food was good, and the service was good.  I'll be back for their happy hour specials =)  It's a nice place to escape the hustle and bustle.
author: Nadiyah S.

description: One of the best (in my opinion) in San Francisco! It doesn't get any better than Sushi Time.
author: Amanda V.

description:
Finally we found a good sushi place in the city. After having a handful of mediocre experiences, I was ready for some good fish in an authentic atmosphere. Enter Sushi Time. 

It sits off the street and you have to navigate your way through a sort of open air mall to find it. It's a tiny spot with only a few tables which fill up quickly, so if you're planning on a group dinner, send someone early to get a table. We opted to sit at the bar in order to get the whole experience and chat with our sushi chef. Unfortunately, you can't order directly from the chef, which was a disappointment. 

We were celebrating a birthday and our dining companions are from Nashville and don't get a lot of good quality sushi. They were like kids in a candy store and ordered every time of sashimi on the menu and loved them all.

We ordered a variety of rolls and nigiri. The rolls are a bit small, but the quality of fish is good and the prices are reasonable. 

The sushi chef overheard us talking about our companion's birthday and sent out a bowl of green tea and black sesame ice cream as a birthday treat. Nice touch!

Sushi Time is definitely a good spot to get good quality sushi for good prices.
author: Lee H.

description:
Just when I thought I was stuck waiting for an hour and half for good sushi, like I do at SushiZone, I found Sushi Time!!!

I've walked by this place a million times and never thought of stopping in. Tonight a friend recommended the place and I obliged. The service was impeccable! The woman that seated us made sure that my water 
and green tea glass were always full. 

We started with the baked mussels, not quite SushiZone status but it was very tasty. Then came the rolls: 

- SpeedRacer: Tuna, Mango inside, Tobiko outisde - ANYTHING with mango is fantastic. The tuna was fresh and soft. It was perfect
- AstroBoy Roll: Spicy scallop, mango, cucumber inside, tobiko outside - OMG melts in your mouth with the perfect amount of spicy!! 
- Barbie Roll: Crab, Avocado inside, Salmon outside, sliced lemon outside.. this roll was soo amazing!!!! it was soft and creamy.. I couldn't get enough!!
- Sake Nigiri: Fresh Salmon - you know they use the good stuff when the salmon's buttery and melts in your mouth.

For dessert we tried the Mango Mochi Ice Cream... perfect ending to an unbelievable meal..

This place is simply a true find! I almost felt like keeping the review to myself because I don't want others to know about this secret spot.. BUT based on 109 reviews, it's hardly a secret anymore.

Good job guys!! you rock!!
author: Monica S.

description: They have really great sushi! Very small but cute place. I always enjoy taking my friends and guests there. Intimate environment, friendly and nice atmosphere with great sake and sushi.
author: Erhan E.

description:
I was kind of disappointed with the service and seeing all the hype about it from fellow Yelpers, I thought that it would be a mind-blowing experience. 

I have to say that the place (being literally one of those tube things like they have in Aquarium of the Bay) it had really good sushi. I got the Tako Roll (not spicy) and the Alaskan roll and it was very good. I tried my friend's spicy roll (which was too spicy for me) and some plum one. Again all very good. 

Granted that there was 4 of us there and we ordered kind of a lot, the food took FOREVER to get to us and when it finally was there, I ate but didn't feel very full afterwards, which is okay I guess, but I wanted to be filled! BUT, the prices were extrodinarily cheap. Like really cheap for the kind of quality it gets, so it gets plus points for that
author: Dustin H.

description:
I love raw fish. It's so very tasty. And for this, I love Underground Sushi Time (really, it's underground, you go downstairs from the street). Their fish is good quality, cheap, and abundant. The place is a bit small, but the service is friendly, and you really just can't knock good, inexpensive sushi. There are fancier places, and places with (slightly) better fish, but when it's just good sushi you want, and you're not looking to cash out that (currently crashing) 401k, this place is the one to go to. And if you do, try the poke - ahi tuna and avocado - it's pure love. Really, I asked it to marry me. But then I ate it before I got an answer...

Only four stars because there is better in the city, and because I don't want _too_ many people knowing about this. But it's definitely number one in my heart.
author: Daniel G.

description: Definitely not the freshest fish I've ever had, but they do make some good, cheap sushi rolls. Sushi Time is in a cool location in an underground tunnel and a great place for a small group of 3-4. Still, I'll usually only come here when the line at Sushi Zone is too long.
author: R C.

description:
Oishii!!! =)
This place was awesome! I am happy that I have finally found a good sushi place that only has Japanese people working! I felt like I was in Japan.

So the place is a little hard to find-its in the basement of a strange little shopping center- and its a small place and hence the wait. When we went we got a seat at the bar and I was more than happy with that!

The fish was so fresh and the rolls were yummy- the sushi rice was just right and miso shiru was yum!

I am glad I took the yelper's recommendation and went there- I will def go back in a heartbeat!
author: Nini D.

description:
Ok, the underground entrance is a bit dark and secretive.  It's quite cozy and friendly inside which is what really matters.  Yeah the windows look like they belong in a greenhouse, but this is San Francisco so enjoy the ambiance.

The sushi is great.  Both the sashimi and sushi rolls were up to snuff and left me wanting more.  Some green tea mochi ice cream was the perfect palette cleanser.
author: Eric M.

description:
The rolls are fresh and well made without costing too much. The most expensive roll is $10, and there are several ones less than $5. I recommend you try the eel, and I hear the crunchy roll is great. They've also got a nice variety of sake (about 12 types).

Only downside is the place is very cramped, capable of seating possibly 25 people, with people next to you able to hear what you're talking about.
author: Quaid B.

description: Good sushi, great selection of vegetarian rolls. Inexpensive, nice staff. Tiny underground place. Long wait on a friday night.
author: Stacy B.

description:
I would give a solid 3.5 stars.    Definitely the yelpers are correct in that this place is small and gets kind of warm.    I went there with a group of 3 other friends and we shared a bunch of sushi.   All-in-all the fish tasted fresh and the sushi was made well - they could have been a bit more generous with the fish inside the sushi but other than that i have no complaints.  

my favorites:  barbie roll (special), spicey yellowtail roll and the rainbow roll.   Gyoza were yummy as well - nice thin skin and crispy on the outside.

Prices were decent.. $22 with tax and tip ( i was pretty full too)
author: T M.

description: So I consider myself a Sushi connoisseur.  Having eaten Sushi on nearly every continent and country I have traveled to.  This place hands down has the best of all things; atmosphere, staff, food and drink.  The Sushi speaks for itself, fresh, tasty, and always delicious.  The best part is I live across the street so I get to eat here often, very often.  It reminds me of a place you would find in a hidden alcove in the depths of Tokyo where only locals go.  The Walu is hands down my favorite, any style!!
author: sam m.

description: This cozy place is like a hidden treasure. The staff was very friendly and the fish was so fresh. Considering I am visiting from Hawaii, I know what the good sushi is supposed to be. Definitely Sushi Time offers this to sushi lovers.  I would love to come back next time I visit San Francisco again.
author: Art T.

description:
F*&% Hammer Time I want Sushi Time!!!

That's all you have to say..."It's Sushi Time!!!" and go there and it will happen for you. Just go and don't let the small mall looking joint fool you into leaving cause you'll be sorry. Every roll we had was good roll and they were nice and attentive to each and every patron. I'm doin' sushi time next week and the week after next. Plus the wait is a quarter than the wait at Sushi Zone...still love that place too... To see what we ate look at "Monica S." review.

AB
author: Anthony B.

description:
Word of mouth is a powerful thing when it comes to eateries--especially if your only public existence is a plastic sign that says "Sushi". Tucked in the back lower level of a mini-mall, this is truly a hidden treasure. Now thanks to a friend, I've found it!

Bring yourself and one other person. If you're feeling extra special, make it a double date. No more than 4 because this place is tiny. For the first time, my studio apartment actually seemed like a big house in comparison. Pair this up a variety of cute, colorful adornments, a lot of Japanese being spoken, a blocked view to the dinky mall outside...and you can pretend that you are an expat in Japan.

All imagination aside, I thoroughly enjoyed my dinner here with the BF last Friday.  While we looked at the menu, there was a lot of positive talk from the next table about the G.I. Joe and Barbie roll. It was almost too much positivity to refuse, but not wanting to be easily influenced, I decided on the bento box. The BF got Sushi Combo B. Good choices for both.

I was especially pleased with my bento. Unlike the usual bento box with a cold piece of tempura and a slice of orange, the bento box here was fresh, tasty and not sad slice of fruit to be found. The BF seemed quite pleased with his choice as well...although he has higher standards than I do (so he would probably rank the sushi 8/10 vs my 8.5/10). But he did willingly eat the salmon nigiri. Very surprising since he hates salmon. That should say something even if our sushi rankings are slightly different.  

When the time came to go home, we had to leave our new found treasure behind. It isn't of the gold coins variety, you see. It is, however, a discovery to be explored over and over again. To restart your adventure, go directly to the "Sushi" sign.
author: Rona J.

description:
AWESOME sushi and sashimi. Absolutely delectable. 5 stars.

Sushi time is now officially one of my favorite sushi places in The City, it has a very cool hidden location, delicious food, even our waiter was charming and cheerful. The prices were just fine, and the mochi ice cream was very tasty. It may have been the three Sapporo's, but I deeply felt  the atmosphere there to be very warm and fun. I am surprised to see that The Castro now seems to be one of the prime spots for excellent sushi in SF.
author: Aaron J.

description:
Its like a little slice of Japan in there, there's a lot of fun stuff on the walls to distract your eyes, and for a cramped spot its quite comfy.

The service was great, and the miso was delicious, but I just couldn't appreciate the sushi/rolls I ordered. They weren't that great, just borderline to say the least.
