The pieces were tiny and lacked flavor. I've definitely had better in many other places, like Wayo. My dinner-mates concured with my assessment.

I guess this time, no time is a good time for Sushi Time.
author: Venatius P.

description:
This is without a doubt one of my favorite places to eat sushi in the city. You can ask yourself, "What makes good sushi?..." and I can tell you good fish makes good sushi and Sushi Zone has just that for a price thats just right without hurting your wallet.

Creative and inventive rolls that are very tasty. Nice selection of fish and drinks. Highly recommend the Ebi Gyoza appetizer.  ;)

Staff is very friendly and if you go enough they will get to know you on a first name basis.

I like the fact that this place is small. Its very Tokyo and the indoor mall it sits in is almost like a scene out of "Bladerunner." Big bonus points there.

They also have a nice small selection of cold sake's. "Mu" and "Esshu" are both of my favorites. So even more bonus points there.

Expect to wait on busy nights (IE Thursday, Friday, Saturday). The food, atmosphere and staff are worth the wait.
author: Patrick C.

description: Went here twice in 1 week because the sushi was super fresh and affordable and the service was quick and efficient.   Found this place by helping and was not disappointed.   The sushi and sashimi specials were very good and the prices were very reasonable.    Truthfully the best compliment for a sushi place is the quality and freshness of the fish and this place did not disappoint.
author: Matthew R.

description:
There we were, walking down market street after seeing an awful play, searching for sushi time. We past one sushi restaurant and started wondering if that was it but realized they didn't have the same name. Then we start walking farther up and while passing my fav neighborhood book store we saw a sign. It said Sushi Time with an arrow going down. We were kinda intrigued though following down the stairs when we found it. A cute little sushi restaurant with the emphasis on little. 

I was feeling a little under the weather so I ordered udon with chicken and some sushi. My boyfriend got gyoza, more sushi, and as always for both of us edamame. All the food we ordered was really good and the waitresses are very nice. There are little things besides the food that make me love this place and make me come back.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
So this wasn't my first choice.. by any means.

My boys and I have a sushi spot down the street aka heaven aka Sushi Zone.. And we've always waited at least an hour and a half (which is well worth it!).  So we put our names down.. pounded a few at zeitgeist.. and came back to Sushi Zone.  "WE RAN OUT OF RICE" Give me a break!  I didn't eat anything all day.. because i was looking forward to some mango and macadamia nut rolls!!... Ugghh.

So we raced over to Sushi Time... and thank god they seated us even though it was 10:15 and they shut at 10:30 (we needed to fulfill our sushi craving!).  So although we were trying to rush it cos we felt bad for keeping them open so long.... them rolls are GOOOODD!!  I can't really remember much of what we ordered except for the hello kitty roll and crunchy roll which was SUPER BOMB!!.. I think we annihilated the "house special rolls" section.

The staff was awesome!! and accommodating!.. even though we were the assholes keeping them from going home on time.

Anyway!! Overall.. A+!! Thank you Sushi time for being super rad!
author: Rio D.

description: We ordered several rolls and a sashimi plate- everything was beautiful and delicious. The space is very small and so don't go here with a big group!
author: Julia W.

description:
Man, I've lived in the Mission for way too long.  Sometimes it feels like I've been to every place with an open door from Division to Cesar Chavez.  Then there are times that some wise, benevolent soul shows me the light and I realize there have been these little gems right under my nose the whole time and I've really been missing out.  Sushi Time is one such place.

I have no idea how long Sushi Time has been there.  Furthermore, I do not care.  I only care that they are there now and that they never, and I mean NEVER stop serving or run out of the tuna avocado tartare.  I am not afraid to say this is one of the best dishes I've eaten in a long time, from anywhere.  A formed mound of perfect tuna, asparagus and avocado in a miso vinaigrette.  Simple, flawless, rich, fresh and addictive.  One day, I'm going to go and just order 4 or 5 of these.  Or 10.

Tho' that dish is reason alone to go to Sushi Time, there are other great things on the menu.  The delicious tai carpaccio with "salsa" of mangos, chiles, and sea salt is nearly as fantastic as the tartare.  The spinach goma-ae, GI Joe roll, speed racer roll, salmon skin roll, crunchy roll, the tataki and the aji nigiri...all consistently excellent and nicely presented even for sushi.  Plus, there are many items I haven't gotten to yet, which sound fantastic.  They have a small but interesting sake list too.

Speaking of small, did I mention this place is small?  No, I didn't...well, it's small.  Tiny, in fact.  Sort of like eating in a quirky, transparent maki roll if there could be such a thing.  The music is often fun, the service gracious and prompt.  There's not much room, so expect a wait...just know that it is absolutely worth it.

Well done, Sushi time!!!
author: Peter L.

description: My new go to sushi place in the hood. Great prices, fresh fish, great selection. It's tiny and hard to find for first-timers, but it's absolutely worth trying out.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Number one - THANK GOD FOR THIS RESTAURANT. It was the only sushi place I could find that was open on a Monday. Fair warning if you're looking to eat sushi on Monday - they are all closed! At least the higher rated ones on Yelp.

Second - super cute place. Don't get nervous when you walk into a seemingly sketchy mini-mall underground. This restaurant is tiny, but full of charm. Very cleverly decorated and the prices are fantastic. Regular rolls range from $4 - $9. Special rolls are a few bucks more.

The G.I. Joe roll was a little underwhelming for being a "special" roll. The Barbie roll was my favorite (yeah, my boyfriend and I didn't pick these two out on purpose, I swear.). 

Only downside - you might have to wait a bit. It's so small that it easily gets full.
author: Elly D.

description:
I was so happy that we found this place - thank you yelpers!

GI Joe roll is my favorite!! 

It's a small place and we are lucky on a Saturday that we got in without a wait.  Great prices and a small place that if there is a good vibe in the restaurant it's so easy to just start talking to the tables next to you and you sort of feel that you are eating at a friend's house.
author: Amiee L.

description:
I really like saying the name-- Sushi Time Underground.  It makes me feel like I'm part of something secretive and special.  And who knows, maybe I am.  Afterall, how often do you eat sushi in a plexiglass hut in the basement of a small shopping center and its a good thing?  

Sushi Time doesn't have the crazy waits of a Sushi Zone and the fish here is high quality in its own right.  The menu is fairly traditional and you can get all of the staples you would want to satisfy a sushi craving.  It's a good spot for sashimi/ nigiri and the prices are very reasonable.  I've always been impressed with the service here as well. The staff is very friendly and attentive.  Lots of smiles, helpful with questions and they just make you feel welcome.  The atmosphere inside is really great too.  It's a small area w/ alot of seating packed in so there's a very cozy and intimate feeling.  You feel like you're in some cool little nook rather than a modern shopping center building.  If you're into sushi, definitely try it out.
author: Zach J.

description:
It took us about 6 months in the city until we found Sushi Time.  Six months of eating yelp-suggested, yet uninspiring or over-priced sushi. Bummer! 
Then we found tiny little delicious Sushi Time.  Basically, if we are planning to spend more than $20 on dinner, we can't justify eating anyplace that isn't Sushi Time.  It has kinda hindered the process of becoming a San Francisco foodie, but oh well! I get delicious hamachi!  
Try the crunchy roll & the magoro zuke, please!
author: Alexandra G.

description:
I love this place.

I used to go so much I'd almost think I'm lodged back there in the photo of the inside of the restaurant somewhere.
author: Shannon W.

description: Sushi Time is a definite favorite for me in the neighborhood. The friendly staff serves japanese and sushi classics, with a few items beyond the typical set. It is always very good and fast. The magical thing is really the size and location: at times, and particularly if seated at the bar, you could feel like being in a typical Tokyo eatery.
author: Raphael V.

description:
My favorite Japanese Restaurant in the city! 
I personally love Japanese food very much so my fiance and I have tried so many Japanese places in the city...and still, we both agreed that Sushi Time is the best.

I love their Rainbow Roll, Crunchy Roll, Mango Roll, Seaweed Salad, Mussels...Their Bento Box is pretty good, too. Everything is fresh here! 

It's a small place with cute deco. You might have to wait about 20 mins to get a table on the weekends but it's worth waiting.
author: Lavinia W.

description:
Mean sushi!  They have a very japanese feel (small close quarters, hidden).

We have and will be back!
author: J R.

description: This has been a long time favorite of mine that has survived. What I really like about this place is that it's great for all occasions. Celebrations, birthday parties, dates, business meetings, getting hammer time. Talk about versatile!
author: Roger H.

description: Fair service-it was quick.Tiny place-7 tables and 8 sushi bar seats. Average sushi. But we are sushi snobs and like big elaborate rolls....
author: Lil L.

description: One of the best Sushi places I have eating in the city. Very very small, about 5 small tables and a sushi bar. Fish is very very fresh, service is great and quick. Though the rolls I feel and a little smaller than I would like, the place rocks.
author: david b.

description: Really good sushi.  The food was fresh and tasty.  Sometimes when you go to a Sushi restaurant their rice may taste stale, their incredients are not as flavorful, etc, but Sushi Time was really good.  Price was ok and their service was excellent.  Place a bit small but cozy.
author: James M.

description:
Hm found this spot today to grab quick sushi before a flick at the Castro Theater.  Anyhow, it's a little spot below a gym and it's easy to overlook.  Inside they can fit about 20 people max I think which is kind of nice actually since it's cozy.

The sushi portions were pretty good although the fish is not as fresh as at some places.  Or it may be fresh, but isn't the super top highest quality.  Of course for the prices they have it's a good deal.  I haven't tried too many of the other sushi spots in the Castro so I can't give any other options but if you aren't looking to spend too much, this place fits that bill.
author: Gene X.

description:
Pretty satisfying. My friend likened it to eating sushi in a submarine.

The fish seemed fresh. The rolls were good. The only thing I didn't like were the flies around the counter. In a place that cramped, you have to keep the counters really clean and constantly wiped down.

I'd go again if I were in the neighborhood, but no special trips.
author: Kay N.

description:
I went here today for the first time after my gf found this place doing a happy hour search for Sushi. This place I must say is in the middle of nowhere. If it wasn't for Yelp I would not know this place exist. 
The service is really good and the hosts are really friendly. The place is really chill and quiet and small. The music is a little weird but I still enjoyed what I was eating. You can't go wrong with the Happy hour between 5 to 6:30. I am definitely coming back..the deals are just so good. You don't find sushi places that cheap! :D
author: Nir B.

description:
Every time I think I've found the happiest place on earth, there's another place that's even happier.  I think Sushi Time is going to hold its place at the top for quite a while, though.  Because, man.  It's like concentrated happiness.

Sushi Time is hidden in a very small mall-ish-looking thing in the Castro, and as I descended the stairs toward the restaurant, I had no idea what to expect.  What I got was about the most adorable restaurant in which I have ever had the pleasure of taking up space.  There are only about 6-8 tables for two, and a few places at the sushi bar.  It's all quite snug and cozy, and while the large and/or claustrophobic might find it to be a bit cramped, I felt I had finally found a restaurant that was made just for me.  There's cute little domed window facing the outside, and it's covered in colorful cloth.  There are things that are a bit like mobiles hanging from the ceiling, and the lights are dim, but not too dim.  The whole thing is fantastically womb-like, only much cuter than I imagine a womb to be.

And then they feed you.  And that experience, too, was among the best casual sushi restaurant experiences I've ever had.  The menu was expansive, the maki were creative, the fish was very fresh and tasty.  The seaweed salad with which I started was on point, but I would actually recommend the nikumiso tofu.  The toasty ground chicken and miso sauce over the cold soft tofu was both salty and sweet, and made for a melty texture that I liked a lot.  My boyfriend and I also shared the sashimi six, the Hello Kitty roll, the veggie roll, and some nigiri of tai, walu, and uni.  All of it was as fresh as could be, but my favorites included the walu (butterfish), uni (sea urchin roe), and the Hello Kitty roll (mango, cucumber, tobiko, and white tuna).  The uni was my first ever (and I had it with quail egg), so I unfortunately can't compare it to other unis I have know.  But man, it was tasty.  So very creamy and with a taste that was of the sea without being at all fishy.  The Hello Kitty roll was as good as it sounds, and white tuna isn't something that I see often at sushi restaurants.

Overarching things about their food that I liked - I liked the quantity of options that weren't fried.  I liked that there were options that were above and beyond standard sushi fare - spicy scallop in a roll?  Just one of the many reasons I must return.  I mentioned that I liked the freshness of the fish, but I also liked the ratio of all the ingredients.  It's not something I think about much, but so often we are fed rolls that aren't carefully proportioned, or that are glommed with so much rice that we don't necessarily get to taste the goodies within.  It really feels like the sushi chefs are careful not to upset the delicate balance of their art.

Speaking of the sushi chefs, a larger party bought them some sake, and they were so very happy.  They thanked the people multiple times and beamed from ear to ear.  We were seated at a table, but I watched them chat with the people at the bar.  They just seemed so friendly, and it was clear from the taste and presentation of their food that they were also knowledgeable people who care about what they do.  Not to be outshone, the waitstaff was kind and capable as well.

All in all, being at Sushi Time just really felt like a treat.  I think it's easy for people who really like food to get sort of compulsive about it.  Do research, travel, consume, ponder, go home.  But Sushi Time just really felt like a special place to be.  And their food felt like special food to eat.  The whole experience had a charm that I haven't felt in a while, and aside from the fact that I could eat sushi every day, I think I could probably eat Sushi Time sushi every day.  I might even go so far as to say that I might haul myself to the Castro to do so.  It's just that special.
author: Becca S.

description:
I just enjoyed my first of what I am sure will be many visits to "Sushi Time". A great little restaurant.

Sashimi was fresh. Tasty Uni with Quail egg...although just on the edge of where I would still serve them (just a tad runny). Rolls were just right. Not too much rice and well prepared. Service was super efficient. What more can I say? I thoroughly enjoyed my meal.

That said, I don't know how this place got a $$ rating, it isn't cheap. I'd put them in the $$$ category. Not expensive mind you...I don't feel as though I overpaid...just certainly not inexpensive. But since I came here initially because of the price-range to rating ratio, I was a bit surprised when I received the bill.

Expect to pay typical sushi prices and you will feel as though you got your money's worth. Albeit with adjusted expectations, I will certainly be back and would recommend this place for small groups (2-4) or a cozy, non-fancy date.
author: Erich N.

description:
Sushi Time= my favorite time!

I love this place and think it's probably San Francisco's best kept Sushi secret.  It's the perfect place for a special Sushi date with your sweetheart.  Go on a weeknight a little past peak hours or before and you'll have your own little romantic submarine hideaway.  They play great swanky lounge music that makes the atmosphere and the staff is terrific.  The rolls and sushi have perfect consistency and are of good quality.  I'm so lucky that  it's close and convenient for me, so it's easy to make it my Sushi establishment of choice.
author: Marie S.

description:
I took a friend here who was visiting from Chicago last week, on the awesome reviews of Yelpers :-D Overall, I agree with its Yelp rating. 

We found it alright, thanks to the directions in numerous reviews below. When we walked in, I was shocked at how tiny it was! It literally had 10 seats total. (Not that I counted exactly, but it couldnt' have been more than 12...!) We were seated right away, but I'm not sure what would happen if they were full and had no seating... there didn't seem to be a place to sit and wait outside, except if you wanted to sit on the steps maybe...?

Anyway, we were seated directly between two already-occupied tables when there was an open one a few tables down. This made it a little awkward at first, since you could hear the conversation on either side of you (literally 1 foot away on either side) quite clearly, but I guess if it had bothered me that much, I would have asked to be moved. So it worked out just fine in the end. Just be prepared for VERY close quarters!

The food was excellent and at really reasonable prices for sushi. We each ordered 1 roll and split the Dragon roll (scrumptious!!), and each paid about $13.00 before tip, I believe. Overall, it was a great experience and I'd definitely go back.. with a very small group of friends! :)
author: Maria P.

description:
I hate to say it - but our Ladies' Night tradition is changing!  We've consistently been coming to Sushi Time for a while now - but as of last night, we're branching out. 

For what you're paying - Sushi Time is definitely decent sushi at a reasonable cost ... but the service was ridiculous.  I don't mind waiting for a table, it is a small place after all, but they kept forgetting our orders!  Last night wasn't the first time this happened either.  I'm sorry, but it doesn't take over 20 minutes to bring out edamame and a couple of misos! 

I'm sure we'll be going back to Sushi Time, but its time to move on - there are definitely more fish in the SF sea!
author: Lisa B.

description:
By far the BEST sushi restaurant I've been to. The food is amazing and visually pleasing. I would definitely recommend trying the special rolls they have, but then again everything that we ordered was delicious. The service was also a plus to this place; it may be due to the fact that the place can only fit about 20 or so people but all of the staff were still friendly and attentive. 

Totally worth an hour drive to eat here. Good find Q.

Live, Laugh, and Lunch
Patty
author: Patty N.

description:
Love their happy hour (5:30-6:30).
Love the service and decor. 
The sushi is great.

This is a great little neighborhood haunt of mine. I love going here because the staff are so friendly and the sushi is always on point. The energy is nice and upbeat and it almost reminds me of the St. Mark's Place yakitori places back in NYC. The wait can be long, but leave your number, head up to Books Inc. and they'll call you when your table is ready.
author: Audrey L.

description: This place is pretty good. The best thing, which is crucial for a shusi restaurant, is that is fresh. Very fresh. Price is good if you share, and the restaurant is small a cozy. I would definitely go with a group. The "hidden spot" atmosphere adds a touch of "I am in the know" that is cool, too.
author: Javi V.

description: I came in here late on a Monday for some post-cocktail sushi.  While the place was difficult to find, it was worth walking around in circles.  This is a tiny little sushi bar with very fresh and well presented fish.  The ama-ebi was very tender, but unfortunately they didn't serve the heads (chef said that there was no deep-fryer.)  Friendly sushi chefs and just-right ambiance.  A good place for a bite by yourself or with a friend.
author: Matthew B.

description: castro for sushi..missing happy hour specials...inside indoor stripmall...quirky as the name, sushi time...quirky anime figurines and strung origami for decoration over short sushi bar and around cramp table seating...mention covered in thick dust, but bar and tables clean....mix of sashimi and rolls ordered....quirky roll names....astro boy, hello kitty, etc....note the "big roll" similar to korean kimbap....uni quite creamy and fresh....sashimi radiant....rolls decent in construction...roughly $eighty filling meal for two with a beer and an order of sake....
author: Hen A.

description: We enjoyed this cozy little sushi restaurant on our trip to SF.  It is small, so we were glad we called ahead to get restvations.  The service was friendly and the decor was very Japanese.  The sake was delicious and we enjoyed the Barbie roll but loved the crunchy roll.  The aji was very fresh. All in all, a pretty good sushi dining experience!
author: Dawn A.

description:
Underground sushi
Smaller than my living room
Hope there's not a wait
author: Jason K.

description: This is probably my favorite sushi spot.  I like that the place is hidden; it feels like a special find.  The place is small, which I like.  The design is cute in an adult, not hello kitty, kinda way.  The service is good.  The sushi and sashimi is always really good.  I don't know how to describe the difference between good sushi and bad sushi, but I have had enough sushi to spot the difference.  Most sushi spots in SF, really anywhere in the US, are disappointing.  Sometimes they put mayo on the sushi or overly thick tempura batter.  This place is not like that.  This is good sushi.  They have a nice and well priced chirashi, which is one of my favorite things to order.  I like how there are numerous options featuring shiso leaf, which I kinda like but I know won't be to everyone's taste.  The unique / special sushi rolls served here are good and interesting.  I remember rolls with a bit of spinach or mango.  Again less of the fried and/or mayo rolls you'll find at many sushi spots in the US.  I like this place a lot.  When I lived in the Castro, years ago, there really weren't many good restaurants.  This was one of the best.  The situation has changed somewhat more recently, but I still like to go here when I'm in town.
author: Kenny K.

description:
Hidden in odd mall
Sit close to neighbors inside
Good food is worth it
author: Josh K.

description: Sushi Time is my favorite sushi spot in SF! They definitely recognize me each time I go in. The best miso soup, salads, ebi gyoza, and all the rolls I've tried are fantastic and super fresh. But by FAR my favorite roll here (and ever in history) is the BARBIE ROLL. Sometimes I order two. It makes my mouth almost as happy as my girlfriend does. Zing!
author: Betsy W.

description: Came here for happy hour and got to partake in their drink specials.  That was an important detail as I don't recall all the exact details (sauces, sizes, etc.) of the rolls we ordered but I recall being extremely satisfied at the end of the dining experience.  I believe we ordered the Barbie Roll, Rocketboy or Astroboy (?) and sea urchin with quail eggs.  The quail eggs on sea urchin is delicious.  If you're adventurous, give that a try.  I promise, you won't be disappointed.
author: Karen N.

description:
Fresh sushi! 

Sushi Time is the size of a closet, but their sashimi is fresh, tasty, and inexpensive.  

I usually get the bento box, the albacore is amazingly fresh at this restaurant & the unagi is great. 

For sushi, this restaurant fairly prices their items and delivers.
author: Pauline B.

description: I just moved to the city and I was really impressed with food. Good prices & I recommend trying the Barbie Roll. Nice quirky atmosphere too.
author: Justin C.

description:
Sushi Time is a small and cozy place hidden in a minuscule mall with a few other stores. We just finished doing our shopping rounds in the city, and decided to give this place a call to see how long the wait would be. Surprisingly enough, the Japanese accented gentleman on the phone told us they actually had space! We quickly tried to find parking (and by quickly i mean not so quickly since sf parking + quickly is an oxymoron). Thankfully when we go there the spots were still open. I was also very impressed that all the employees here were Japanese *yay!*. One thing to note is that they have super awesome chopstick holders! i don't know if they're really made out of bamboo, but it sure is in the shape of one. I wish I could've stole em. :D

This is what we ordered for the two of us:
 
sashimi A (with sake salmon) - very very very fresh! the salmon wasn't too fatty, and it 90% soft and 10% chewy. (5/5)

san salad - best of all worlds! we couldn't decide which salad appetizer to get, and lo & behold there was san salad which came with the seaweed salad, asparagus goma-ae salad, and tofu salad. Both the seaweed and tofu salads were my favorites. The dressing on the tofu salad was very flavorful and made everything that it touched delightful. I wasn't that big of a fan of the goma-ae salad as the dressing was little too gritty for my liking and I'm not that big of a fan of black sesame. (4/5)

rainbow roll -  One other great things about all their rolls is their perfectly bite size. Not too small to be insignificant and not too big so you have trouble fitting it into your mouth.  They have a good fish/filling to rice ratio ratio too. All the sashimi used for the rainbow were also very very fresh. (4/5)

astro boy roll- I didn't find this roll to be as great as everyone made it sound here, but it was definitely good. I couldn't really taste the spicy mayo at all. This roll could use a bit more filling too. (3/5)

GI-Joe roll - eel, cucumber and avocado goodness. (4/5)

I was a little sad they don't have toro, but I will not be deterred. The food here was amazing, and is now going to be one of the top japanese places i go to in the city.
author: Gloria C.

description:
Great sushi at a very reasonable price.  Friendly sushi chefs, always happy to talk to you and recommend a roll based on what you like.  
The place is a little tricky to find the first time coming in off Market St. (enter below the gym, down the hall, down the stairs, turn left.)  The result is you find yourself in a small, cave-like restaurant.  Some might call it cramped, but the small space and atmosphere inside make you feel like you are in Tokyo.

They have some happy hour specials when I'm in there sometimes, and the Nigiri is always fresh and delicious.  This is the one place in town that I'll actually eat (and enjoy) the salmon.  

The only downside is that there isn't much seating in there, so it isn't the kind of place you can take 10 people and get a table, but that is also nice because it means it isn't full of yelling saki-bombers.  

Next time you have a hankering for sushi, check out Sushi Time.
author: Robert F.

description: I am a vegetarian, but this place had many options.  Each one varied in flavor, but the mango avocado was excellent.  It's a neat little hidden place that is a fun experience.
author: Jonathan U.

description:
I hate to give sushi underground a bad review but this place is too inconsistent. When there are two sushi chefs, it is efficient and delicious. When it is one, he is unstable and the sushi comes out erratic. We waited over an hour to get one order last night.
The owner used to be friendly but he too is moody.
I want to say great things about this place but each time we go in, it gets worse. Maybe we should try another night besides Wednesday. AVOID THIS PLACE ON WEDNESDAYS and Saturdays. Very good sushi. I am a customer service snob. I like great service over everything else.
author: Annie A.

description:
Even though I love Japanese cuisine, I don't eat a much due to an intolerance for MSG, which shows up in some quantity in every form of processed soy.

This place made me very happy. I got the Ebi Gyoza, which were filled with a tasty gingery mix of shrimp and veggies, and not a hint of soy sauce. They were flavorful, delicious, and moist without the accompanying dipping sauce. Not too greasy, and nicely crisped on the edges.

The steamed edamame was very nice, warm and just the right amnout of salt.

The old standby California roll was also great, and again needed no soy sauce to liven it up. 

A cute, tiny little restaurant space, and they even have happy hour - with cheap drinks, rolls, and bento boxes - on the weekends. Looking forward to going back and trying more.
author: Kiri M.

description:
A true hidden gem in the Castro because you literally can't even see the restaurant from the street and you walk through a mini mall, down the stairs, and finally find this little place on the left. It's a tiny place, so pick another place if you're dining with a large group. It's widely decorated, just above from being labeled as tacky and has a very Japan feel to it. 

The menu is simple but they give them fun names like Barbie roll or GI Joe roll. The sashimi is fresh, the rolls are good, and service is friendly. I like how you choose your own sake cup from a basket full of different designs.
author: Linda C.

description: This tiny hideaway is my favorite sushi place in the whole city. The rolls are beautiful, actually bite-sized, and so fresh! Try the Barbie roll (very fresh with slices of lemon on top - perfect!) or the GIJoe Roll (avocado and unagi), or the Astro Boy roll (spicy scallops).  Nigiri is good, too -- very fresh. The Mochi green tea ice cream balls are the perfect, after-dinner  refreshing treat. Service is stellar -- quick, friendly, and prices are moderate. You won't want to waste your time anywhere else after going to Sushi Time!
author: Heather S.

description:
Small hole-in-the-wall spot, that has a nice feel, located in a mini-mall accessible off both Market St and 16th street.

Stopped by right after they opened, and we were the first ones in. Premium seating right where we wanted, by the time we left the place was 3/4 full. Place is pretty small so I can see coming later would have had some waiting involved. 

Happy Hour prices were helpful, but I still clocked in right over $100 for two people, now that said.. We ordered a LOT of food and booze.

Sushi was good, everything was tasty. Not incredible but nothing to complain about. I'd go back again, if in the neighborhood. 

They are temporarily closed on Sunday's until further notice. Which sucked because we ended up here on a Sunday a few weeks back, to our surprise, even though according to Yelp they were open on Sundays...
author: Paul V.

description:
So I have this one really horrible p-chem professor this quarter (that's right Delmar, this is about you, you jackass), who has managed to botch every exam that we've had to take. In fact we had to take 2 midterms b/c he failed to make enough copies of 1 exam, turned it into a take home test, and then gave us another unscheduled midterm a week later in class. What does this have to do with Sushi Time? Well, the manfriend sensed a storm brewing after listening to me bitch about the aforementioned exams and whisked me away to (the new to me) Sushi Time to erase the memories of p-chem. 

Sushi Time allows you to grab a drink up top somewhere while you wait and calls you when your spot is ready. This is ultra convenient and a stark contrast to SPQR which won't even allow you to call them to check on your table. I had low expectations for S.T. as it's located below street level in an odd little shopping center. That being said, the quality of the fish and inventiveness of the dishes blew me away. 

We started with the cucumber sunomono to prime the palate. From there, we moved on to the delicious tai carpaccio garnished with a tiny dice of mangos, chiles, and salt. Hamachi sashimi and maguro zuke nigiri were next, each one well cut, fresh, and bright tasting. A hello kitty roll and a tuna tartar (for our "dessert") followed. 

I loved the quality of the ingredients, the friendly service, and the little home-style details like the origami paper menu covers. The wait allowed us to get through 1 cocktail at a nearby bar which is pretty reasonable for a Friday night. My only complaint is in regards to the very meager wine selection. You can opt for a half bottle of Alexander Valley Chardonnay or Cabernet Sauvignon, or a full bottle of their Cab.  These are not the best wine pairing options for sushi in my opinion, or rather they are very confining. I would love to see a crisp, reasonably priced Cava or sparkling wine and a Sauvignon Blanc added to the list. Also, as a novice sake drinker, some descriptions would be helpful in the sake department. Still, that is a minor quibble after a great meal. Looking forward to returning, 4 stars.
author: Candice L.

description: Yes, most definitely a fan!  I've passed this place countless times over nine years, and only tonight finally went through the alley and down the stairs.  What did I find - a really cool sushi joint!  There's a speakeasy feel to Sushi Time - maybe because it's sort of hidden.  Their menu suits it's size and the offerings are very good.  Only thing stopping me for giving it all five stars is their sashimi portions could be a tad larger, otherwise everything else as great. Bonsai!
author: Tiberius A.

description:
One of my new favorite sushi spots in the city.  The ambiance is exactly what I look for in a sushi bar... hidden within a corridor of stores off the street it's a cozy, dark little spot where your table is a foot apart from the next one over.  Obviously you're going to be sharing space with your neighbors but hey, that's what living in the city's about.

The sashimi is fresh, the rolls are fun but not too over the top, and they seem to follow the rule of small sushi spots in the city that you have to have a good appetizer to keep people coming back... the tuna and avocado tartare.

The service is great and the wait isn't bad, probably due to the fact that it's so well hidden.  Just don't come with a big party or you're out of luck.
author: Bill B.

description:
Didn't quite know what to expect when we rolled into Sushi Time.  First of all, the location gives off the ambiance of a back alley meets Strip Mall from the San Fernando Valley which might be a little much for some people (especially those special breeds roaming the Castro) to get over.

Once you except the idea that you're going to be dining in a literal hole in the ground, it's all up hill from there.

While the sushi wasn't the "best" I've ever had, that's hardly their fault.  It was lovely tasting, fresh and best of all...cheep as high holy hell.  Dragon Rolls for under 10 bucks, in this city?  Someone must have been walking around in my dreams.

In addition, the server man is really nice and my water glass never wanted for liquid.  Seriously, he was all over it.  I had to pee like, a gallon later that night.  Amazing.
author: Jesse J.

description: A little tricky to find, as the storefront is not on the street. You'll find the large sign for Sushi Time out front, but follow the arrows to the back towards the gym and you'll happen upon this little establishment. Good, standard place for sushi. Authentic and fresh, nothing fancy. Just a tad expensive for standard sushi though...
author: Uyen D.

description: Before I even came to San Fran (I'm from Hawaii) I was reading up on this place, and when I got here this was the first place I wanted to come. As soon as I walked in all I could think was Chirashi! And it did not disappoint, and for the price I got no complaints. Oh and by the way whoever came up with the names for these rolls is a genius. Barbie roll FTW!
author: Aaron K.

description:
I want to give this place 5 stars..but I'll need to go again to confirm my  opinion. It was fab! The fish seems quite fresh, the rolls are super yummy, and its inexpensive. The place is little and underground -- don't be thrown off by thinking there's a gym where the restaurant should be..just walk downstairs and you'll be greeted by the huge neon sign that says "SUSHI TIME". [There seriously is a gym so look for THAT sign first...then as you walk in you'll see the SUSHI TIME sign. :) ]

I don't remember all the rolls we had but the Astro Boy roll and the Barbie Roll were both very yummy. In the past, I've been sketchy with the whole mangos-in-my-sushi-roll thing but i've been converted! This is destined to become one of my regular sushi joints in the city and I look forward to going again.
author: Grace G.

description:
What time is it?  IT"S SUSHI TIME!!!

What a great little (and I mean little) place.  The Japanese chefs are always in good spirits.  The music is always really weird but funny and adds to the experience.  The sushi is always outstanding.  The seaweed salad is always the right temperature.  I love it.   I hit it regularly.
author: Colin S.

description:
A small (some say cozy, I say small) sushi restaurant. They have all the typical items you would expect plus some other items that I've never heard of. For the most part, things did taste pretty good. I tried salmon roe, and it was disgusting, but by no fault of the restaurant, just sayin'. As mentioned, the menu does have some extra items, but it does lack even more choice of staples. More combos are in order! Also, I wasn't really sure if we were supposed to get plates, but I don't think we were. And since there were 5 of us in our party, it was a little weird to be doing family style without our own plates. Anyway, like I said, the place is small and they probably don't have space for extra dishes and such. I didn't have any sake but I'm sure it's really good. 

It's really cramped. I was getting bumped into by the waiter and other guests. I suggest going as a couple. Not many more than that. Also, all guests must be present in party to be seated.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
I was in love with Sushi Time before the food arrived.  Sushi Time is tucked inside a very Tokyo style mini-mall and the decor inside the restaurant is SUPER cute!  Feels very Tokyo, which I enjoyed.  There's very little room inside though.

Their sushi rolls were amazing - small (not the super big rolls that you can barely fit in your mouth), minimal amount of rice so you can actually taste the fish, perfect amount of sauce on rolls.  There were also cute specialty rolls like the Astro Boy :)  The nigiri sushi was also good - the fish covered the rice portion, so you know they're not ripping you off here.  Sashimi was not so good - cuts were a bit sloppy and the fish alone wasn't spectacular.  The mango mochi dessert is tasty, too!

Only complaint is why it took forever for our sushi to arrive.  There was another table of 4 and a table of 2 also waiting for their food, but it seriously took over half an hour on a late Monday night.

I'd definitely come here again! :)
author: Wendy T.

description:
Nanji desu ka?  

Oh yeah, it's sushi time.  

Offering a fun, underground environment, this small restaurant serves up tasty udon as well as a nice mix of creatively named rolls.  I was a bit under the tenki, if you catch my tokyo drift, and I shied away from having a lot of the sushi, but this place charmed me.  I will be back for a followup review.
author: Tim G.

description:
Meh. The fish was excellent but otherwise I wasn't very impressed. Sushi was warmer than room temp which I'm never down with. I dug the atmosphere but it seemed a little pricey for the meal we got. Not a very creative menu either.

I'll probably give it another shot but will stick to the nigiri/sashimi. Great fish!
author: M L.

description:
It always feels a tiny bit like I'm stepping into some scene in Blade Runner when I visit this place, moreso after several servings of unfiltered sake - heh, heh.

Every time I've come here I've left with a very happy stomach.  The fish is consistently fresh and the atmosphere is fun and warm.

I've found the wait for food can be a bit excessive even at times the place isn't full, and the quarters either cramped or cozy.  Depends on your company.  The sake helps.  This isn't the best place for a heart-to-heart, as it can feel like you're sitting in your neighbors' laps, but it's a cool choice when you're looking for a lighthearted, quirky spot to get your fill of the fish.
author: Jack G.

description:
Wow, the ambiance is great, and the fish was delicious (albacore tataki, spicy yellowtail roll). My eyes literally rolled back when I tasted the albacore - I had the same level of tuna for much more in Seattle. 

Non-sushi dishes were also excellent (tori udon, unagi don buri), right serving size, great ingredients, great flavor. 

I keep thinking of an excuse to go back to the city so I can eat here again soon!!
author: Stephanie L.

description:
I have been ignorantly strutting by this place for years. Ok so its more of a limp than a strut. A limp of ignorance.

I never imagined the treasures I would find a place called Sushi Time, buried in a mini West Hollywood type strip mall in the Castro, the only signage being one of those folding signs that people sometimes wear in places like LA. Go figure.

Well now I am eating the maki of shame. This place rules! It is by far the best sushi for the price range that I have had so far. Because of that balance of price and quality I give it a full fist of stars.

I love the Albacore Tataki, the variety of miso soups, all the sashimi, the blippy happy music, the origami mobiles, the toy themed menu, the easy going friendly staff.

I will definitely be making up for the years I pranced...gahh my back...limped by, oblivious to the true joy that was beneath my very feet...
author: Derek O.

description:
We put our names on the waitlist when we got there and stepped outside to wait.  Thirty minutes and three departing parties later, looked at the list, and they had flipped the page to add names to the next page, and sat three other tables that had arrived after us.  Poor organization.  Don't mess with my sushi fix like that.  

Fish ranged from good to very good.  Nothing that melted in my mouth this time.

It IS stuffy in there.  

Our initial order came right away, and after we finished, we ordered another three orders.  After twenty minutes, we cancelled it and asked for the check.  

Seemed kind of hit-and-miss here tonight.
author: Y W.

description: Not sure we would have ever tried this place were it not for the yelp reviews, location looks like a greenhouse attached to the corridor of a mall, but fish was very, very good.  Small and intimate inside, staff was very friendly.
author: Alexa B.

description:
This place to me feels like Japan. Tiny, cramped and crammed, you elbow the stranger next to you when you try and pick up your unfiltered sake, everything is a mystery and Bill Murray provides some comic relief.

Alright, no Bill Murray, but it is small. But that just means you can talk to the sushi-chef as he prepares your Speed Racer rolls, ask him what he recommends, and have him critique your use of wasabi. You can also whisper for another Sapporo from the wait staff.

Extremely tasty, exotic and eclectic -- the uni is so insanely buttery, you'd swear you weren't eating sea urchins, one could easily OD on the unagi, and the spicy scallop melts in ones mouth and the sake list is impressive. Nice cozy ambience -- though it is really fucking small -- and you can impress a date with a fine meal, with drinks, tip included, for $50, or you can go nuts and still only pay $30-$35 a head.
author: Chris R.

description:
Since Sushi Time has been receiving such good reviews on yelp, we decided to give it a try.  We were very pleasantly surprised with the staff, the quality of the food, and the very cozy and welcoming environment.  Don't let the very obscure entry trick you, they bring the YUM factor in full force here!!

We ordered an array of sashimi, nigiri, maki rolls, soups, and all were fantastic...not to mention extremely well priced!!  The cuts of fish were generous & high quality.  

Sushi TIme has made its way into our regular rotation!!
author: Corey L.

description: Came here on a recommendation from a friend. Tried the Barbie roll and the Walu spicy roll. Cuts were ok portions. The service was mediocre at best. Not bad... Not great...
author: Minh V.

description:
Pros:

. Food is great
. very small place and nice atmosphere
. good music (although it hasn't been that good lately and you can barely hear it)

Cons:

. Service is horrible!! except for one waiter.
. Long wait to get a table
author: Flo L.

description:
About the size of a shoe. More delicious.

I've only been here once at the time of this review. It was not busy. The place seems to be mostly patronized by quiet homosexuals. There was one woman who came in (aside from mine, who was with me), and I thought she talked too much.

One person talking loudly, or at a reasonable level about stupid shit, can easily ruin the atmosphere. Shut up if you come here.
author: Matthew W.

description: Their HH deal is one of the best I've ever seen. Service was great and I loved the "hole-in-the-wall" feel. I really don't think you can have bad sushi in CA but their spicy tuna was excellent. I'll definitely stop by again next time we are in town.
author: JK L.

description: Total "hole in the wall" and I love it. Sushi always really good. Take someone here if you want to seem "in the know" while you both enjoy great sushi. Order the green salad too. Super fresh with great dressing.
author: Daniel K.

description: Sorry, after going to Ozumo this place gets knocked down from a 5 to a four star place. Gomenasai!
author: Zaviera R.

description: I have been to this place 3 or four times.  Staff is always friendly.  It's tiny but it's cool.  I think it's a little overpriced, but what sushi place isn't?  Last time I went the sashimi melted in my mouth.  I got the happy hour bento box for $13.00.  It was yummy.  It came with a delicious green tea ice cream but it was only two spoonfulls of ice cream.  I am American, I like a huge bowl of ice cream.  but still, it was super delicious, I think it was homemade.  It was part of the meal so no big deal.  i could have ate more but I was broke, lol.  Thumbs up.  I like this place.  It feels like you are in on a secret when you there because they aren't open for many hours in a week and it is small and kind of underground.
author: Cynthia B.

description: The best thing about this place is the location. It is underground in a really tiny space. You actually feel like you are in Tokyo eating at a fast food sushi place! However, if you take the food away from the location it is nothing special. Infact there are places just a couple of blocks away with better sushi (Eiji for one). First time I went here was 4 years ago? - still the same greeter (which I assume is the owner) but he was friendlier then...
author: Angelito R.

description:
Came here for Happy Hour tonight with a friend and wow-- Yelpers were not exaggerating; this place is SMALL.  And warm.  But you get over that quickly, and the the "underground" aspect of the name quickly starts to hit you.  Quirky decor, plus some of your standard sushi place fare, along with a really friendly staff makes it all work out.  

I ordered the tofu salad, the Alaska roll, and the Barbie roll, while my friend ordered the Rock 'n Roll, the dragon roll, and the Astro Boy roll.  With the Astro Boy and the Barbie being the place's own special rolls, one would think that they would be amazing... and they ARE.  The Barbie roll is unlike anything I've ever tried-- the little bit of lemon really adds something, and the Astro Boy roll is... dammit, it's just good, okay?  

Had some mango mochi and some black sesame ice cream afterwards, and were given our bill by a super friendly waiter.  Loved this place, but it lacked the OMG AMAZING to make it a five.  Either way, though, Sushi Time = Awesome Time.
author: Lauren P.

description:
the place is really cute but it is literally the smallest restaurant i have ever been to, and i have lived in cities known for small places like nyc and hk!  there are only close to six tables, arranged in a row.  it's so cramped that you can't even get through without moving the entire table.  you definitely feel like you're in japan haha

the rolls are delicious!  the barbie roll and astro boy roll here are must haves.  the butterfish is sooooooo yummy!  the location is a bit far/out of the way for me so i doubt i will be a frequent here but it's definitely a good place to check out if you're in the area!  the prices on the rolls are not that expensive, even with sake.
author: Irene W.

description:
This ain't a sushi place for Japanese people.  Other than that, it was a great atomosphere and had decent rolls.  Also, super cheap.

However, there were two things that are just unacceptable to me:

- There was NO wasabi under the fish on the nigiri.  What the heck?  The sushi chef caught me lifting up a piece of fish with my chopsticks and told me that white people don't like the wasabi on the nigiri so he doesn't put it on.  Hello?  Do I look white?  And we're in California, not the deep South - people have developed palates here.  Do it right!

- Part of why I love ordering amaebi (other than the sweet creamy texture) is because it comes with the deep fried heads.  They don't give them to you here.  When asked, the guy told me that the supplier doesn't give them the heads.  That seriously makes me question the quality and freshness of their fish.  Also, I felt ripped off.  They should put a disclaimer on the menu.

The two flaws above are pretty serious to me.  However, I would come back because it's ridiculously cheap and you probably can't go wrong ordering rolls.  I would not order anything particularly unusual though, nor do I think I would order nigiri again.  Definitely falls into the category of lightweight Americanized sushi vs. hardcore authentic sushi.
author: Riya K.

description:
Fresh fish.
good selection.
cozy atmosphere.
Sushi Happy Hour? sweet!
author: Shayna N.

description:
Got take-out from here after reading the reviews on Yelp.  California roll + shiitake roll + unakyu roll = $13.50 and a very satisfied Gina.  Dang was this good.  Especially with the bottle of Sho Chiku Bai I bought down the street.  And when I went in to pick up the food, the place wasn't full...I'm hoping this is the case the next time I decide to eat there.

Signs point to "sushi" inside the mall on the corner of 16th and Market--that's the place.
author: Gina K.

description:
Most sushi retaurants have Japanese-esque names attached to them like Sushi Kazoo, Sakae Sushi, or I Ran Sushi.  Sushi Time is about as whitewashed as one can get.  Despite the name, it does nothing to scare away potential customers.  The restaurant is located in the downstairs of a mini-strip mall.  Tucked away in a quiet little corner, the restaurant probably seats somewhere in the range of 25 people including the sushi bar.  It's a nice little intimate joint.

We sat at the sushi bar and the chef was extremely friendly, talkative and wanted to make sure the customers were well taken care of.  As for the sushi it was excellent.  The menu featured different types of nigiri and fresh fish.  Sorry though no chicken teriyaki.  This place tries to stay as pure sushi as possible.  

As for the cost / taste ratio, this place passes with flying colors.  I had the mixed sahimi over rice and it was SUPERB!  Nice chunks of tuna surrounded rice and it was an absolute delight to eat and enjoy.  It didn't kill the wallet either.  My wife and I got away with an excellent sushi dinner for about $50.  We will gladly return.
author: Bill P.

description:
Wow -- SMALL. Er...I mean "intimate".  Unlike some other small sushi places I've been to, this one was very clean, and didn't try to cram more people in than the room would hold.  Also the curved windows along one of the walls makes the whole thing feel like a submarine.

Having showed up shortly after 5pm on a weekday, I was the only person there, and got very attentive service.  The fish was great and very fairly priced.  In fact, the one reason I'm docking this place a star is the lack of variety.  They have the staples -- but little novelty.  The one rare-ish thing they had was Aji...and that's not all that rare in this town.

However, if you're just craving the staples at a reasonable price -- this is a good place.
author: Eugene F.

description:
This place is  a hidden gem. So well hidden, that, in about three years of living two blocks from here, I never once knew that it existed. Only after moving cross-country and coming back to visit did I happen upon it. 

We showed up on a Saturday evening, and it wasn't hard for a party of three to get seated at the bar. There aren't many tables, so you pretty much take what you get.

I ordered the speed racer roll, which contained tuna and mango, the spicy tako roll, which contained octopus (duh), and the salmon nigiri. Everything was excellent - the fish was much fresher than anything I've had in quite some time. The food came out quite quickly - this isn't one of those places where you wait 40 minutes for your sushi.

Overall, the service was pretty good, and my meal came to about $20 (I also had green tea mochi and edamame, which were fairly standard, although the mochi was a bit softer than I would have liked).

I miss SF.
author: Dana L.

description:
I've been coming here for a good 4+ years.  It's a very small, intimate little sushi joint hidden away in a small business area.  The setting is very typical of what you'd expect of a small Japanese sushi bar.  The fish here are always fresh and the Hamakama (Yellowtail collar) is amazing, if it's available.

The place has gotten quite popular so seating can take awhile.  But they do let you leave your phone number and call you when your table is ready.  Just enough time to go upstairs and check out Books Inc.  

The music is an eclectic mix of cover bands and downtempo renditions of classic and pop songs.  Very unique and always compliment the semi-campy decor.
author: Shiun H.

description: My friend and I found this place while walking around Market waiting for a concert. It's down a hallway and not easily visible. It's very small, but the decorations are relaxing and the atmosphere is calm. We had quick service. I ordered the Hello Kitty Roll and the Alaskan roll. My friend ordered a crunchy roll, which was yummy! Definitely a place to visit if you want a quiet and filling meal!
author: Effie P.

description:
I love sushi, and having had the chance to try a number of different places I've gotten pretty adept at quickly identifying the quality of a sushi restaurant. Sushi time is a small place hidden in a small indoor mall away from the curbside. 

I liked the decor, it almost reminded me of the small sushi/ramen joints in Japan that I saw on the travel channel. The owner is a very friendly japanese man named Masa, and since I was the only one he and the sushi chef proceeded to strike up a conversation with me as i ate. It was a very pleasant dining experience overall.

I got the Lunch special, Sushi Box C. It comes with a roll of your choice, and 5 pcs of chef's choice nigiri. I got the spicy hamachi roll which was nothing special, but the fish was fresh. My nigiri consisted of unagi, salmon, albacore, maguro, and hamachi. The slices were huge... and very fresh as well. The salmon and hamachi were especially delicious. The chef must have cut a piece close to the belly, because that hamachi melted in my mouth. Very decent rice to sushi ratio as well.

If you're in the area (castro) and you have a craving for sushi, this place is a very good choice. Overall it's affordable, and the quality of fish was good. If there was a tiny, very picky issue I would say the rice was a little too sticky. But.. i'll be back sometime in the future.
author: Jim Y.

description: Great food. Really friendly staff. Barbie roll and rainbow roll were really good. Tried my friend's soup and it was really good. Next time i'm headed over I'm going to grab some miso.
author: D n.

description:
Finding a decent place to eat on a Friday night is hard even in this economy. Four of us tried to call Sushi Time before we arrive in case there is a long waiting list. Unfortunately, they don't do "a list." Fortunately, there is no wait, so they say. 

This was my first time there, and I would have never been able to find it on my own. Hidden in a mall-like building on Market street, neighboring a printing shop and some other random stores, it reminds me of Tokyo. 

Restaurant is tiny and seats only about 20 people. There were two 2-person tables and the sushi bar available, but we wanted to sit together at a table, so we opted to wait. There is a bookstore upstairs, which helped tremendously in killing time. 

When we came back after 20 minutes, none of the diners seemed to want to leave this cozy warm intimate joint, so we waited at the sushi bar and ordered some drinks. When you order hot sake, they pass you a basket full of little sake cups so you can pick your own! What a nice touch of detail! On top of that, their chopsticks come in a wooden container that are just adorable. 

I love restaurants that pay attention to details and aesthetics in general. 

The food was great. As a starter, we ordered the San salad, which included 3 types of salad to sample. The seaweed, asparagus and tofu salad were all delicious with a strong taste and fragrance of sesame which I love. For sushi, we had hotate, aji, tai, and hamachi nigiri. They were all very fresh and buttery. We also had the Speed Racer rolls, with tuna and mango. And salmon skin rolls, which had burdock and shiso leaves. Both different from your traditional sushi, but with fresh ingredients and no crazy sauces (which I hate.) 

Price is fair, and service friendly. We didn't feel rushed to leave, and tea is always filled promptly.
author: Candice B.

description:
Always delicious fish, always. The Barbie Roll is a must for the thin slice of lemon on top. 

I'm a creature of habit when it comes to my favorite restaurants. At Sushi Time, I start with a hearty bowl of the Kenchin Miso Soup --Kenchin must mean potatoes, carrots, onions and mushrooms? Yes, this soup is good and it's just the beginning.

Always get sashimi here. Why? Cuz when fish tastes like buttah, you know it's good. Seriously, you can't go wrong with the Sashimi Six or any of the nigiri. And the rolls -- what can I say? -- they are inventive, delicious, and a mouthful...cuz the pieces are HUGE!

Of course, if you're claustrophobic, this would not be a good place for you...it's like the yellow submarine of sushi restaurants -- close quarters and underground.

Oh, and what's with the music? It's Japanese pop renditions of all your favorite '80s songs. Truly bizarre and worth it.

Be prepared to drop change on a big meal.
author: Cody S.

description:
Tried this place because of Yelp.   And once again I was not disappointed.  I have to say this is now my favorite all around sushi place in SF.  

This is not one of your trying to be the next trendy restuarant in SF.  Or where you go to be seen.   It is actually very hidden from the street.  But It makes it more of a gem. 

This place has great quality of fish, nice selection of rolls, and a price that is pretty inexpensive.   The employees are very nice, and service was great.  The only minus was that it was tight but I think it gave the place a nice ambiance.
author: Linh N.

description:
Eating dinner here I feel a little bit like a fish in a bowl with the glass wall/roof sloping up overhead.
The sushi is good - some different selections on the menu which is nice to see.  The Ika Shiso roll is AMAZING.  love it.
tea cups are way too small and I need at least 8 refills per meal, but that's an easy fix - just sit next to the tea pot and you can  help yourself.
author: Sarah L.

description:
What a find! This place, tucked away behind and below an unassuming tunnel storefront on Market, had some of the best sushi I've ever tasted -- fresh, simple and original, and not overpriced. 

I adore mackerel (saba), so their sabagari roll (with pickled ginger) was a delight for me. The philly roll (I order it with fresh salmon) was far better than most I've had. Everything tasted great, including the rare not-too-sweet green tea ice cream.

I'm going back as soon as I can!
author: Dan S.

description:
I went on a sat night- late like 9:30- it took us 30 min to figure out that it wasn't visible from the street. You'll figure it out when you see this plaza area, go downstairs and Voila!

I am just not a fan of cramped quarters and hearing other peoples conversations or others hearing mine. The place is super small and when there are hella heads in there it gets down right stuffy & hot!! like getting out of a plane in panama in the middle of summer with 90% humidity..gross trust its not fun. ++ i don't like sweating bullets and eating sushi...i refused the free tea in the begining bc it was so hot and all i could see was a little fan for the chefs.

Rolls had cute names like BARBIE and HELLO KITTY and had the typical range of 8-11 bucks. Oh and the service was super fast!!

I did like the sushi it wasn't something that blew me away i'll give this place a go if i see that its kinda empty bc i like the underground *hidden* feel  but i would rather go some place more spacious with A/C
author: Paola L.

description:
I suppose this place might get really crowded and that the waiting might be huuuuuge since it is so tiny and so good, but my husband and I were pretty lucky to get seat at the sushi bar as soon as we arrived.

The waiter was very friendly but again the typical rush with the orders. You barely sit down for 5 minutes and they are already anxious to take your order... 

Anyways, we started with some nigiri that were pretty fresh and yummy. We got albacore (that melted in out mouths), mackerel, eel and yellow tail. The we ordered some rolls: barbie roll, teddy bear and rainbow. All of these were pretty good too.

I would go back to get some of the different rolls that they offer, but would not wait over an hour for it as there are so many great Japanese places in this city.
author: Camila E.

description: This is my back-up spot for when I can't get into Sushi Zone early and don't want to deal with the endless wait.  The quality of the fish is good, but has gone down from the past. Smaller portions as well, while the prices have gone up. I used to look forward to the big and fresh cuts of salmon & albacore here, but not so much anymore. The happy hour specials are still a good value and this is still among the few places that have great mackerel (balanced, smoky and not fishy).
author: Nancy F.

description: One of my favorite sushi bars in the city.  It's a tiny hidden gem sunk low underground and probably seats under 20 people.  The fish is always fresh- I know it should always be fresh, but many places are not so fresh.  I'm a big fan of the home made gyoza- I like the ebi more than the tofu, but both melt in your mouth like butta.  You really can't go wrong with anything you order here.  Again I've had most of the menu and everything is solid every time I go.
author: CHRISTINE L.

description: I took my date here because of the reviews, obviously and she left very satisfied. I chose this place mainly because it is small and it seemed more intimate with the Japanese inspired setting. The service was great and the food was fantastic. We ordered the Spicy Walu Roll, Barbie Roll, and the infamous Crunchy roll. All were very fresh and good. The quality of the rolls just melted in your mouth and you could taste every individual element but came together and created a great experience. I recommend this place to those who want to bring a date or have a party of 4 or smaller. It is located downstairs directed by the SUSHI sign outside. I forgot, the rolls were inexpensive! What can go wrong!
author: John H.

description: Details, details, details... this place is all about the details. From picking your own charming sake cup to the little box your check comes in.  I love the marriage between authenticity and whimsy.
author: Lyndsey J.

description:
This is the best sushi I've had.  It even tops the locally-recommended sushi I had in Tokyo.  Several friends and I frequent Sushi Time at least once a month, and each time we're amazed at the quality of the fish.  The wait staff is insanely nice, attentive, and knowledgable.  And the price is totally fair.  Without drinks and with a small appetite the total comes to $25 or so.  With drinks and a large appetite the worst I've ever done is $40.

I highly recommend the Aji, Hamachi, Barbie Roll, and the Tai Carpaccio.  But everything I've had has been great.

Sushi Time is also a great date spot, because it's tiny and cute with unique character.
author: Alex L.

description: On the outset, it's hard to take a joint with a name like "Sushi Time" seriously....but you should.  I'd heard about this "underground" place before and finally made a trip to check it out.  In this city full of more than it's share of sushi to choose from, this is a solid go-to.  Creative rolls, fresh fish, very affordable.  Bonus: everyone working there is very nice and all said goodbye to us as we were leaving.  It will be time for sushi time again soon!
author: e w.

description:
Cheap, delicious and very fresh fish. Super inexpensive rolls. I really can't say anything bad about this place other than the fact that it needs to be closer to home! Service is very friendly and prompt. I haven't had a bad experience here. Even the "not so great" rolls are good. I almost always hate California rolls, but I'll actually order them here at times. Not "real" sushi, but they are very tasty... did I mention they were cheap? 

Oh, you want to remember that there is something like a $20 minimum if you're going to charge your meal, so keep it in mind!

Definitely check it out if you're in the neighborhood!
author: Anita B.

description:
Tiny Tiny Tiny little place tucked under Market Street, but my new favorite Sushi in the city.  This is NOT the place to take a large group!

A must try is the sake sampler. I was celebrating so I got both of them!  So good and so different from your regular sake experience!

The sushi was very good and I can't wait to go back for more!!

*PS* I went here souly on the recommedation of yelpers!
author: Dangerous T.

description:
I respect Nobu K's discerning reviews, but I have to disagree with him on this place.

We go to Sushi Time all the time because the fish has great flavor, it is really cheap, has cool ambience, and is a hidden gem (maybe not so anymore)...

I love the fresh sushi specials, their nice sake selection, traditional and modern maki. The flavors are always nicely balanced.

remember, sushi time - yes, sushi zone - no. but only if you want real sushi.

favorites:
fresh sardine nigiri when available
barbie roll
hamachi nigiri
spicy tuna (one of the best in SF)
delicious fresh green salad (so rare in SF sushi restaurants)
author: G Z.

description:
OK so there are a few flying gnat things.  And our chef really seemed to be a bit strung out.  But the food was good and plenty of options for vegans and fish lovers.

Mango roll is excellent.  Unagi was really good, but we needed to remind the aforementioned chef about it.  

Good quiet atmosphere, a very tiny out of the way place under the Gym SF.
author: Amy C.

description:
Location/Ambience: Castro - humble people, lots to do, and to add to its quaintness, it is underground! I love the coziness of the restaurant and how it only has about 5 tables and a small sushi bar. It was nicely decorated with traditional Japanese knickknacks and such.

Food: Delicious. They had 4-5 varieties of soup/miso soups (one with clams). They had a delicious 'special rolls' selection of no more than 10 but they would probably all be good. I tried the Speed racer: tuna and mango inside with tobiko outside. Genius to think of putting mango in the roll. It was such a different complimentary taste! Also had the Astro Boy Roll: Spicy scallop, mango, cucumber inside, with tobiko outside. I loved the mango here as well to counter the spiciness of the scallops. I also had red tuna sashimi: very fresh. The menu wasn't overambitious nor overpriced like many other sushi restaurants. If you're looking for overstuffed, huge rolls-don't come here. This place is simple with a twist.

Prices: Ridiculously reasonable. The special rolls average 7-8 dollars and the quality was never compromised. 

Service: Very good. Two waiters. My water and tea cups were never empty.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Really excellent sushi, service, and atmosphere.  The food was absolutely delicious!

The staff was very accomodating and really friendly and nice.. including the sushi chefs.  

The one downside is how small and stuffy this place is.  I guess I don't really mind that it is so small, but it's more the fact that it's very humid and warm in there because of the size.  Needs some ventilation or something.  

You get the feeling that when you leave, your clothes will smell of raw fish (love eating the stuff, but not so much smelling like it).  I considered removing one star because of this, but the incredible tasting sushi and nice staff has me giving them the full on FIVE stars!
author: Chrissy S.

description:
We came during happy hour when the sake was cheap, but a warm buzz in such a small place with little ventilation can really make you burn up. Over the course of the night I tried 7 rolls, and to be honest, I thought they all pretty much tasted the same. Maybe it's the American in me, but the rolls were tiny, therefore hard to distinguish in flavor, especially since I was popping them in like M&M's. 

I did also have some nigiri and sashimi, some of which was okay (hotate, saba), and some of which was really good!! We ordered the  Sashimi 5 happy hour special (3 pieces of white tuna, 2 pieces of salmon, 5 buckaroos) and at least on this night, the white tuna was a real star, very fresh!
author: Christine H.

description:
Good times, Sushi Time.

This place is super cute, warm, cozy, and inviting.  The sushi is tasty (there's tastier, but they do it pretty good here), the staff friendly, and the vibe is warm.  We enjoyed the seasonally excellent albacore nigiri, in addition to a variety of roles.  Seaweed salad also the yummies.

We waited for about 40 minutes, on a Friday night around 8:30pm, but it was worth it.  Prices are right (with tip we were at $22 per person not bad given that we got edamame, two seaweed salads, five rolls, 3 nigiris, and a beer).
author: Jon A.

description:
What is the hype all about?  The food was fine, but after reading all the Yelp reviews I thought I would be amazed.  I didn't mind the 30 minute wait to get seated, but waiting 20 mins to get the waitress to notice us, followed by a 30 minute wait to get our food was unacceptable.

Don't order the tofu dishes, they are not good.  The 10 piece sashimi meal was pretty good (but then lead and asbestos would taste good after waiting a millenium to get our 3 ounces of raw fish).

You want amazing sushi?  Kiss Seafood.  And good luck getting a seat.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
Goodness!  Thanks yelpers - you were right again!  Being four undecisive girls, we always have difficulty settling on a place to eat...thank goodness we all felt like sushi!  This place is cozy with its own brand of charm...def felt at home - esp since the owner was so kind and fatherly to us.  Slightly on the pricey side - we were very satisfied with our dinner.

We ordered the rolls - barbie roll (highly rec), the crunchy roll, the astro roll...The nigiri just melts in your mouth...we couldn't get enough of the hamachi and white tuna...sake was a bit salty for some reason..being a cold day in SF - the miso soups were yummy...just right =)
author: Julie H.

description:
Best Sushi in California.

Or at least the Bay Area.

Seriously.  Check out the underground sushi at Sushi Time.  Very Tokyo authentic (right down to the soundtrack).  Sitting at the bar here is a sushi lovers version of a table dance.

Enjoy!
author: J. Santiago S.

description: This place was good! You'd never see it from the street and it's hidden downstairs, but it's worth finding. The place is tiny, so finding seating can be difficult. There wasn't a table for 3 available (even after a 30 minute wait) so we sat at the bar. The sushi came quickly after we ordered it. A little strange that our soups and other starters came after the sushi, but it was all very tasty.
author: Amy S.

description:
My friend and I were trying to find a new sushi restaraunt to try in the neighborhood, after much research on Yelp I decided to give this place a shot. I was a little weary since I have walked by this little shopping mall several times and saw the sushi sign which made me a little uneasy.

But to my delight it was fabulous! The sashmi was so fresh and melted in your mouth. I also tried the Barbie roll because thats what everyone was raving about and I could defintiley see why.  

The place itself is tiny, but has a very cute design and the staff was super friendly. Needless to say I will defintley be back.
author: Nichole M.

description:
Hole in the wall Japanese place in a nondescript semi-strip mall-ish area.

But damn is this place charming. Its a pretty small and intimate place. I think I only counted 5 or 6 tables (plus the small sushi bar). The entire place probably only seats 25. It reminded me of those small sushi joints in the back alleys of Tokyo, you know, the kinda that serves up the good stuff and not the conveyor belt sushi.

This place would be GREAT for a date, so next time I'm on one (hint hint), I want to come here. Even better if my date's paying since its a little pricier than the usual sushi places I go to. But the sushi is quality, and I'd pay that little extra for the atmosphere. Will DEF be back again!
author: Rocky K.

description: This place is very much a hole in the wall (it is down the stairs and in the middle of a small shopping center off the street),  but quite good and reasonably priced. The sushi dinner, which was about $15 and included a soup and salad, was very good. The restaurant is small, so you should expect to be very close to your neighbors, but given the reasonable prices, good food, and good service, it's worth a trip.
author: Douglas H.

description:
go to happy hour m-f 5-6:30pm! 

wonderful, fresh, big, tasty (not so much rice) sushi!
author: Jennifer D.

description:
I love how tiny this place is. The fact that it only fits about 20 people, makes you feel really exclusive if you are one of the lucky few who got there in time to grab a table. 

The fish is really fresh and the service is very speedy. I forget the name of my favorite roll, but it has unagi, cucumber and cream cheese. yum! def recommend.
author: A K.

description:
My favorite balance of delicious sushi and modest price.

I've been spoiled, being upgraded to various sushi joints by my Japanese girlfriend. I can't go back to the cheap stuff I was eating before. Yet I can't afford the best all the time. Sushi Time is the compromise.

Plus, they're actually Japanese.
author: John K.

description: Crazy long wait while the food was only mediocre. The avocado in the avocado maki wasn't ripe yet. The tofu donburi had way more rice than tofu.  Not worth the 35 minute wait after we settle for a take-out order.
author: Tiffany L.

description: i like this place a lot, but it's really small, which is kinda annoying if you wanna like stretch out a little bit.  The staff was really nice and the sushi was really good thou and that's probably all that matters which is why i gave it a 5.
author: christopher h.

description:
The sudden hail shower tonight drove me underground to this super small sushi place, and the street side happy hour advertisement didn't hurt.

I've been to this location a couple times before, but I think it was a different sushi restaurant back then.  The sushi is good - I like that they place a dab of spicy sauce on top of the spicy tuna rolls instead of mixing it with the tuna.  That way you can still see the integrity of the fish.  The specialty rolls are also tasty because all the fish is pretty fresh.  The ebi gyoza was funky - kinda too sour and wet rag tasting.

The service was friendly enough, especially the guy making the sushi.  Maybe it's because the place is so small, poorly lit, relatively empty, and it was cold and rainy outside, but it made me uncomfortable when the staff would laugh behind the curtain and chatter on in Japanese.  It didn't help that the server handed me a glass of lemony water, and immediately switched it out with another glass after I had a chug.  Maybe that's a Japanese thing, but I doubt it.

The restaurant itself is eclectically decorated with fans, masks, and scrolls.  The music was a bit weird.  During happy hour, it was all Disney songs recreated through whistling, claps, yowling, and other indiscernible sounds.  When happy hour neared its end, the music changed to pop/techno with voice accompaniment.

BTW: There is a $20 minimum credit card charge, and a $7 minimum per person.  So bring cash if you're dining alone and just ducking in for a snack.
author: Vicente G.

description:
I heart underground sushi time. Not only for the sushi but the atmosphere! I was lucky enough to be taken there my first day in San Francisco and I have been back ever since, bringing sf visitors and locals who have never been there. I love the cat samurai wall paper and the weird music (covers) that they play in here, not to mention is like a little gem that someone who has been there has to take you to. I have tried giving directions, yet people can't ever find it. It is also one of my favorite date spots, although after writing this, I doubt I will be able to take one there. Too predictable now.

The sushi is delicious, the seaweed salad is super yummy. I like their Philly rolls and anything wrapped in Mango. The Hamachi Nigiri just melts in your mouth.
