I recommend getting there between 5-7pm which is Sushi Happy Hour where they amazing deals. If you don't want to wait at Sushi Zone but still want to eat great sushi, this is your spot!
author: Javier B.

description:
Ah, my favorite sushi joint ever!  Everything tastes sooo delicious!  From the Philly roll to the California roll, I am hooked on Sushi Time!  The fish is always so fresh, and the service is wonderful.  I love the candle lit ambiance, and the accent of red used in the traditional Japanese style decor.

This is a wonderful sushi bar to go to with friends on a chilly SF night.  Just be sure to down some sake bombs to go with the delicious cuisine!
author: Jacqueline T.

description:
I feel like I am the last one to find out about this place, but I still can't help the excitement. One of the few times where something led up to the hype!  Believe it or not this tiny little place located in what looks like a  strip mall may be the best sushi I have had in San Francisco.

It you're claustrophobic, or impatient this place is probably not for you. If you like very fresh, inexpensive, inventive sushi then you can't miss this place.

The Highlights:
Albocore Tataki Sashimi (Sliced seared white tuna with ponzu sauce)- The fish melted in my mouth and the Ponzu sauce complimented it perfectly.

Astro Boy Roll (spicy scallop, mango, cucumber inside and tobiko outside) - It wasn't really spicy, but the combination of the fresh, sweet mango, the spiciness of the scallop, and the crunch of the cucumber was amazing.

Spicy Tuna Roll (tuna, scallion, cucumber with spicy mayo) - I was apprehensive because I generally hate all things mayo, but this was one of the best spicy tuna rolls I have ever had.

Crunchy Roll (shrimp tempura, bbq eel, avacado, cucumber inside and tobiko with sweet eel sauce outisde) - A pretty standard crunchy roll, but executed absolutely perfectly!

Throw in a seaweed salad, 2 large bottles of Saki,  2 large Sapporo's, 2 incredibly full stomachs, and the bill came out to only $55 dollars. A pretty damn good price for amazing sushi if you ask me.

I guess what I am saying is... Yes! Believe the hype!
author: Ben H.

description:
I really enjoy Underground Sushi Time. That's why I'd prefer you not go, unless you're going with me and then I'd love to go. 

The fish is very fresh. The service is great. You most likely will have to wait. It totally reminds me of being in Tokyo. The urge to drink umeshu is overwhelming.
author: Angela K.

description:
I love this place!  Ok, so its tiny and a bit cramped, but the sushi makes up for it!  The sushi is consistently fresh.  Masa, the owner, is the best.  

You have to get there early on Fridays & Saturdays to beat the crowd.
author: W D.

description:
My top sushi place in San Francisco now. 

I havent had bad sushi in SF yet and most places I have tried are very good; Sushi Time is the best.  The prices are reasonable and selections are vast.

The sashimi tuna was great; succulant and meaty.  The GI Joe roll was tasty with nice texture.  

The Barbie roll was another excellent choice.  

Every roll we tried was flavorful and designed well.  

Great choice for sushi.
author: Torry D.

description:
Great little spot in the Castro. Fish was fresh and the service was attentive, but not pushy.

It's small too! Felt right at "home". I would go there again and it actually feels like you are underground!
author: thrasher b.

description:
Love the location!  It's just not someplace you would think to find a restaurant and that adds to the atmosphere, which is secretive and intimate.

They stick to conventional rolls and they serve quality and yummy sushi.

Go during happy hour and you can have your fill of rolls, sake and/or asahi and not bust your wallet.

A great place and a definite recommend!
author: Stephanie Y.

description: I love Sushi Time -anytime! The fact that it is a tiny little place tucked away in back and down the stairs makes going there even better. The staff are friendly, the food is delicious and good prices.  What more do you need?
author: Denise N.

description: The happy hour specials are terrific.  The wait staff is very friendly.  Go early or expect to have a little wait.  The food is pretty good.  The only reason I won't give it 5 stars is because they might give it a good "wash" at some point. Installing a bug zapper wouldn't hurt either.  All in all, this doesn't prevent me from going.  So 4-stars!
author: Sean W.

description: So, I read all the great reviews for this place and was really psyched to check it out. I was kinda disappointed, it was really pricey and the portions were on the small side. That being said, they did crank out some tasty sushi, the Barbie roll is a must have if you go here. Unfortunately the overall tasty-ness of the meal does not make up for the skimpy portions and high price. I've had equally good sushi for a better price and more of it. My advice:  skip this place and find better sushi in the city, there's a lot out there.
author: Beatriz A.

description: This hidden gem in the Castro is truly worth a visit if you're looking for delicious and inexpensive sushi. It's very small, but there's not much of a wait.
author: Greg B.

description:
Sushi Time is a great, super clean, ultra delicious neighborhood spot for some great sushi.

The Barbie Roll can change your life if you let it.

The service is extremely friendly and attentive and the atmosphere is great for conversation.
author: Matt O.

description:
Sorry Sushi Zone. Sushi Time may be my favorite spot to get sushi.
God Damn perfect for a date! I can't stress that enough. It's small, but not crowded. Fast, but the sushi is fresh and flippin' great. I slid in on a Friday night with the lady friend at 8 ish and grabbed a table right away. Hard pressed to find a spot better than this.
author: Lou Z.

description:
yum yum yum.

I have been to a few sushi places close by and this one was so great.  Very reasonable prices, Very cute interior, nice service, and the food was so great.  We had the seared tuna sashimi with ponsu sacue.  I am still craving more of that.  I will be back soon!  Also the roll with the unagi and avacado was great as well, and very pretty. it was fairly late so we got right in and seated instantly.
author: Jocie H.

description:
A hidden gem in a strange building, which I suspect looked really good as an architectural model -- business street frontage with a hollow core wrapped in retail and office spaces peering out across the void.

The sushi is superb. Tuna bowl gets 6 stars - fresh and delicious - strange observation, but this place has the best tasting sushi rice I've ever had.

The atmosphere is terrific, featuring incredibly good music that gives it a fun edginess (which this totally unpretentious joint otherwise avoids). Service is complete if a bit slow. But it's nothing to complain about, as long as you're not in a rush. 

I went with a friend last night around 8 and we closed it down, sipping bottomless cups of green tea long after paying our bill.

Skip the hour plus wait at Sushi Zone and stroll down Market next time you've got a hankering.
author: Jonah C.

description:
I feel like it's a 3.5 star. I wish we could give 1/2 a star. why can't i?! 

the staff and chef are really nice. it's a tiny hole in the wall place. if you can't find it, it's in this weird plaza that is next to Books Inc. you the stairs in the back. although, it's a tiny little tunnel, you can leave your phone number with them to roam where you want instead of just waiting there. 

the tuna-avocado looked so good in the picture on the website and yelp but wasn't as yummy as i expected.  i thought i was going to have this piece of tuna with avocado just melting in my mouth = no, wrong. the tuna didn't melt. we got the rainbow roll, ika, smoke sake, maguro, and ako. overall, it's was fair - nothing exceptional. all of that with an iced tea, seaweed salad, and a miso soup cost us $43 + tip. so it's not too bad.

you can make ask conversation with people we seat at the bar also. everyone just seem super friendly at the place. love it. 

food = 3. 
staff = 4.
author: Jocelyn T.

description:
Good sushi, nice employees, little cozy environment.

AND! it's not that expensive.. so very niiiiiceee.
author: Shine W.

description:
Sushi Underground is lovely. They will pour your nigori in a glass. The chefs are friendly and smile. The fish is real good. The place is tiny and off the street. It will get full because it is yummy, but it does not tend to get as crazy packed as the other good sushi places that are more accessible.

Happy hour!
author: Yes P.

description:
I'm still a little on the fence about this place.  The major upside for me is that it's a stone's throw from my front door, but if I lived any farther than a few blocks, I'd say stop reading now and just don't go.

The sushi is good, not great, but definitely not bad.  They've got a couple interesting rolls and appetizers - but again, nothing to write home about.  It is a small place, and by small I mean about the size of a shoebox, so it's cozy but definitely not good for parties larger than 3.

The highlights are the Happy Hour (5-6:30pm everyday) which offers *slightly* discounted appetizers, rolls and sake.  Also, they brew their hot tea to order, which I think is a nice touch.  Service is also notably friendly and prompt.

Bottom line:  If you're in the hood and need some sushi that won't break the bank (though maybe not wow you), Sushi Time's your joint.
author: Amanda K.

description:
Sushi Time is a hidden gem in the Castro District.  It is underground in a shopping plaza, if you weren't looking for it you would surely miss it.  This place has the most delicious and one of the MOST fresh sushi that I have ever eaten!  We ordered the 6 piece sashimi appetizer as well as their special Albacore Nigeri and all the sashimi was not only fresh, but fat and buttery.  We also ordered a number of rolls that also shared the same quality.  Their rolls are a bit small so I would suggest ordering more than you think you would eat.  

The staff was very friendly and attentive which only added to the entire dining experience.  If you are looking for a place that serves strictly delicious and fresh sushi, you need to try this place!
author: Frances L.

description: This place has fresh fish, awesome chefs, friendly staff, and great prices.  Best of all, they're actually Japanese!!!  It was the perfect place to go on a Wednesday night with no wait, no crowds, but good dining experience.  It's small so I I would try to avoid going on a Friday or Saturday night.
author: Nina L.

description: Wow!  I walked by the sign for Sushi Time everyday on my way to and from work.  I never would have thought to go inside or give it a try because it's in a back mall-ish area that is "very understated" to say the least.  Thankfully my friend brought me here and I was very pleasantly surprised.  The place is SMALL so we had to wait a bit for a table, but it wasn't too bad.  We had their housemade shrimp gyoza and miso soup to start, both were good but I liked the sushi better.  I forget the names of some of the rolls we had... definitely had a rainbow roll and a few others with interesting names like GI Joe.  The sushi was excellent and great quality.  I've been craving it every night since I went.  Highly recommended!
author: Jen F.

description:
I went to this place because Eiji was closed last week.

Rolls/Makis are really good and fresh, with some original yet tasty options.
I had one of their dinner (San Syoku Don) and was a bit disappointed. the sashimi pieces were a bit too big compared to what sushi or sashimi should be. Fish was fresh and tasty... it was just not the best one I've had.

Overall, it's a good place, and eating there is nicer than in other Japonese restaurants. But for sashimis, if Eiji is open, I would go there first!
author: Pascal L.

description:
I'd walked by this place dozens of times and never thought about eating here even though I really like sushi. But when walking by with a friend about a week ago, we decided that we'd try this underground place next time we wanted sushi in the Castro area.

So, after cocktail hour today, 5 of us went to Sushi Time not realizing how small the place is--probably less than 300 square feet--and all the tables were taken.

But there were 5 seats in a row open at the sushi bar and that's a good thing because we could watch the 2 cordial and professional chefs turn out works of art including wonderful dinners for us.

There was only one waiter, so the service was a bit slow, but he did a fine job considering the demands placed on him. This is a very friendly place and reminded me of the small sushi restaurants in which I ate while in Japan for a couple of weeks in late 2005.

I had the G.I. Joe Roll and the Rainbow Roll which made a great combination. They were beautiful to look at and delicious to eat--I'd go back to this restaurant and would recommend it to anyone who's a sushi-lover.

I suppose that if we'd had a table or if the stools at the sushi bar had backs on them, my back would have ached less and I'd award 5 stars instead of 4. 

For great sushi made and served by friendly people, try this place if you haven't already. It's a real gem in the Castro area.
author: IQuack D.

description:
I don't usually like sushi, its just not my style. But for some reason this place rocks my world. I have no idea how they get the sashimi to taste so much fresher than any other place. Sushi Time is possibly the smallest restaurant I have ever eaten in. And the one waiter always seems a little over-worked. But hey the overhead is low and the food is delicious.

P.S.  - The dark dingy entrance keeps out annoying sushi snobs who are the ones who ruin most of the "nicer" joints for me.
author: Shaun W.

description:
This is like giddy-making good. Seriously. I don't know how else to put it. Everything tastes like you've never even had sushi before. And we didn't even wait for a table on a Friday night. And, the two of us had sake and beer, maybe 4 rolls total (3 of them specials), a seaweed salad each, and walked out of there for like $60. Amazing. 

Don't expect the speediest of service--there's only one guy working the (tiny) floor. It's OK, the food will be so good you won't care.
author: Sue M.

description:
Shh, don't tell my neighborhood sushi place this but I think I've fallen in love with Sushi Time.

It's underground, exuding genuineness by it's small size, friendly staff, and random music.  The food is almost always solid, with tasty and reasonable Udon soup prices and creative sushi rolls.  The Unagi is amazing and while I'm not a fan of their California Rolls (but then again, who is :), their seaweed salad is one of the best I've had.

Minus one star for their minimum per person and credit card charges - haven't they read their merchant agreement to know this is not kosher?  Otherwise, for sushi and good, wholesome soup, this is the place to go.
author: A K.

description:
This is my go-to sushi joint--always fresh, solid nigiri and rolls.  The GI Joe is always a hit when I bring friends.  And everything from the basic yellowtail to the more exotic sea urchin and octopus are fresh and seriously tasty.  Did I mention fresh?

I love the shoebox atmosphere and they've always got the coolest tunes playing; feels like a slice of hipster Tokyo with an undertone of speakeasy. 

Don't neglect the sake list - but my inside tip is that the first one on the list (and, incidentally, the cheapest) is the way to go.  Love it.
author: Marie S.

description:
Just had an intimate dinner here and it was aesthetically pleasing on all counts!

The sushi tastes very fresh, and along with the classics they have some really good special rolls. I recommend the Barbie and the Speed Racer. One of them is salmon with a bunch of things and mango- I know, awesome.

The restaurant's got a whole subway station look going on- tiny, tucked away below ground level off the street. I haven't been to Japan but looking at some other reviews I guess that's what it's like for real.

The whole experience is in such close quarters that it feels cozy, like a little hiding place from the crazy city outside. Great food, nice people and pleasing to the senses!
author: Gautam J.

description:
cozy wonderful hidden location

super close to my house

affordable prices, and good options for my veggie friends

delicious, beautiful, well-made, and fresh!  i come here at least once a week!
author: Dora F.

description:
I have been here about 5 times. I've ordered the california roll, barbi roll, rainbow roll and spicy tuna roll. ALL of them were really tasty. The edemame is warm and salty. YUM! 
Its really cozy and cheap. It's my fave local sushi hangout place.
Everyone is really friendly there, too. That always makes a difference.
author: Jimi G.

description: Decor nice but space wise terrible it reallllyyyy small and hard to find. Wait time was decent the server are at hand. Food is good, rolls were pretty good, miso soup decent well seasoned, shashimi was fresh and good portion to fill you up.
author: Angie N.

description:
The tuna tartar with avocado and asparagus has me coming back again and again.  Get some edamame and some warm sake and enjoy the cozy atmosphere. 

I also like the bbqed eel ...I think its the rock and roll.  If you don't mind your fish being cooked, and are a sucker for the sauce as much as you are for good fish, then this is the roll for you. I also like that the spicy tuna is spicy sauce with tuna, not mashed up tuna that's probably old with some sauce to hide the lack of freshness.  Sooo small, but lovely.
author: Jessa L.

description:
no joke, the sushi rolls were so fresh. fish melting in the mouth. happy hour (5pm-6pm) offers 4 dollar sushi rolls, 4 dollar large, warm sake, and 3 (or 4?) dollar large asahi beer. 

all in all, my boyfriend and i had 6 rolls total: barbie roll, kamikaze roll, astro boy roll, rock n' roll, and 2 alaskan rolls. HIGHLY recommend the barbie, alaskan, and astro boy. both very fresh, and the astro boy was pretty spicy.

in total, 2 large beers, 1 large warm sake, and 6 rolls totaled out to $62 AFTER a $10 dollar tip. very well priced, ALMOST every roll is under $10. loved this place, definitely coming back!
author: Cristal F.

description:
I felt like I had walked into Captain Nemo's submarine after climbing down the stairs and entering this small sushi restaurant. 

It's definitely as cramped as a submarine, but instead of having the fish swim around on the outside, here they are deliciously sliced up and just melt in your mouth (OK, that might have been just a bit of a macabre picture to paint - I'll go and apologize to the fish in my aquarium right now).

However, both the salmon and the hamachi nigiri were the best I've had so far here in the City, the specialty rolls were also great, and the service was very friendly. 

The only problem I encountered was when I had ordered take out. Instead of the seaweed salad I had asked (and got charged) for, I only found a tiny green salad in the bag when I got home. 

But as fantastic as their sushi is, it would take a lot more than that to keep me from coming back to this place.
author: Nucnuc M.

description: Seriously good sushi.  No lie. We get this for take out on nights like tonight...when the city is covered with fog and we just want to relax at home.  Fresh, fresh friendly service, ready in 20 minutes and always tasty.  If they have uni (which they didn't tonight, wahhh) it's fresh and scrummy.  The rolls are also fabulous here and they are a good size, not too big but not too small either...def enough for the starving couple.  I highly recommend this place for dine in or take away.  YES. FIVE MOTHERHUMPING STARS.
author: Claire C.

description: Ate here once and have been dying to go back. I LOVE Japanese food and frequent Japan. This place is like a hidden jewel in the Castro. Went for dinner with a friend and fell in love. I love eel and the Unagi Don was amazing. Also, the gyoza was fabulous. The rolls were americanized but, definitely worth it. I love the funky names too. Makes it extra special.
author: Aabid K.

description: Tiny spot at Castro. Almost missed it. Food is okay but not enough variety for me. I came there alone before the rush hour so I was seated right away. If not, I'll be pissed waiting for the food that I rated as an okay food only
author: Cliff T.

description: Decent prices, fresh fish. Interesting location makes for a fun, underground vibe. The barbie roll was my favorite.
author: m t.

description: THIS PLACE is the real deal.  Fresh fish, great sake (you even get to choose your own glass!) and such a weird and spiffy location.  Given the choices in the area, it is either here or Eiji for me (for a more quiet, lowkey experience.)
author: Aaron W.

description:
Sushi Time is my favorite time on earth!!  

Food:  5 stars, including good-sized veggie dish selection
Seating:  5 stars because it's so intimate and clean and stylish
Service:  5 stars because the waiters are so attentive, expert on the menu, and cuuuuute
Music:  5 stars due to the always unusual always excellent music
Price:  5 stars as it's excellent, well-priced, delicious food

Is it Sushi Time yet??  Is it is it is it???
author: Quality T.

description: So good I kinda don't wanna review it! Tiny hole in the wall place by Ike's in the Castro. The sushi was super fresh and fun. The barbie roll and the astro boy roll are my fav's. But their butterfish sashimi was amazing! I think we ordered a cucumber salad as well that we never got but oh well...good sushi. It can be sushi time all the time!!
author: Marianne s.

description: Sushi Time is super delicious and super tiny. Go at 5:00 for happy hour -- you can fill up on discount sushi and drinks for $20 or less pp. But this place is couples' skate only. Do not call your friends to meet you here unless you don't mind not sitting together.
author: Kely G.

description:
I'm gun ho for the GI Joe!  Seriously the best roll I've ever had -- the avocado melts in your mouth.  We had the Astro Boy & the Speed Racer which were delicious, but we actually ordered another GI Joe because we fell in love!  Who knew a military style roll could be so tender!

Don't be discouraged by the totally random "Sushi" sign with an arrow under the gym - it looks sketchy, but it's actually a secret little gem tucked away from Market St.  There are very few tables, but we had one within 5 minutes & the service was quite good.

Totally worth the trip down the stairs!
author: blondiepopps p.

description:
always good and always filling.. 
astro boy roll is something i am a fan of.
the service is really good as well.

thank you sushi time.
author: Elliott G.

description: I think I passed by this place a zillion times assuming it was cheap and sketchy because of the sign & weird location.  Thanks to Yelp I finally stopped by a few months ago and have been back three times already!  I like the unassuming character of the place, the fact that you can place an order to go and it's ready within 15-20 minutes, and most of all that the sushi is as fresh as it is in some of the nicest places.  I like to think of their Barbie Roll as a dressed-down version of the Best roll at Koo (one of my favorite spots, in Inner Sunset).  They have some pretty creative rolls here too, a bunch with mango that are pretty good one with spicy butterfish - neat!
author: Danna G.

description: Sushi Time serves really fresh fish. What else can you ask for in a sushi joint? The barbie roll was my favorite but every other roll I tasted was scrumptious. Our table of four completely filled up (and enjoyed two bottles of sake) for $100.00, including tax and tip. Gotta love quality sushi for a reasonable price! 1 less star because of the size of this place. It's tiny, fits maybe 16 and they won't seat you without your whole party present so when my friends were late I was sweating the fact that we might lose the only 4 person table left. Thankfully they arrived 2 minutes before the next party. I was starving, I may have eaten the fish in the bowl on the counter.
author: Sam M.

description:
Welcome to hamachi nirvana.

What a great little (and I mean little) establishment.

There's only room for about 16 guests at a time...but if you come a little late in the evening, as I did, this really isn't an issue.

So...about the hamachi.
Clean, creamy, white, melt -in-your-mouth bites of nigiri bliss.
I'm pretty picky about my hamachi...and Sushi Time's was excellent.

The menu is pretty traditional of sushi restaurants here in the Red White & Blue...but without all the hip fodder of designer rolls. They have a short list of house rolls...but they tend to stick to the basics.

Aside from the hamachi, we had maguro and the spicy yellowtail roll. Both delicious.

The bill was totally reasonable.

I'll be back, Sushi Time...I'll be back!
author: Sonia P.

description: This cozy sushi spot was one of those places that I had desperately hoped would stay under the radar because I selfishly want it to myself. Even when I ate here for the first time a couple years ago, me and my girlfriend at the time refused to write a review on Yelp to help keep it under cover. Well, now it's blown open and everyone knows about this secret little spot. Most of the time the rolls and sashimi here are great for a little weeknight dinner on the cheap. I like that it's tucked away underground and has roughly four and a half tables and a cool little sushi bar. Not necessarily a date place so much as a fun little spot to make it sushi time with a friend.
author: Michael E.

description: Been here a twice now and it was a 4 star the first time, 5 star the second.  The sushi is fresh and just plain good.  The place is just great.  Small, feels super authentic and just a great date place or small party.  Everyone who works there is super friendly and happy to have you in their world.  So if you like a cool place + some of the best sushi in san francisco + a really great price (3 of us ate and drank for $90 bucks) then Sushi Time is should be your new sushi place.
author: Jessica M.

description: My favorite sushi spot in the city located in a shopping mall in the Castro district and that's saying something bc I hardly leave my neighborhood (russian hills/cow hollow). When you walk in you feel as if you were transported to Tokyo just for this. So many varieties of sake and tea. The fish is SO fresh, Tai carpaccio is my favorite (HIGHLY RECOMMEND) , with the shrimp gyoza coming in second. They have such a variety of fish that it makes for a unique and fun experience when choosing rolls. I go for my normal salmon sashimi, spicy tuna, hamachi and usually get a more fancy roll to go with it also. It IS small, so if you're not into the kind of place where you can make friends with the (nicest) sushi chef and have a few drinks with him, then this isn't for you.  Another great thing about this place  is if it's packed, they'll give you a time frame and you leave your number and can have a drink at the near-by bar or just hang out (if you don't drink or feel like it) while you wait. Lastly, they have great miso soup. We've taken a few friends from out of town (LA) and they were more than impressed. The prices are great, we're never disappointed with our meals, the ambiance is fun. All around great place to eat.
author: Audrey A.

description:
we ordered the following rolls (listed in the order of the rolls i liked, best being on top):
1. bincho
2. barbie 
3. alaskan
4. crunchy
5. spicy scallop
6. futomaki

i'm not a big fan of eel, but the bf is, and he really really liked the crunchy roll.  this place surprised me with their very fresh and tasty fish.  the menu is small and pretty much just fish (no teriyaki, chicken karagge, temperua, etc).  at first i was disappointed with the small menu as i didn't think i'd like most of the rolls (either boring or i didn't like the fish), but i think it's just because i've been to too many bad sushi places.  i had raw scallops once at this buffet, and it completely turned me off to it, but man, this spicy scallop roll was delicious (only if it wasn't so spicy)!

oh, they also use real crab meat instead of imitation crab meat, and it makes a huge difference (because i hate the "imitation crab meat with too much mayo" you often get at sushi places).
author: H. L.

description: Where has this place been??!! I love it! Why can't I give it 10 stars??? Amazing melt in your mouth sushi and sashimi at fairly reasonable prices. Fantastic specials! Fresh bottled Sapporo (not flat, like some places that serve you bottled stuff that's clearly been sitting on a shelf). Quirky, almost Harajuku-esque atmosphere. Nice waiters. And tiny, like most Tokyo restaurants. I'm in love with this place. I hope other people don't find out about this soon. But I secretly do.
author: Suepattra M.

description: I live a block away and can't get enough of SUSHI TIME!!! Not only is the food fantastic, Masa keeps you happy, Robert pumps out the goodies and you can't beat the tunes: Japanese covers of trashy American music. I keep threatening to bring my laptop in so I can rip it. But back to the food...sushi, sashimi, nigiri...yummy, yummy, yummy. If you can get there early, their happy hour can't be beat. I've never been to Sushi Zone and with Sushi Time so close, I don't think I will.
author: Sig N.

description: All i Have to say is WTF?!  I was there for lunch today.  Was the regular chef at home napping for the dinner crowd?  The rolls were sloppily prepared and presented.  There was too much rice.  The fish was fine, but very little compared to the rice.  The roll selection at lunch was silly small.  No, this place is worthy of 2 stars max.  Go elsewhere.
author: Justin M.

description:
the happy hour special got me! ok sushi, some nice surprises.

FOOD:~astro boy roll: pretty good!

~rock n roll roll: really good when warm!!

~spicy tuna: tasted a little old. they use the old fish for spicy tuna, the spicy sauce covers the taste.

DECOR: cool!!! tiny underground tokyo vibe.

SERVICE: a little overworked, but nice.

BATHROOM: outside, a little gross cuz semi-public access.

OVERALL: would go if in the neighborhood & need cheap sushi. not really a destination.
author: miss b.

description: Of all the many sushi places in the area, this is the one to be a regular at. Small place, for sure, but on weekdays the wait is rarely long and the sushi is always excellent. Awesome atmosphere and very affordable, fresh, sushi. I love the specialty rolls with crab salad in the inside ... try the rainbow roll or barbie roll, both amazing.
author: Nate C.

description: This is the best sushi I've eaten in the US (my family is from Japan). When the chef says the tuna is good BELIEVE HIM. Went here for our anniversary last night and while my boy and I ordered a couple of things, we decided to leave the majority of the meal in the hands of the chef. When your meal ends in something unexpected but surprisingly pleasant like mango rolls and is filled with delicate touches like just the right amount of wasabi on nigiri to open up your palate, you know you've found a good one. I'll be back to this little place. Good memories from a wonderful night!
author: Shawna S.

description: Great place to meet  a friends and catch up over some great food and tasty sake. The place is really small, 4 in your party is the max.
author: Lilia R.

description:
This tiny 'underground' sushi bar is tucked back on Market in the Castro and unless you really looked or made a wrong turn you probably wouldn't find it. It's small, funky, and makes you feel like you are in a small crazy joint in an anime.  We had been on an all day food finding fest (this was our last stop for the night) so we didn't order much but what we did try was melt in your mouth wonderous. We ordered the barbie roll (I love how San Francisco understands the importance of thin lemon when you are eating salmon..), a california roll topped with eel and avocado with a drizzle of eel sauce, and a 2 piece albacore sushi. The eel was delicious but this roll in particular had a bit much rice for my liking - the bottom of the pieces were very dense making it a bit gummy. The albacore was melt in your mouth - it was literally just falling away from itself kind of tender. The service was mediocre but there was only one person running the tables and such but it sucks to sit and watch your sushi just waiting for someone to whisk it away at the bar (yet another reason I hate sitting at tables at sushi restaurants).  I would totally come back and see if I could convince them to do some custom sushi.

Oh and the prices are fantastic
author: Natalie G.

description: The sushi is great the rolls are not this biggest but the prices are good. I recommend getting a roll with mango in it. There is not much room and you might have to wait a few minutes for seating like I did.  The underground environment  makes it feel like your a ninja. I highly recommend this place for the good prices.
author: Steven G.

description:
We went to sushi time after researching places to go on yelp and WOW. Excellent sushi, excellent service. After reading all the reviews and concluding it was a small restaurant, I was a bit nervous about bringing my 18 month old as small restaurant equals less room for noise to disperse. But I was willing to take that risk to have good sushi. We went early, around 6 as to try to avoid the dinner crowd. We were only one of two tables but by the time we finished the place had all but filled up. 

The sushi was so fresh and delicious. We tried the astro boy and barbie roll on the recommendation of other yelpers and were not disappointed. The lemon slices on the roll were so flavorful but not overwhelming. 

Sometimes when sashimi is not fresh, it either tastes slimy or watery like someone washed it off but their sashimi was so fresh, flavorful, and beautifully prepared. The uni was sooo fresh and delicious as was the grilled yellow tail collar. 

There were two servers manning tables and they were very attentive and accommodating to us with our baby, we really appreciated that! The small venue actually gave it a more intimate cozy feel.
author: T R.

description: This was a perfect place to grab sushi happy hour with my pal that lives in the neighborhood. The service was a bit slow in the beginning. I needed to flag down the server a few times.It was friendly tho. The location is small but central. The aji was the highlight for me. The fish was fresh, beer was cold and the price was right.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Who would have thought an underground sushi joint would have traditional and quality tasting sushi.  Unlike most restaurants that have unique rolls, theirs are limited to the conventional.  The atmosphere is intimate and cozy, so if you're not claustrophobic I recommend you try it out.
author: Suzanne C.

description:
A hidden lil'sushi joint, hard to find, but once you do, you'll probably come back.

While it is TINY, it walks the fine line between no wait and crowded. Friendly people behind the bar, the music is always something fun, and the fish is always tasty.
author: Kaveh A.

description: This is one of my favorite sushi houses. The seafood is fresh and delicious. They have a great happy hour with discounts on some of their regular menu items. The rolls are incredible and the staff is very friendly. The place is very small, so getting a table can be difficult at times. I suggest getting there early. Enjoy!~
author: Jon P.

description: Wow, not impressed.  And I know my beloved Yelpers love this place.  True, I didn't try the highly heralded mango sushi (I'm sorry but I'm a purist) but what I did try was really average.   Prices are cheap and the atmosphere cozy and fun, but neither made up for the less than impressive food.
author: Shannon M.

description: Unassuming but very cool place! First of all the sushi is GREAT! Melt in your mouth and full of flavor great. The service was spot on. My tea was refilled regularly and without my asking. The place was packed when I was there, and they were keeping up with everyone. The decor is funky and fun and the music plays at appropriate decibel levels and totally fit. Prices were very fair. A good time was had by all.
author: L P.

description:
please don't come here. the sushi is phenomenal and the service is top notch. i had never had mango with sushi before; they popped my cherry.  this small restaurant only has room for me & my unstoppable cravings for raw fish so back the fuck off.

:]
author: Lizzy L.

description: Love the service here. And the weird urban mall locale - feels very much like a set out of chungking express. Save yourself confusion by entering at the restaurant-level off 16th st. As for the sushi -- 4 (but not 5) stars. Sashimi is delicious, but at Sushi Time one or two fish will take the day -- unlike other sushi spots around town, where each bite is a flavor trip. Rolls are average for SF. But the price is perfect. Cold beers, and warm environs. Excellent local sushi spot.
author: N K.

description:
sometimes life hands you lemons and you make lemonade sometime life hands you lemons and they get into a cut in your hand and hurt like hell... "

thought that this night was gonna be the painful variety. initially tried to go somewhere else first, but could not get in. looked around at some other places on market for sushi and than a sign out of blue (or i guess a red sign on a wall) said sushi.

in we walk into what appears to be the holistic mall from hell. tanning booths and vitamins and workout equipment and inside what appears to be a greenhouse was some really really really awesome sushi!!!

sushi time is one of those places that make me smile when i look around this city cause the food is good(buttery buttery well made sushi) booze is good(lots of sake to choose from) and really friendly people. also they played a song by the knife(not intentional i am sure) and even when my girlfriends second round of maki took a bit, they were really apologetic and it was a genuine apology which is very refreshing. 

overall great experience i only give 4 stars cause i am not much of a sushi expert and maybe there is better, but i usually only eat vegetables so not too familiar. i do know good times and good service and this was it.
author: Chris G.

description: This is the cutest sushi joint! Nice menu, fair prices, friendly people. I would be here all the time if I lived in San Fran. They aren't kidding when they say the place is small though...
author: Andrea S.

description:
so i've walked past this place for years...afraid to go in 
1. because it's downstairs
2. because it's in a strip mall
3. because it's downstairs in a strip mall with other stores that  appear to exude medicoracy
so, i'm glad when a friend of mine actually MADE me go in and eat there. what a surprise, what a find. everything on the menu is amazing & fresh. i'm a sworn convert and find myself going back time and time again. 
plus i love seeing my friends faces full of hesitation when i drag them down to this place  and assure them, "yes, this is actually where we are dining tonight." i guess looks really can be decieving. 
but shh, don't tell because this place hasn't gotten as ridiculous as sushi zone (& it's better).
author: deborah g.

description: I love this place.  Been walking by it for years and never gave it a second thought due to its weird location.  Finally went a few months ago.  The sushi is great.  Very fresh and tasty.  The place is very Japanese...kinda reminds me of the types of places you'd find in Tokyo...small, cramped, and oddly cute.  I pretty much stick to the basics and have yet to try the, uh, hello kitty roll and such.  And the prices are super reasonable for the quality.
author: Eric C.

description: I am not really that big of a Sushi Fan but I was at this place last night with my gf and a few other friends and it was a great experience. The place is tiny but the food they server is simpley AWESOME. We ordered all kinds of rolls along with some sashimi, cabarnet and hot sake and also Miso soup. The spicy yellow tail rolls were my favorite but I tried pretty much all of them and everything was really good. The service was great and it wasn't pricey at all for a sushi. I would totally go there again
author: Vik P.

description:
You ever get the feeling that there are two dimensions with one single doorway? If ever there was a fantastic example of such, it would be (Underground) Sushi Time. The reviews I read before setting my heart on  Sushi Time made me believe I was either in for amazing sushi, or mediocre dirty sushi, and nothing inbetween. 

When I walked through the doorway, I thought I was in Japan. A tiny five table place with maybe eight seats at the bar, all lined up in one tiny, packed area, rounded windows, underground -- says it all. The lights were dimly lit, and I was half expecting an andriod to seat me. We got a table because it was our first time and we were just going to get a couple of rolls to taste (I typically like to sit at the bar). The very first thing I noticed about the bar was that it is no high concept piece of art like the other sushi bars I'd been to in San Francisco. This was mainly traditional sushi with the addition of a select few specialty rolls. Well, I'm a sucker for mixing, so I went for the special rolls. They were absolutely fantastic, especially one topped with Albacore, which literally melted in my mouth. I knew I needed to eat more, so I get a two piece Albacore sushi, which proceded to also melt in my mouth. I had not had tuna the likes of melt since Enshino back in Encino, and I knew then and there that I really could get accustomed to this place. The service was not fantastic, but I would absolutely opt for sitting at the bar next time. I will be back, of course to check on its consistency, but it's a couple more visits away from five stars, no doubt.
author: Shannon F.

description: Dunno why this place is not 5 stars!!! Just tried 4 rolls, gyoza, miso and ice cream and everything was just amazing - melted in my mouth!!!
author: Alex L.

description: Fresh fish - even on a Monday! Loved the astro boy (spicy scallops). Love that it's a tiny, under ground hole in the wall - just like I imagine Tokyo :)
author: Mia M.

description: Secluded in a small shopping center in the Castro, this place has probably eluded many. Expect good rolls with reasonable prices. Hot sake a must. Small and intimate without many tables, but I've never had to wait long to get one.
author: Andrew K.

description:
i'm a vegetarian AND i'm relatively new to sushi, period.

so i always get vegetarian rolls n' such, but i've been here twice in one month already, which should go to say SOMETHING.

i love the atmosphere in this place.  it's small, but you don't have to worry about being loud with your friends.  sometimes your neighboring tables will even join in on your merriment.

in terms of fish, my friends raved that for the price, it was some seriously good stuff.

all in all, five stars for ambiance, freshness, good veggie options, and all-around good times had here.

ohh... and the sake is delicious.  i'm not crazy about the sweet unfiltered stuff... we got some tasty hot filtered sake and i guzzled it down like nobody's business.  Mmmmmmm.
author: Beccie F.

description:
great sushi. this is where my friends and i went immediately after getting our lips tattooed. i wouldn't trust mcdonalds for a post-lip-tattoo meal, but sushi time made the grade.

nice, cozy spot where the staff has good attitudes. i like it.
author: Jason D.

description: I'm so glad my friends and I found this great place (thanks to yelp!). Everything we ate was amazing and the owner was so sweet. I'll definitely be craving their tuna tataki and mango roll again soon.
author: Rachel S.

description:
there's a difference between a hole-in-the-wall hidden gem, and a place that's just. . .a really small place.  i should note that my review isn't really an absolute scale-- sushi time was undeniably delicious and i'm pleased to have found it so near the mission, where the dearth of sushi is apparent, but i don't think sushi time lives up to the reviews it's been given.

first of all, with an hour wait on a tuesday, it's definitely not hidden.  second of all, while the butter fish and aji nigiri specials were excellent, i was a little disappointed by the tuna avocado tartare and the snapper carpaccio.  the tuna tartare had a pretty distinct dressing (?  dressing?  sauce?  marinade?  i dunno what you call the thing you toss the tartare in) i think it also used a lot of olive oil, which i don't think belongs-- just too strong a flavor to go with raw fish.  i was just tasting olive oil the whole time.  the snapper carpaccio tasted ok, but the portion was disappointing, and the diced red and green bell pepper accoutrement made it look like a christmas fiesta or something.  tiny fish slivers having a sad christmas fiesta in the basement of a church before the AA meeting starts.  also, the tsukune is no longer on the menu.  (and may i recommend, if you cannot make it to aburiya kinnosuke in new york, that izakaya with the raw chicken in berkeley as a replacement.)

this was pretty harsh, since i'm totally planning on going to sushi time again, i just want to temper your expectations over what's been shown here.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
I think this place is actually called "Underground Sushi Time" but that's beside the point. Came here last night with a friend (read, ex) to talk about some future business stuff we had to work out. The place was a little hard to find. You have to go into a little strip mallesque thing, go down a flight of stairs, look for the sign and you're there. The place is small but we were able to be seated right away. If you go here I highly recommend the Tai Carpaccio, it was hands down excellent. We ordered a number of different rolls including the Bochi roll, Barbie roll and I think one other. The Barbie roll was really good, the Bochi wasn't really my style. Neither of them out shined the Carpaccio though. The best part of this place had to be the prices I think we ordered three different kinds of rolls (2 of them specialties) the Carpaccio, and drinks for two with it only coming out to 55 bucks with tax and tip. They also gave us free edamame! 

Service was really good as well. The guy always made sure our water was full and that we were taken care of. He saw my friend put her jacket on and pretty much immediately came over and asked if she was to cold and would like the door closed. 

Don't know if this place would be so great for a large group but for 2 or 3 people I'd put this place pretty high on the list of sushi joints in the city.
author: Tommy P.

description:
how good does it feel when only half way through your dinner you realize that you are about to unleash the praise that should, with regard to posterity and respect, only be uttered once a year? and how much better does it feel when you know that you are at the very final moments before sputtering out this praise - this honor that is bestowed but ONCE A YEAR - and it's only the 5th week of the year?!?!?! yes, it's true: SUSHI TIME IS MY NEW FAVORITE PLACE! take that 2007!

-flavorful, fresh fish
-creative maki and appetizers [the tuna/avocado tartar is ri-DONK]
-attentive, friendly small [only 2 guys last night] staff
-very warm! yes, i love to eat and not freeze at the same time. this should not be as weird as it apparently is...
-great music
-well priced ~$5-$9/roll

only seats about 20 peeps, so be ready for a wait - but it is, oh, so worth it.

my recommendations:

astro boy roll: spicy scallop, mango, et al.
barbie roll: california topped with salmon and lemon
shiso tako: perfectly tender octopus with minty-basily shiso leaf 
avocado/tuna tartar - very fresh with a 'bite' of perhaps yuzu and garlic(?)
author: Joanna R.

description: I think this place has the best avocado maki I've ever had, there was something pleasantly...more...about it than anywhere else. It's a cozy little spot tucked in what you think is a strip mall basement, but they've done up the interior with some great decor; you can really tell it's the character of the owner and sort of personal flavour. I love looking around at all the wall scrolls and other assorted hangings while listening to the oddball music (they sure aren't afraid of mixing genres!) and bopping my head. They offer vegan miso broth if you want, another huge benefit if you're a veggie and don't touch the bonito broth. I tried a few other things like the kampyo, it was good but nothing to scream about but the shiitake maki was very tasty.
author: Troy E.

description: This place is the adorablest.  It's like being stuck in a tiny japanese submarine, but with the fish on the inside.
author: Michael M.

description:
okay. this place is good. not great but pretty good.

the only that is not giving me five stars is the location and space of it all. it was marvelous hearing about someone's sex life and the intricacies of poop with dinner.
author: Derek Alistair J.

description: Talk about a hole in the wall! But it has the best sushi in SF! Great and fresh sushi, reasonably priced. My wife and I have been coming here for years, but not as often now because we have 2 kids and it is near impossible to squeeze a family in there! Sometimes we do take out from here but it's just not the same.
author: Benjamin W.

description:
great sushi and excellent japanese covers of famous english music.
great find.
author: s s.

description:
when i think of sushi time, i think of their mouth watering/ melt in your mouth sashimi, top notch service and decent prices.  


it definately makes my top 3 favorite sushi places in the sf.
author: Wednesday M.

description: small place but good quality! I only order nigiri when I am there, so I can't comment on other dishes.  However their fish is always fresh.
author: Ling Ling Z.

description:
Inari, kanpyo maki, avocado maki, vegi roll and vegan miso soup. The inari was fantastic - sweet and fresh and juicy, the kanpyo was soft and flavorful with perfect seaweed around it that was not at all chewy or hard to break. The vegi roll was also excellent and the avocado was soft like cream cheese. Miso was salty.

This is the best sushi I've had in SF and they are very vegetarian friendly. This place may even be better than Angel Fish in Alameda.

Atmosphere is very similar to Tokyo. Service was quick and attentive with lots of water refills. Price is worth it.

I have to mention that my husband got the albacore and could not believe how amazing it was. I think he cried a little bit.
author: Sarah J.

description: Pretty good sushi, they have great tuna. Thankfully it was not crowded, for a 21 seater. Their Sake sampler isn't bad either.
author: Divya R.

description:
YUMMY!!!

The fish is so fresh it does that melt-in-your-mouth thing!  The 6 pc. sashimi plate ($9.95)  had 2 pieces of tuna, 2 yellow tail, and 2 salmon - and my goodness was it good.  Next time, I would go for the 10 piece plate because I wouldn't be able to get enough of this stuff.

There was 3 of us, so we decided to also get an order of edamame and 6 rolls to split among us.  The following is a list of rolls we got, starting with the most delicious:

Astro Boy Roll
Rainbow Roll 
Crunchy Roll
GI Joe Roll
Bincho Roll
Spicy Yellow Tail Roll

All were so delicious, but the Astro Boy with yellow tail and mango definitely wins the award.  It was such a great combo of flavors.

Rolls were $4-$10.  The Rainbow was the most expensive.  But even the fun rolls like the Astro Boy or GI Joe were $7-8.

After 2 appetizers and 6 rolls (total around $60) among the three of us, we were all at a "good full" - not overly stuffed, but at a good full.  This is probably because most of the rolls we got were smaller than the average roll you would find anywhere else.

The service is great.  The music was fabulous the night we went (funky/loungy covers of pop songs from the 80's and 90's).  The food came out at a decent speed.

I went on a Tuesday night at 8 p.m. and although the place is tiny (only about 6-8 small tables to sit at plus the bar) it still wasn't crowded.  This was surprising because the sushi is so good, and the price is awesome!

ps- they have a happy hour too!  $3.75 for select rolls along with cheap prices for beer and sake.
author: Liz T.

description: I'm really not sure what all the rage is about here. My girlfriend and I went in here totally ravenous for sushi, and probably at that time, just about anything. The nigiri wasn't stellar, the tuna tasted "old" and rubbery. The salmon was a bit slippery, the hamachi was ok and the miso was decent. However the service was odd and cold and there was just something uncomfortable about this place. Although I love the subterranean location it tastes like the sushi was buried and dug up like kimche. With the profusion of sushi joints in this city I don't see that I'll be coming back here ever again.
author: Len S.

description:
this place was great.  

it feels like an authentic Japanese hole in the wall sushi place tucked in the corner of a small Tokyo shopping area.  

The sushi was superb, prices not ridiculous and superior quality of other places.
author: Matt V.

description: Jesse, Nelly and I ate at Sushi Time saturday nite. jesse had been here before and liked it. they have such cute names gi joe and stuff like that! yes, its all sushi, no extra other types of dishes, which is fine with me cuz i love sushi, but dont come with non-sushi loving friends. well priced, good food... i didnt like the yogurt drink but j and n did. this place is VERY small so i can imagine it gets crowded during busy times.
author: Merredith L.

description: This place has a crazy cool ambiance.  Super tiny with awesome kitchy decor.  The food comes fast and they have a good variety of sashimi and sushi. It is a true competitor to Sumi down on 18th street. I cannot wait to come again!
author: Emmie B.

description: After having experienced Sushi Zone, nothing really compares. Went here for happy hour. Rolls that are $4 can be found cheaper at other restaurants. Let's take the california roll for instance. $4, happy hour? Hmm, I have been to other places and are less than $4. $9 for their special rolls? I've had $9 rolls that were delish and even bigger. So, I felt a bit jipped.  It was small which I didn't mind it. I like small, hole in the wall places. But this place was just okay. Probably won't be back.
author: Audrey B.

description:
i have a hard time saying anywhere in the world has better sashimi than sushi ota in san diego BUT this place is, wait for ittttttt....., yum-o!
haaaa.
ok, no but really, there is a tuna and avo tartar starter that seriously is AMAZING. so yummy. really well-seasoned and perfect amount of garlic. 
i also was a super fan of the hello kitty roll (yes, it's really called that.). the tuna and mango combination works beautifully. my other rolls were decent, nothing to write home about but solid, good, fresh sushi.
the place is uber small and literally underground (all the underground talk made sense once we got there) but it isnt claustrophobic in the least. 
oh, and my girl b made best friends with the red ceramic cat thing sitting next to her. they pounded fists. yea. i know. i still heart her.
author: rachel b.

description: I have frequented (2-3 days per week) this establishment for quite some time now (@ least 5 years) and by far this is the best sushi bar in The City. For those of you who are not in the know, please keep standing in line for Sushi Zone. If you have that much time then you deserve to wait. By the way, I work for one of the Japanese purveyors for both the above mentioned restaurants and both receive the same quality seafood from us. Trust me, this little gem should be discovered, but if you are one who does not mind waiting for the same quality fish. Then by all means, be my guest and wait. I'll be having dinner.
author: Gabe T.

description: The sushi was excellent, but the service was a bit questionable though  I've had worse. The sushi made up for it. Ill definitely be going again.
author: Tom H.

description: I really, really adore this place.  The sushi is great (not Nobu great, but great for this price range) and the people are so friendly.  The sushi chefs say hi when you walk in.  With a place so tiny, they can afford to...nay, HAVE to.  The rolls are good, as is the nigiri - you can't really go wrong for a normal night out.  Go during happy hour to get a deal!
author: Nicole K.

description: Let me say all the bad things about Sushi Time: We had to wait about 10-15 minutes for a table (on a Monday). It was sauna-like inside - dark, dank, incredibly warm and moist. Even in the dim light, you could see clutter and cobwebs and things that hadn't been dusted in years. They have those really cheap chopsticks with all the splinters that you have to whittle off like a praying mantis. Our waitress wasn't the friendliest, and didn't bring the glass of water I asked for - just the glass - ???. So don't bother okay? I'm saying, it's just terrible... and I want all of their remarkably delicious and creative sushi, reasonable prices, and "secret underground magical cupboard world" feel for myself.
author: ert o.

description:
I agree with my fellow yelpers in that I love the hidden away Tokyo-esque setting of Sushi Time.   You walk into this little compound area, pass by a nutrition vendor, hang a quick left, down a stairs, then you are there.  

Love the Happy Hour (It's the only time I go)...can be pricey on a college student budget but its worth it every once in a while.  Place gets filled up quick because they seriously have maybe 4-5 five tables and a smallish sushi bar. 

In sum, good sushi, average price, cool atmosphere, go during the happy hour.
author: Sean G.

description: Totally hidden away off Castro, Sushi Time is tiny but cozy.  I think it fits about 25-30 people max at any given point.  Loved the ambiance.  Sushi quality was good but not exceptional.  Great service, though.  Pretty affordable, though - $5-8 rolls and $3-5 nigiri.  Sashimi dinner runs about $18.  I was so happy to come in off the street on New Year's Eve and not have to wait for a table ... other people who hopped in did, though, and there was a brisk takeout service.
author: Melinda C.

description: Best sushi in the city! I've been here many times and it's always a great place to eat!
author: Captain Muffin D.

description:
(Note: this review is for a visit about two years ago, things may have changed.)

At that visit, though, my friends and thought the sushi was the worst we'd had, and even left sushi uneaten.
author: Max D.

description: Great lighting, great quirky Japanese pop muzak, and really good reasonable food make this my new favorite sushi joint for casual and slightly rowdy outings. The all night happy hour on Tuesdays and really cheap good sake don't hurt either.
author: Stellah D.

description:
I used to live in the Castro and this was my regular solo sushi place. It has since become the destination for the sushi-madness moods that strike my beau and I on a regular basis. The fish is fresh and delish, the prices are stupid reasonable, the service is friendly and the place itself is cozy and comfortable. 

In the transportive space you feel like you could be in Tokyo (or Paris for that matter) as easily as you could be in San Francisco. It's a hidden little joint tucked underneath Books Inc. and a vitamin store. Once inside, you'll find a narrow, dim room with about six tables for two and a low sushi bar that seats about eight. Despite its size and popularity, it's never too crowded to get a seat and even when it's full, it's never too loud. 

The two servers who are invariably there are both very friendly and efficient. Often, when sitting at the bar, one of the two sushi chefs will take your order directly, while the servers keep you up to your ears in sake and Asahi and tea. If you're one who likes super elaborate, crazy maki rolls with jalapenos and grapes stuck in them, you'll be disappointed with the selections at Sushi Time. It's a back-to-basics kind of place and all of the maki is made with very little more than fish, rice, nori and green onion, occasionally with a spicy sauce for the "spicy" rolls. They do have a rarely changing specials list that includes the Speed Racer roll which is your basic tuna roll with some mango and spicy sauce---super yummy, but not over-the-top creative. The tai carpaccio, also on the specials list is difficult to eat, but once it's in your mouth, it's heavenly. 

Basically, this place is about the fish, and if you're not into actually tasting the fish in your sushi, you'll be better off with the maki menu at Blowfish or Tsunami (one of these places is not overrated. I'll give you two guesses as to which one. Hint: it's not Blowfish). I can never get enough of the sake nigiri at Sushi Time. I think they get their salmon straight from heaven. 

And when the bill comes, prepare to put your eyes back in your head when you see that your two Asahis, two large sakes and a gut-splitting amount of fine fish cost...$45. 

Dude, that's practically free in this town.
author: Sage R.

description: Great sushi.  Quirky vibe.  Super tiny.  I'm all for the senior special these days, so it works perfectly for me (no wait!).  I'd be willing to wait, though, 'cause the food is good and the vibe is decidedly not yuppy (not that I can in good conscience say I am un-yuppified).
author: Lisa A.

description: I actually had a bit of a roller coaster effect here, but walked away a happy girl wanting to come back and try more dishes. I came in excited to try, but as always a bit skeptic. Being sat was quick since we opted to sit at the sushi bar, but took a long time, at least 10 min, for them to even take my friend and I's drink order. I was not impressed with the way the fish in the sushi bar was kept, it seemed like a bomb went off in the fish cooler, everything was wrapped up, thrown in all willy nilly and looked just generally chaotic. That made me reluctant b/c it made it seem like the chefs didn't care about the fish. But I decided the quality of the fish looked alright and placed my order. Everything, and I mean everything we ordered was delicious! We chose: Spicy tuna roll, astro boy roll, boiled asparagus roll, a new sort of Alaskan roll, I can't remember the 5th roll, but we also had seaweed salad, edemame and a delicious pot of apricot green tea. Also everything on everyone else's plates looked delicious as well.  We payed about $20 each, including tip. So there ya go, sushi roller coaster: ups and downs but walked away very happy.
author: Jessica R.

description: SOOOO GOOOOOD!!! Very very small but the best Sushi I've had in the city!
author: Raina S.

description: A hard to find jem. This place is recessed in a shopping cube. Downstairs, this sushi joint is quiet and slow paced. If there are full tables, it may not be worth the wait. There's one sushi chef and possibly a slicer in the kitchen. The fish is fresh and the rolls are unique. Of course there are standards but I recommend the specialties.
author: Peter N.

description:
we used to love this place. then the other night my husband got the spicy hamachi roll as part of our take-out order and the fish looked kind of grey. i smelled it and refused to eat it. he said he thought it seemed fine. (he was really hungry). 

poor husband, he threw up all night. this was the second time he's thrown up in his life because he has a stomach of steel. this is how bad that fish was.

everyone gets food poisoning from time to time but this was entirely preventable. i'm not a fish expert or a sushi chef but one whiff of that fish and i knew something was wrong. i wish i trusted my gut and didn't let him eat it. 

i can't believe the sushi chef thought this fish was acceptable to serve. would never happen in japan or any respectable sushi place. 

so incredibly disappointed as this was our go-to spot for sometime now.
author: b r.

description: You enter the restaurant and you are transported to an oasis...A tiny space but definitely lovely.My roomie and I were so excited and did not have to wait that long and we were able to catch the Happy hour.We started with a large hot sake and a bottle of asahi as we browsed through the yummy selection of maksi and nigiris.I ordered the usual,Sake,Hamachi,Miguro,Shiramiguro nigiris.ahhh  ultra fresh and a piece of heaven in my mouth! Love this place and will absolutely be a regular.Don't forget their green tea Mochi for dessert.It's the perfect ending!
author: Paulina L.

description: Sushi time is a great place for a fun atmosphere and some really good sushi.  The rolls are not overly inventive but unique and they have green tea mochi which is always a plus, its tiny but a good atmosphere despite the initial mall like feel before you enter.
author: Doug D.

description: My fav sushi place.  Never had better salmon nigiri anywhere, cheaper than most sushi spots, rice done right, good atmosphere but a little small.
author: chad n.

description:
me love sushi. love it, love it, love it, love it. 

what a hidden gem. and i do mean hidden. but look closely and you'll find the cutest, coziest, freshest sushi joint this side of the city. actually, compared to a lot of the sushi places in sf, this one tops my list. 

1. best HAMACHI, hands down! 
2. great, tasty sushi roll selection with cute names (hello kitty roll, barbie roll) 
3. moderately priced (to me, i would say great priced for the quality)
4. nice, tight rolls (for those of you who hate when rolls fall apart before getting into your mouth)
5. fantastic details throughout the restaurant (lots of purty things to look at while you wait for your sushi)
6. not too crowded, COZY place (love that its hidden away from the main street)
author: Miss Lili F.

description: I love Sushi Time... it's really an adorable place.  They have an abundance of interesting Cali-Fusion rolls which seem to always delight my buddies, but the Nigiri is also super fresh and way more affordable than some places in the Castro vicinity... which delights me.  I must ask myself why I don't come here more often.  Also, their Kitsune Udon is quite comforting... for an otherwise rather standard noodle soup, the inclusion of fresh shiitake really livens up the dish, especially on those cold rainy San Francisco nights.  Double yum.
author: Maximilian P.

description: There are a lot of good sushi places in my neighborhood, but I'm currently totally in love with this place. The sushi is definitely quality, and their prices are better than a  lot of the places around. Went last night and got a 6 piece sashimi appetizer for $10, but the slices of sashimi were massive! - more like huge chunks rather than slices. The thing that gives it the fifth star is definitely the cozy ambiance. Don't get me wrong, you can't really go here in numbers greater than 2, but if you are just 2, it is perfect. The fact that it is tucked away in a random mall-like structure gives it extra points for its kitschy appeal. Another great benefit - I've never had to wait more than like a minute for a table, even on a Friday night.
author: Meredith M.

description:
I went there around 9:30 and the wait was about 20 minutes. Not too bad for a small sushi place. The inside is a bit cramped, but has a nice ambiance with cool decor and house music playing in the background. The wait staff was very nice and pleasant.

Now for the quality of the food. We only had sashimi and both my friend and I consider ourselves pretty good judges of fish quality. Sushi Time's tuna was below average. The rest of the sashimi (albacore, mackarel, yellotail, salmon) was average or, at most, above average. For the price it was a little disappointing.

Overall, its a nice affordable date place, but if you want good sashimi I suggest looking elsewhere.
author: Abhik P.

description:
The place is very small and tucked away, down some stairs off on market street. Fortunately, we were able to go with a group of 6 and be seated together. The servers were very welcoming and accommodating, even with our larger than average group.
The menu had a great variety and we ordered a bit of this and that. I got the seaweed salad, which was good. I also tried the chicken meatballs, which were tasty as well.
As far as rolls go, I got the dragon roll and the pickled diakon raddish roll. They were great, and very filling and fresh. I tried some other rolls that my friends got and nothing let us down. 
For dessert, we ordered some black sesame paste ice cream and some green tea and mango mochi. The ice cream was very good... and almost had a coffee flavor to it. The mochi was good as well (typical mochi).
The bill was what I expect from a sushi place (not too much, but not super cheap).
Everyone enjoyed it and I will go back again.
:)
author: Brian R.

description:
It pains me to write this review, because I used to love this place (gave it 5 out of 5 stars on 3/26/2008), but the terrible service and unnecessary wait has caused me to stop going all together.  I came almost twice a week, and invariably the manager's attitude toward guests has been cold.  

My most recent visit was especially bad -- we had a party of 3 but the manager misread the number and placed a party of 5 ahead of us.  Understandable mistake.  What's not ok in a restaurant is unsanitary conditions at the dining table:  my guests pointed out that the table smelled bad... a little like sewage.  And in fact, it smelled terrible because the cloth used to wipe the table was dirty and reeked of mildew.  The server had to re-wipe the table.  It still smelled bad but we stuck it out.  My guests encouraged me to not come back and cheered when I said I wouldn't...

So.... goodbye Sushi Time -- Barracuda is louder and more generic but that's where I'll go now.  Or Ryoko's on Post and Taylor.  Loud but the fish is better.
author: Benjamin L.

description: I love Sushi Time! I discovered this place via Yelp when I moved to the neighborhood a couple of years ago. It is super cute and tasty and the people that work there are really nice. There was a chef there for awhile that kinda stared creepily but I haven't seen him there recently, and it didn't stop me from going there for the good food anyway. I usually order miso soup and a barbie roll. Beyond that it depends on the company and my mood/appetite. Beware tho, it is not good for anything resembling a private conversation. You can pretty much gather the main topic of every conversation going on inside the little place.
author: Kate A.

description: Set in a blade-runner-esque bar to a soundtrack of anonymous cover-songs, this place exudes timelessness.  The atmosphere is fantastic, so is the sushi.  Also, everyone calls this place "Underground Sushi".
author: Jason H.

description: i will say the BEST of the BEST Sushi secrect spot in SF. Himmy place organized and clean. Good service and FRESH TENDER fish on every order. resonable price.....LOVE it so much~~
author: Jenny C.

description: Really cute joint, super cozy, and very reasonable prices!  But the food itself wasn't the best I'd ever had.  While the nigiri was excellent (particularly the seared albacore) the rolls left a little to be desired, taste-wise.  The artistry is amazing through - watching the sushi chefs work, I was in awe of the level of craft they bring to the food.  Oh and the sake is great too - the Dassai 50 was wonderful.
author: Elaine U.

description: A cute little hole-in-the-wall with great sushi at reasonable prices. I'm tempted to give it a bad review just to keep people away. :D
author: Ziad E.

description: I like the cozy, low key atmosphere of this place and the prices are pretty reasonable.  My husband pointed out that the atmosphere is like some of the restaurants in the movie "Lost in Translation," which is probably part of the reason I like it.  However, the sushi can be hit or miss.  The last time I went to sushi time, there was a nice long bone in my saba nigiri.  Not so cool.  I'll still come here for a beer and some cheap sushi when I'm in the neighborhood, but I don't think I'll be going out of my way to come here.
author: Michelle A.

description:
Maybe it was one too many Sapporos, maybe it was the house music in the background, but last night I had an awesome experience here.

The sushi was 4 out of 5 stars. You can find better sushi elsewhere in SF but you probably won't find this good of sushi at this price point. There were three of us, we all ate a ton, had a drink each, and still the bill was under $100. score.

The atmosphere was fantastic. It's small, so I'd be a little hesitant to try to stop by at a peak time. I showed up at 8:15 and by 8:30 all the tables were full.
author: Grant C.

description: The sushi is decent and the price is decent but it ends there for me.  This place is cramped and hotter than a fucking sauna. I got bumped in the back every single freakin time someone, anyone, walked by.  I asked for some miso or sweeter type sauce (cant stand soy) and was told they had nothing like that.  I pointed out some different types of sauces on the menu that was paired with other items and asked for those. After a supersecret conversation with the manager the waitress told me it was going to be extra in a manner that suggested I wasnt gonna want it now.  SO I said, "sure just charge me for it".  At this she went back to the manager and told him and he came over and told me there wasnt enough for anything but those dishes.  He clearly thought that the threat of an extra charge would "scare me straight".   Fucking hogwash.  Terrrilbe customer relations.  Plus there is a 10 dollar minimum per person. Not a credit card minimun mind you, an actual food minimum.  I mean who doesnt eat more than 10 dollars worth of sushi but it seems a bit stupid to put that on your menu.  I have no intention of sweating it out in this broom closet for half decent sushi again.
author: Dru P.

description: My new favorite place for sashimi. Great price, very fresh fish. The only complaint I have is that the restaurant gets to be a bit warm when is full. And the staff is very friendly. Definitely worth every penny...
author: L K.

description: Love this place.  Down to earth, yummy sushi (especially the tai carpaccio), and easy on your wallet.
author: Anya K.

description: Gotta love the atmosphere.  It's underground and I like that one yelper likened the experience to eating in a submarine.  It's very cozy and warm, especially after coming in from the rain.  Good fish, which i didn't expect to be fresh from the smell outside, but it was and good hot sake- all at decent prices.  The names of the special rolls are fun and they don't have the tally sheets for ordering sushi at the bar so it's more open to converse with the chef, which makes for a friendlier environment.  First place I've seen rolls with mango incorporated.  The cutesy details make this place special.  First, the size, then the stools at the bar, you get to pick your sake cup out of a basket and they bring your check in a small wooden box.  I love it!  You should go there once just for the experience and the sushi's worth it.
author: tamera t.

description: Went here with my boyfriend last night. Really cramped, but cozy, intimate, and cute. Good, fresh sashimi. Only problem was that the barbie roll was half the size but twice the price of Philadelphia roll. bleh.
author: tammie v.

description:
Definitely my favorite sushi place to eat at thus far.

I have to admit, this place wasn't that easy to find--especially since my date and I were from out of town.  When we were finally able to locate the place, we entered and were greeted by a kind Japanese man.  He told use that that the last table was currently reserved for three people but then he kindly informed us that if we would wait just 10 minutes, a table should be ready.  So after about five minutes, the waiter showed us our table and we were seated.

The decor around the small restaurant gave the place a really cultural and traditional feeling.  The paintings of samurais behind the chefs, the japanese dolls that were placed on the shelves, the pictures of japanese families, everything was pretty interesting to look at.  The restaurant was fairly compact and it kinda feels like you're sitting in an underground greenhouse without the plants.

For dinner, we ordered the goma miso soup, uni nigiri, barbie roll, maruko zuke sashimi, astro boy roll, speed racer roll, and the hello kitty roll.  

The miso soup was the best I've had so far.  As for the rolls, all the rolls were nicely displayed and each had something very distinct about them.  For the barbie roll, each piece of sushi had a small piece of lemon on top which the made the roll taste very fresh and provided a unique after taste.  The hello kitty roll was delicious.  The fresh fish eggs that just pop in your mouth and the fish that just melts in your mouth makes this a very surprising dish despite it's name.  The red snapper from the maruko zuke sashimi was very tender and fresh.  The unagi in the astro boy roll, topped with the spicy mayo and avocado, was a great combo of flavor that just melted in my mouth.  The tuna in the speed racer roll was just succulent and I can still taste the unique texture of it within my mouth.  Lastly, the most surprising dish in my opinion was the uni nigiri.  This was the first time my date and I had tried sea urchin.  The sea urchin was coated with a creamy sauce, which my date considered to taste like the "entire ocean".  I don't think I felt that splash of flavor but I have to admit that the flavor was completely unique (in a good way) and something that I could not compare the taste to.

I would definitely go here again, probably with a different date.  Have fun reading this patty :D
author: Quanghuy L.

description: Wow this place is tiny, but who cares when the sushi is fresh; rolls are perfect bite size pieces.  Right now my favorite Japanese restaurant!  Service on point w/o being over bearing.  Our food came out perfectly timed,  not jonesn desperately yet squirmin in anticipation! Sushi time...anytime!
author: D C.

description: On a recent trip to a conference, a former colleague and I were tipped off to "this great hole-in-the-wall sushi restaurant" that we had to try.  I agree that the "underground" description is totally apt, even if it's not part of the official name.  A sandwich-board sign on Market Street points the way down a hallway, down a set of steps, and through a pair of red curtains.  Inside, we were treated to a small (but cozy, not cramped), very low-key place, with friendly staff serving good quality food at very reasonable prices.  I can't compare it to any other sushi restaurants in the city, since I'm not a local, but for travelers looking for good sushi just a short ride down the F-line from Union Square, check this place out.
author: Andre P.

description: This place is great.  It's an extremely intimate little sushi bar on the lower level of a tucked-away shopping area.  The place has all kinds of character and excellent miso, not to mention all the other food.  I've never been disappointed there, once.  That is, excluding all the times I've showed up too late in the evening and they've been closed...
author: Robert P.
