description: I still love this place and went here again for the first time in months. I love it how they now have a tea menu where you can get a pot of tea...sooo great for the crappy weather night we had!
author: Karen B.

description: I absolutely love this place. I remember it feeling like the size of a school bus but I found it very cozy and welcoming. I like the decorations, especially, the textiles that cover the ceiling. The sushi is great and the size of the place makes the experience intimate and inviting. Can't go wrong with this place.
author: Gina C.

description: I tried Sushi Time the other day--I'd seen a Happy hour sign outside saying that they had specials from 5-7, but upon sitting down discovered it was only till 6:30(it was 6:45). Oh well..not the end of the world but they should update their signage. As it is, the sushi is pretty cheap anyways. Since I was by myself I took a seat at the bar for a quick dinner. The place is VERY small and not for the claustrophobic. Sushi was just ok...nothing that I'd rave about. I get much better at All Season on Castro. Might be a little bit more, but the sushi is better. The mango rolls didn't impress me.  I don't know...maybe I didn't try the right things, but I left underwhelmed.
author: kevin b.

description: Went here for a nice Valentine's Day dinner and my boyfriend and I absolutely loved it! I love the small atmosphere and super Japanesey decorations =) Not only that but their fish is AMAZING and so affordable! Their specialty rolls are quite delicious, everything was! We had the maguro, sake and hamachi sashimi, the Avocado Tuna Tarter, Goma (Sesame seed) Miso soup, spicy yellowtail roll, alaskan roll and the barbie roll! I recommend all of these! For dessert we shared the black sesame ice cream- DELICIOUS !!! Don't forget the large Sapporo's for each person, haha.
author: Remy K.

description:
Sushi is good and I like the atmosphere. But the Sake selection and price is terrible.  Had to take a star away.

Sake comes in small expensive flasks that are 2 - 3 times what other places charge.  Love to see them sell small 300 ml bottles in the 12 - 15 $ range.
author: David C.

description:
Sushi time is exactly what sushi should be - nothing more, nothing less.  The fish is melt in your mouth fresh.  They have 'fun' rolls, although none dependent on mayo for flavor.  When you get the fish right, you don't need to drench in sauce.  The barbie roll is all the excitement you need- perfect california roll covered in fresh salmon with a touch of lemon on top.  

Their spicy tuna roll is one of the best I've had, and their tuna tar tar is really amazing (I'd say as good as the tuna tar tar at Ozumo - and about half the price.)  

Don't go for swanky ambiance - but it's a gem of a 'hole in the wall' neighborhood sushi place.  Highly recommend.
author: Casey M.

description: Hands down the most charming sushi spot I have come across in SF. The sushi also impresses. When ordering saki you get to choose your wares from an assortment of tiny decorated cups. Its a nice touch.
author: John C.

description: Good sushi, at pretty good prices, especially if you go at happy hour.  I was once accidentally charged $1,779 for a bill that should have been $17.79 but they were so apologetic and helpful in clearing it up with me and my credit card company that I gladly go back.   I like that it's kind of hidden away off the street so you truly feel like you've discovered something special when you go in.
author: Sarah B.

description: That "omigod I'm going to the food court" feeling quickly goes away when you duck inside.  it's cramped (although the bar is fine).  the sushi is great and price affordably.  the sake flights are a good deal.
author: N C.

description:
this place was pretty good but i was highly disappointed that they have no udon or ramen and not tempura. i really enjoyed the fact that it is in the bottom of a crappy little "mall" in the castro. really, i did.
oh but the tea wasn't hot, at all.
author: Renee L.

description: One of the best sushi places in San Francisco! The prices are so good - especially considering how fresh everything tastes.
author: C P.

description:
The restaurant is small and cute. The ambiance is great. I love the decorations. It felt as if I was in an underground sushi bar in Japan. I ordered the "tuna and avocado tart" and the "dragon roll". The tart was interesting and the dragon roll tasted like any other dragon roll to me.

We were seated right away. However, it started getting really busy towards the end of our dinner. AND this was just a Monday night. It took about a good 30 minutes for us to be served all of our food. People had to wait. My brother had ordered three items on the menu but was still hungry. He was going to order another roll but was told he would have to wait another 20 minutes. 

Overall, the ambiance was great, the food was mediocre, but sushi time was not on time for us.
author: Tiffany H.

description:
passable ahi
curved glass, slow-paced, open air
doting neighbourhood
author: Scott S.

description: Because of Sushi Time, I now look down upon other sushi places. Okay maybe not look down upon, but they really can't compare. On first walking in, I really didn't expect it to be THAT small, so I was quite shocked. I then ordered a Rainbow and GI Joe Roll, which were amazing. The fish is so fresh, and tasted amazing. On top of all this the staff was friendly and there was not one problem with the service. Definitely plan on going back. Prices were not that bad for sushi either.
author: Andrew F.

description:
Just go. This place is fun, cheap and my favorite sushi in the city. Ok...Sebu and other good places are definitely competitive, but this place is absolutely awesome. Despite being in a weird looking mini mall, the atmosphere is actually pretty fun and intimate . 

Definitely go. This is coming from a guy who eats sushi all the time and has been around the world eating sushi...
author: Patrick F.

description: I love this place.. amazing sushi and in a totally unique location. Baked Mussels are a MUST have in this restaurant. The staff is always friendly and fast service. My only issue is on your sign outside they advertise happy hour from 5pm-7pm but once you get inside the menu says 5pm-6pm. Love this place so don't try to fool people! I will still pay for the experience because it's worth the money
author: R J.

description: I asked a friend where I should go for good sushi and she recommended Sushi Time.  When I saw that it is in the basement of a mini-mall, I was dubious.  I sat at the bar and chatted with the owner while waiting for my order.  The sushi was excellent, there was a very good selection for sake, and the service was perfect.  The sea urchin tasted like it had just come out of the sea.  It is an intimate place with great value for the money,
author: Robert H.

description: Best sushi in Castro, IMO.  Been going here for months and months, regularly.  For aficionados, get the chefs' recommendations, but it's all good.  Intimate and cozy.  Some of the servers could be more customer friendly -- lighten up, guys!  -- but they are acceptable.
author: BayGuy A.

description: really cute spot in the basement of a bizarro asian shopping mall. it feels like eating dinner in a tiny tunnel (or, like someone else said, a railroad car). friendly staff, decent menu, 10-minute wait on a thursday night around 8:15. the food was good, though i ordered pretty boring stuff. they have 3 different kinds of miso soup, though, which is rad.
author: Elle B.

description: went here as a change from my usual miyabi comfort sushi. i was impressed. my boyfriend apparently used to do takeout from this place all the time and promised i wouldn't be disappointed. i wasn't. the ahi-esque nigiri was divine, as was the red tuna appetizer. i was very impressed by the freshness of the fish and the ripeness of the avocado and mango (which i've had at all the local sushi joints and damn if some restaurants seem to get the most un-ripe mangos on earth) the waiter was amazingly nice and the ambiance is unbeatable. be on the lookout for it though, it's actually under a building and it's not totally obvious where the entrance is if you're not looking for their sign. another perk: really cool bookstore on the same block if you have time to get your read on before you get your sushi on. i'm definitely going back!
author: lisa w.

description: i absolutely love it. there are tons of sushi places everywhere, but it's hard to find one that makes you really feel like u're in japan. the size of this place is TINY, probably only fits like 20 people or less, 20 being really tight. everyone on staff is japanese, even the decorations are authentic. when i say authentic, i mean that they aren't trying to look japanese, it just looks that way because the owner probably wanted to make the restaurant look more like home. not only that, the food is amazing. the subtle and delicate flavors make me miss living in japan again, and i have hardly seen places use ingredients like real yuzu for flavoring other than in japan. love it!
author: Emy s.

description: i have never enjoyed myself or been charmed by a sushi chef more. noticing i wasnt a regular, he asked how i had heard of the tiny underground capsule of fresh sushi joy, and of course, i told him i saw him on yelp.
author: Lisa M.

description: love the food, the vibe, the underground of this place. I would go to this place anytime if I lives in sf!
author: lee lee l.

description: You won't find this place unless you're specifically looking for it.  It's hidden in a courtyard just off the street.  It's a teeny, tiny place, that's somewhat cozy.  The prices are pretty low considering 1) it's sushi, and 2) it's San Francisco.  They have a ton of rolls that sound like they would taste fantastic.   We had several pieces of sushi and a couple of different rolls.  The food was average at best, nothing to rave about.  That said, you get what you pay for.  Decent prices, decent food.
author: E T.

description: Delicious!  This tiny place is full of life and character - a fun place to spend a casual evening and get GREAT tasting food.  The Walu nigiri (Butterfish) literally melts in your mouth like butter, and the Mango Roll is a great mix of sweet, fresh, tangy mango, crunchy cucumber and buttery avocado. For fresh, tasty sushi at an affordable price, this is the place to go.
author: Julia H.

description: Their obscure location used to mean that they were rarely crowded, but Yelp & iPhone apps have given them away.  I still get regular cravings for their wakame salad & sushi.
author: Marc C.

description: decent sushi. Pretty big pieces on the sashimi plate, but the hamachi had a faint oder. Nice and cozy. I went on a monday and got a table right away but would hate to think what it's like trying to get seated thurs - sunday. service was allright. I'm not a big fan of rolls anyways, but was there with an out of town guest who isn't a big raw fish fan, so we got the crunchy roll and something else - very standard. The edamame were excellent though. They had aji, and it was very good, as was the saba.  $100 out the door for three people drinking 3 large beers...
author: tregar o.

description: I absolutely LOVE Sushi time! It always has the freshest fish and I love that it only has sushi. The happy hours are a really good deal too, you can get sushi, a salad, and Saki or dessert for like $15 or something. Anyway, this is a tiny little place with great, friendly staff and you should try it out and enjoy your time there!
author: Ali C.

description: if i could post the entire menu on this review, each dish would rate 10++ stars!! be sure to not miss out on the tai carpaccio and tataki sashimi to accompany a shot of cool unfiltered sake to start off a night to remember (or forget? :) with only enough room to fit perhaps 20, the decor is cozy and comfortable and not cramped, be sure to ask masa for the specials that day, although i doubt one can go wrong here. you'll laugh  to tunes ranging from jackson 5 to carpenters to jay z as each treat melts in your mouth! having eaten in quite a few japanese restaurants from the gold coast to yankee stadium to tokyo, i'm glad to have experienced the white tuna and mackerel for the first time here, cheers to sushi time! i would consider moving to the neighborhood if only for this underground delight, truly a delight for all your senses!
author: Hae-Jin K.

description: The place got 5 stars because it saved us on the day after Christmas when every other joint in town was closed. We had planned to go to Eiji which is another popular Japanese hole-in-the-wall but didn't realize that you absolutely had to RSVP there to get a seat since the place is so small. Walking away in frustration, our eyes caught a discreet small sign that says Sushi Time Fresh Sushi leading to a little alley full of flourescent lights. It looked very bland and unassuming but so hungry were we that we just plowed on, desperate, to see if we could find this Sushi Time. Boy did we ever! Tucked away at the end is the damnedest cutest charming down-to-earth-but-rocking little Japanese joint I've seen in SF. They even brought the checks in cute little Japanese ornate boxes which is a very classy way of business transactions in restaurants. The atmosphere and the service was excellent. The guy behind the sushi counter was working furiously but with great humor. Our waiter was very considerate and put us at ease. I can tell this is a local gem because the waiter, there is only one, asked us how we found this place so he knew we weren't locals. He was surprised we found this place quite by accident and what a great accident it was. The sushi was FRESH and SUCCULENT and the portions were very proper and filling. The prices were quite reasonable too. They served honest-to-God decent green tea the way it should be and the interior was just so authentic and genuine. There were a good number of locals and a good number of serious Japanese customers chatting away in their native tongue. We had a Blonde Roll special that knocked the socks off of us. I can't say enough good things about this place and no it's not because we were starving out of our minds after being kicked out by one other restaurant though that didn't hurt. Definitely go at night. That's when this restaurant really lights up with their Christmas tree light-esque decorations and candles and soft lighting tucked away from the alley.
author: Pamela L.

description: What's up San Francisco? For such a food town, you seem oddly inept at discerning good sushi from the mediocre. Sushi Time was a big disappointment for us. The fish was flavorless. Rolls were average at best. The flavors were mediocre.  Portions were modest.  It seems that because its hard to find, and pint-sized, diners instill Sushi Time with quality that is otherwise undeserving. Quaintly served and modest prices don't make the food better than what it is. Will not go back. The wait in line is SO not worth it....
author: M T.

description: Great value.  fish was fairly fresh and rolls were $4-5.  service was very attentive and took pride in their food.  would go again after trying a lot of other places.
author: Stacy N.

description: i absolutely adore this place.   it's like a precious little secret (but clearly not unknown based on the multiple raving yelp reviews).  it feels like being in a cozy modern japanese capsule with very tasty food and sake.
author: Missed F.

description: made a last minute decision to go eat at this place on saturday night. i was kinda in a hurry that night and i was hoping that there wouldn't be a long wait. i was pleasantly surpirsed to be seated right away. i've been here only once before, a few years ago, but i forget what my experiece was like. the food was better than average, but i have had better sushi in the city. the prices are pretty good though. considering this place is right around the corner from me, has good prices, and doesn't have huge ass lineups like other sushi places, i think this place is a good option for when i have last minute sushi cravings.
author: James J.

description: Not fancy, but in a funky basement-ish glass tube of a building. Go for happy hour, the prices are awesome. Certainly not high-end but lots of bang for buck at happy hour.
author: J B.

description: this is a hard to find location on market. you have to go up to noe and look for tower records. it's across the street, through a bookstore and down a stairwell. once you are there, you will always remember.  it's a cozy little place that looks straight out of tokyo with japanese poster and sticker decor all over....dimly lit....the spicy tuna hand roll is delicious...served in a  little glass...the sashimi melts in your mouth but the service wasn't so attentive....it took about 10 minutes before anyone took our order...may have been that we didn't "look" ready but water wasn't offered for a long while.  Otherwise, great food.
author: regina k.

description: LOVED it!  you wouldn't think it is going to be that great....but the seaweed salad, the miso soup, and the rolls are really wonderful!  Definitely will be back!
author: J F.

description: Not bad sushi at a reasonable price tucked into a little ally. What's not to like? Everything tasted fine, only the sweet shrimp had a slight fishy smell. Service was good as well.  Hmm, I guess my gripe is mostly that I went in expecting a 4.5 star experience from a secret sushi spot in SF and I simply got a decent experience. I suppose I was expecting there to be Toro, fresh wasabi on request, real crab in a crab roll or california roll or something out of the ordinary for people to pass it a 5 star rating. I would say that the yellow tail sushi was very good but overall not the fantastic experience I was hoping for.
author: Michael G.

description: The fish is fresh and delicious. The eel melts in your mouth. They don't use too much rice on the nigiri or the rolls. The miso is perfect. And it feels just like any sushi joint in Tokyo: intimate and literally underground. The only draw back is that you're sitting practically on top of your neighbors, but then again, that keeps it quiet and cozy.
author: Aimee S.

description: We go here all the time.  Great sushi. Reasonable prices. Very small and nice wait staff. The sound track is always awesome...
author: Michael W.

description: I almost don't want to hype this place because it is so small, and I'm afraid it will get to crowded, but, alas, it is so good and reasonably priced.
author: OperationWayne r.

description: This is a great restaurant. It's very small and tight, but it was warm (thermally-speaking) and dry on a cold we evening. I had the sashimi plate, and the fish was very, very fresh. The unagi/avocado/tempura roll was acceptable but unremarkable. Just a warning. Be prepared for a very cramped (but friendly) space. I sat at the bar and heard every word of the conversation of the first-date couple next to me, including how butch/fem they thought each other was, what Listz piano pieces they were each working on, why one of them needed a personal shopper, why one of them believed in lists but not new year's resolutions, whom one of them slept with when drunk last, how one of them thought the other's use of the phrase "can't walk and chew gum at the same time" was absolutely brilliant, why one was fem because he didn't like gyms, you get the drift; there's NO escape from your neighbors' conversation.
author: Ice Cream Truck I.

description: Cute, small, neighborhood sushi spot on Market Street.  Great prices, fresh fish, good for a group of 2-4 people.  I'd definitely go back.
author: Sarah K.

description: i dont understand how this place has such high reviews. the quality of the fish was poor. the fish were not fresh. the rolls were not that unique either. the staff is nice and friendly and pay much attention to their customers. anywoo, this place is so teenie tiny and its so hard to spot. its located down stairs of a strip on market street. this joint really needs a huge sign with its restaurant name on it.
author: Alexis S.

description: it's just simply fresh and good.  affordable for the quality to you get compared to other places too.
author: Truc N.
